Review_body: I recently watched this after Zack Snyders couple of new movie releases. This is better than the 2020 version in my opinion. Keeps you engaged.

I was not immediately thrilled at the concept of a DotD remake.  The original seemed pretty much complete in itself, and remakes are lame.Then I noticed Sarah Polley in it.  Now, for a talented actress, she has been in almost nothing south of the border since The Sweet Hereafter, and routinely turns down roles.  She simply doesn't do bad movies, and didn't here.  I found that intriguing enough to realize this was probably not a standard remake, and I bet right.And it lived up to its billing.  This movie hits the ground running and doesn't stop.  The first five minutes is perfectly paced and hits with sledgehammer force.  I knew I was in good hands when Johnny Cash's "The Man Comes Around" played over the opening credits.  Incidentally, I thought the opening and closing credits were comparable to another favorite set of credits, the ones in Se7en.There were only a couple direct homages to the original Romero film, one of them a setup for the shot from the poster of the original DotD movie.  I won't spoil this by naming the actor, but I think you'll see it coming. It's an intriguing twist on that moment.I won't comment on the obvious differences in the original, or the post-ironic conceit of zombies in a shopping mall in 2004.  (Zombies in a shopping mall!  Just like real life!)My gripes are very minor, and involve somewhat overdoing a few camera techniques that were also overdone in 28 Days Later.  However, one area where the film excelled was in pacing.  The violence was perfectly choreographed.  (Also, I want to marry Sarah Polley, but I'll save that subject for somewhere else.)I have seen reviews complaining of shallowness or repetitiveness, but I think such comments completely miss the point of a zombie movie, which is the existential horror of lurching sameness, and the complete lack of any moral complexity.  Zombies are simply insensate evil, and must be destroyed. The carnage does not involve human beings, nor villains, simply nonliving evil that must be destroyed.  Unlike the humans killed in a Dirty Harry movie or a war movie, zombies have no intrinsic value whatsoever.  There are no shades of gray, and no guilt in enjoying the slaughter.As such, the only way to judge a film is how it hits you in the stomach. This film had me cringing back in my seat from the first few minutes, and never let up.  I have to commend the opening, and how, like the zombies themselves, it moved fast, with a wonderful lack of stupid expository comments, explanations, or meaning.  Without hesitation, it simply jumps headfirst into the gaping maw of horror.In short, it is completely without any redeeming social value.And that is how it should be.This is an instant classic, and the crystallization of all zombie movies to date.

I just got back from this.It absolutely rocked.  I think it is the best zombie movie of all time, including the original Dawn of the Dead, although the pace was closer to Cameron than Romero.I was leery of the general idea of a remake of the Romero classic, until I noticed Sarah Polley was in it.  She simply doesn't do bad movies, so her presence promised something more than just a derivative schlockfest.
It masterfully combines the rollercoaster Hollywood film with the sheer creepiness of the original.  It also has enough of the light touch of the original to offset the horror enough to be just barely tolerable.Additionally, the zombie makeup manages to be campy and silly and terrifying at the same time.  This is a good trick.This kind of movie has to be judged with the gut, and I found myself cringing in my seat more than once.  It had a lot of similarities to 28 Days Later, but was just plain better, without the pacing problems of the last half of 28 Days.The first ten minutes are superbly paced, and the situation develops with a near total lack of the stupid exposition or explanation that usually interrupts the carnage long enough to be annoying in a disaster movie. The total collapse of society is so quick that it mercifully leaves little time for stupid talking heads.  The movie dives headfirst into the absolute horror of the situation without sentimentality.This also has the best opening credits I have seen since Se7en, with "When the Man Comes Around" by Johnny Cash setting the tone for the rest of the movie.The movie is packed with scenes so rattling that the rare calm scene where little is happening is completely nerve-racking.  I still have an adrenaline rush.Anyway, if you like zombie movies, this is, in my opinion, the ultimate one.  I liked the original, but this one takes the original and kicks its ass.  My only (slight) gripe is the overuse near the end of faux-clumsy handheld-style tracking shots, but I can live with it.  The scenes in question are still paced perfectly.  I also don't have any better idea for how they could have done it.  Obviously vanilla smooth Steadicam or dolly shots would have been completely out of the question.The best single performance in the film is Matt (Max Headroom) Frewer's, as a doomed zombie bite victim.  This scene includes one of the few direct Romero allusions, specifically the shot used on the most commonly seen poster for the 1978 classic.Another great thing about this film is it is the perfect film to knock Mel Gibson out of the #1 spot.

I don't find gory movies very good. But I will make an exception for Dawn of the Dead. I recently watched it, and I just have to say that it's amazingly scary! It starts off with Ana...(a nurse from a local hospital)...waking up to one of her neighbors attacking her husband, (Luis). Not knowing what to expect, she tries her best to keep him alive. But too late, her husband was infected. He became a part of "them". Pratically a zombie, trying to eat humans alive! Ana panicked, and went to the bathroom to hide herself from being hurt. She tried to calm herself from what just happened. Her own husband trying to attack! Being as calm and collected as she can...went and open the door-BAM! Luis's head pops up! He twist and turned...trying to get a taste of his once called wife. Ana, on the other hand, was shocked! Her heart racing, and pounding to get outside. She ran for her car...and saw something horrifying. All hell break lose; her neighbors were all infected... I can't tell you everything that happens, but you will enjoy this movie like I did.When you watch at least 15 minutes of it...your hand will start to tremble. You get shivers and goosebumps. I guarantee you.

I have to admit, the Zombie genre isn't my favourite, but Dawn of the Dead (2004) is a brilliant film for so many different reasons. In my view, it's the best zombie movie ever made.The actors are likable, which makes you empathetic to their cause. You want them to succeed, you feel sorrow when things go bad. My main complaint with so many other zombie movies is I couldn't care less about the actors. Also, in Dawn of the Dead, the quality of acting is good, much better than most other films of it's type.The film has plenty of action, but it doesn't detract from being a horror film. There's plenty of gore and quite frankly, the zombies scare the bejesus out of me (and I don't scare easily). I think one think I particularly like about this film is that the zombies are really nasty, fast, aggressive, in-your-face intimidating monsters who would really scare you in real life. I've just never been that keen with slow moving, sinister, but gormless, zombies. The zombies in Dawn of the Dead are truly terrifying.The pace of the film is excellent too. It moves quickly from scene to scene but at a good pace and covers many different things which keeps the film as a whole interesting.I really can't recommend this film enough. I really love it, and that's coming from a guy who's never been really in to zombie movies.10/10.

Review title: Warning Running Zombies but is still Awesome
Review_body: With most remakes they do not live up to the original, but in this case this one does in its own way. I am a Massive Zombie fan!Warning this movie involves running zombies! i am not a fan of running zombies but i give an exception in this one, the use of the running is great for building suspense in this filmthe opening sequence is amazing, there is no mucking around they get straight to the point, Zombie Armageddon!the Lead Actress Sarah Polley is great and believable with a resemblance to Gayleen Ross which is great casting. Ving Rhames is great as the emotionless Kenneth.Dawn has subtle references to the 1978 Dawn and cameos from original Actors which is an added bonus so look out for thosethis movie is an awesome horror and action suspense film with great humor mixed with the zombies, it is a great addition to the zombie collection especially in mineBeing his first film, Zack Snyder has done himself proud.

I do not understand why this movie has a 7.4 average user rating.There are no words to describe how bad this movie is, but here are a few key reasons of why I think this:The acting is TERRIBLE - Many of the dialogues are just retarded - There is NO character development - The plot is very simple and in many cases it just doesn't make sense - The filming is un-original - The special FX, and this is the least of all, are B-movie gradein fact the whole production is B-movie grade. There is absolutely nothing in that film that is worth watching. instead of leaving the original movie to rest in peace they created a "zombie" compared to what the original was IN ITS TIME.

Review title: Finally a truly enjoyable horror movie!!
Review_body: In 1968, a young director by the name of George Romero filmed an inexpensive horror movie that would later be hailed by movie critics the world round as a cult classic (and for good reason!) That movie was, of course, the black-and-white zombie flick, Night of the Living Dead.  I have seen the remake and it was truly enjoyable.  Now, as a rule, I tend to find re-makes unneccessary for the most part; the original films are usually classics and a re-make often lacks the same texture and feeling that the original had. There are very few exceptions, of course, and Dawn of the Dead is one of them.  First of all, let's face the facts about horror movies: most of the ones that have come out in the last year or two have, quite frankly, been nothing short of horrible, i.e. They, 13 Ghosts, The House on Haunted Hill, The Haunting, Wrong Turn, Cabin Fever and let's not forget the god-awful, pathetic excuse for a horror movie, Darkness Falls (if you haven't seen it yet, PLEASE spare yourself the misery and skip it...trust me, you're NOT missing anything...and if you have seen it, my deepest condolences for the time wasted watching it). There have also been some really good ones, most notably The Ring and Freddy Vs Jason (admittedly, it's really more of just a guilty pleasure for us NOES and FT13th fans)...I haven't seen the remake of Texas Chainsaw Masacre, but I've heard it's good so I'll rent it this Tuesday.  But I'm straying from the point here. Dawn of the Dead starts off right away with a sense that things are about to go wrong, or already have. The pace is very even, very fluid and certainly doesn't leave you waiting for the movie to get to the point.  It's effectively creepy, gory and scary as hell in all the right places and ways: what if you literally woke up one morning and discovered that the world you knew so well was changed forever? That the people you know and love are not only dead, but also part of the teeming thousands of walking, flesh-eating zombies on the hunt for blood? You actually care about the characters in here and fear that one of them will get left behind only to become lunch for the hungry dead.  **Possible Spoiler** Another thing I liked was the ending: unlike the low-key 28 Days Later, this movie's ending is much creepier, and without the happy-go-lucky "everything turned out okay and they lived happily ever after" kind of ending that 28 Days Later tried to offer us.  Plus, the zombies in here are really creepy, thanks to George Romero's famous touch.  Trust me, this one's worth seeing!!

Review title: Misleading title but still a good horror movie.
Review_body: When I came across this title I said to myself OK, Romero's Dawn Of The Dead is one of the best horror movies ever, why did someone felt the need to film a remake of it? Then I saw the preview and understood one thing, it was a different movie. The only things the two have in common is that people are hiding in a mall and there are flesh eating undead creatures.Notice I don't, and can't, use the word zombie because it's a known fact that zombies are slow creatures. Zombies who can run DON'T EXIST.This being clarified, and the initial deception being left aside. DOTD2K4 is a good horror movie, in the sense that there is no comforting mood. At no point, past the helicopter scene, one can think of of an happy ending. And that's just perfect.The good surprises come from the Director's cut DVD extras, On the news bulletin, we get to see a cleaning team in Monroeville PA, for those who didn't know, the original Dawn of the dead was shot in the Monroeville mall. There is also Ken Foree and Scott Reiniger from the original movie playing small roles. Ken as a televangelist repeats the same tag-line he gave us in the first movie : "When there's no more room in hell..." I give this movie a 4 not because it's that bad, but zombies don't run and I won't allow a director to play god with Satan's creatures.

Dawn of The Dead 2004Director:Zack SnyderStarring:Sarah Polley,Ving Rhames,Jake WeberThe original dawn of the Dead will always be the definite zombie movie and nothing will ever beat it but the remake is still pretty darn good. Instead of wasting all the time developing characters this movie is wall to wall action.which is no bad thing because the movie is perfectly paced and has a different feel than the original. You probably wont be learning the characters names but you will still get the jist of whats going on.One complaint i have is that i just didn't like the feel of the mall maybe because it wasn't explored but the originals mall just cant be beat. The Movie is more a re-imagining taking the basic survivors stuck in a mall idea and the similarities stop there. The story wont do anything for most but the pace and action will make up for it,while the acting is all pretty good apart from the red haired girl who loses her father,her performance was laughable.all in all a really enjoyable action flick!!!!3/5

Review title: hands down, THE best zombie movie ever.
Review_body: early george a. romero's gore-tastic films have a tendency to be, well, a bit humorous. the original dawn of the dead, don't get me wrong i love the film and it's a classic, however, it lacks the potent surprise of the undead and limits the potential of zombies. i'd say this film is the sequel Aliens to Alien. a bia-jillion times better. the originals are still good, but don't hold a candle to the next! this movie has every element of everything you've ever wanted from a zombie film. thoroughly entertaining and these are the best flesh eating undead zombies to date! incredibly scary and lightning fast. sit back and enjoy this action packed blood lusty zombie instant classic! 10 out of 10. if you ever watch one zombie film, this is it.

Review title: One of the best ever remakes?
Review_body: This has to be one of the best films ever made in the horror/ action horror genre. I was a big fan of the original George A Romero film, and went into the cinema with a cynical eye. But after ten minutes of the film I was totally won over. The first ten minutes of the film are hard hitting, and brilliantly directed. I thought the film would probably go down hill after such a great start, but the adrenalin just kept rising. There were parts of the film that made you want to cheer out loud.The screenplay and direction paid homage to the original film, but slickly mixed the 'old school' zombie film style with modern action and camera techniques. I was concerned that the makers may have made a completely different slasher style movie under the franchise of Dawn Of The Dead, but have indeed made a faithful remake, which stays very true to the original story.The casting in this film is superb. The actors have a good balance of not taking themselves too seriously, but being quite believable at the same time. CJ is probably the coolest warrior ever to appear in a zombie film!The makers have injected a small amount of humour into the film, which is more ironic than cheesy, which create some original funny moments. The makers have been very innovative, and have added some new ideas seamlessly into the action and story, making it fresh and interesting.It is refreshing to see organic gore effects, as many films now depend on computer imagery. The gore is nicely sick and bloody, but here comes my only criticism; there could have been more shots of zombies devouring human flesh and organs!If you like action horror, this film will blow you away. The rollercoaster doesn't stop until you find out what film they used to shoot it with! 9/10

Review title: One of the best zombie movies ever...(minor spoilers)
Review_body: I love zombie movies. I'm a big horror/scary movie fan and, as a rule, prefer suspenseful and creepy to gory and bloody, but zombie movies just blow me away for some reason. Ever since the original NIGHT OF THE LIVING DEAD which gave me nightmares as a kid, I just can't get enough of the genre.This is by far one of the best I've ever seen. The mixture of creepiness, spine-tingling "gotcha" moments, and prevalent humor is absolutely perfect. Even the typical asshole-redeems-himself-in-the-end is done in a fresh and believable way. His transformation is gradual so we buy it completely as true.The characters are truly fleshed out, and you get to know them all and care about them, which makes you kind of fight right along side them.I think one of the most disturbing parts to me is near the end before they leave the mall. Up till now, all through most of the movie, the cop and the gun-shop owner across the street have been communicating from their respective rooftops via binoculars and dry-wipe boards. First they play a game where the cop writes to the gun shop guy, "Do Burt Reynolds..." and you look down in the crowd of zombies lurching about the street and, sure enough, there's a zombie who's the spitting image of Burt. BLAM, the gun shop guy blows him away.Later, the group at the mall prepare a couple of large vehicles to be as defensible as possible so they can smash their way through the zombies and possibly find safety somewhere. They intend to go by the gun shop first and rescue the owner. But, something happens and he is bitten. The cop radios him through a walkie talkie he managed to get over to him to ask if he's okay. You see it coming. You know it's coming. You KNOW it. But, when the cop sees the gun guy climb up to the roof and begin writing on the dry wipe board, and the cop puts the binoculars to his eyes, well...it still breaks my heart to see it and it still makes the little hairs on my arms stand on end.Great screenplay, great acting, fantastic cinematography, impeccable directing. Probably the most entertaining couple of hours you'll have watching a scary movie.

Someone pointed out to me that 28 Days Later was not persay a zombie film... and true as that may be, my contention is that Zack Snyder's (who) Dawn redux is no more a zombie film than 28 Days. It is poorly scripted (by Scooby Doo's James Gunn, so what did we expect?) and more closely resembles a sequel to 28 Days Later than a reworking of the classic film it is intended be based on. Sure this one also takes place in a mall, and has cameos from 3 actors from the original, but where the Texas Chainsaw redux created an intriguing, suspenseful and original take on the 1974 film, it also captured the essence of Tobe Hooper's classic. Dawn 2004 captures none of that. This film supposes that none of us have seen NOTLD or DOTD(1978) and tries to pull us in with a dizzying 10 minute prologue, which is taught and well constructed but ultimately leads us to... well NOTHING!!! A bunch of people you don't care about talking, talking and talking some more and for good measure they kill a couple of "zombies" so we don't forget what the movie is supposed to be about. Some stupid comic relief for those who can't handle the "horror" (if you can call it that) and then the breakneck final act which is edited in that MTV,  shaky cam (Blair Witch), cut every nanosecond pace in which the "zombie" attacks in 28 days were edited or for that matter any typical "Fast and the Furious" action film of the past decade which is geared to appease the no-attention-span video game playing fans who make this kind of crap so successful at the box office. There were NO scares in this movie, every moment was predictable and formulaic. The attempt at character development via the silly and overlong conversations that took place around the coffee shop only served to bog down the film and I for one nearly left the theater 45 minutes in. Not a memorable performance among the leads. The best moments came from Tom Savini and Ken Foree in brief cameos. Ving Rhames even disappoints and one can only hope that Jack Lemmon hung on to that Oscar that Ving gave him. The film had some (too few to mention) moments, but then so do reruns of "Who Wants To Be A Millionaire?" With the recent releases of films like Wrong Turn, Cabin Fever and the TCM redux I was beginning to think there was hope for the horror genre, but after seeing DOTD 2004, I say let the dead STAY dead for now and cross my fingers that George A. can get his 4th dead film made. Any TRUE zombie fan who LIKED this movie needs a lobotomy. When there's no more room in hell... the dead will continue walking right past this waste of time!

This remake is probably the best remake of all time.  The director captured everything that Romero put into the original, and added some more.  The character's are realistic, unlike those in some horror movies, and the special effects are captivating.  The comic relief bits are funny, and give you a sense of security, when you already know there is none.  But we definitely have to thank the movie "28 days later."  If not for that excellent film, "Dawn of the Dead" would not have been anywhere near as exciting as it was.  I know most of you are true fans of George Romero, as I am one myself, but this movie does not knock his name from the top; it raises it higher.  I don't know about anyone else, but I give this movie a BIG 10, and will be back in the theaters very soon!!!

Review title: It's a zombie film, it credits Romero's Screenplay and it's called Dawn of the Dead; but somehow it doesn't feel like it belongs in the "Dead" series
Review_body: Have just seen the "re-envisioning" of Dawn of the Dead and overall really enjoyed this film (certainly more so than I would have expected).  The directing and shutter speed was very much in your face - this is indeed undead for the MTV generation.Phantom Menace was dubbed Star Wars Episode 1.  It sounded and looked like a Star Wars movie but after watching it the first time - you kind of didn't feel like you had just watched a Star Wars film.  This movie leaves you feeling the same way - it is a zombie film, it credits Romero's Screenplay and it is called Dawn of the Dead; but somehow it doesn't feel like it belongs in the "Dead" series.  For me - they could have given this one a completely non-related title and it would have stood on its own merits. Not being titled Dawn of the Dead would actually have removed much of the baggage that comes with reworking such a well-loved classic.SPOILERS> The opening sequence where Ana leaves her house and surveys the carnage taking place on her doorstep whilst helicopters buzz overhead was tremendous.  The aerial photography that follows as Ana takes a car journey to safety was breathtaking.  Awesome.  To be fair, as the opening credits roll - those scenes set a standard which the film struggles to maintain thereafter.Whilst the Mall in the original DOTD was brightly lit by fluorescent light this new film delivers a claustrophobic, spot lit location which ensures many shocks and never actually portrays the mall as a safe haven. Watching this film is a truly gruelling experience - I felt physically exhausted as I left the Cinema.In the original DOTD there is sufficient character development to ensure that we feel sympathy for the characters, we understand them and believe in them.  With the exception of Ana, Michael and Kenneth there is no characterisation in this new movie.  You never get to know the characters and writing these comments I am struggling to remember the names of the supporting cast.The plot suffered from many moments that just did not make sense: 1. How come Nicole drives the truck over to Andy's to fetch the dog? Couldn't they just whistle to recall the dog?  If you could get a truck over there then why didn't they save Andy earlier? 2. Why does everyone go through the sewers to rescue Nicole from Andy's shop? If you could get over there by sewer then why didn't they save Andy earlier?  Why bother messing about in sewers anyway when you have two reinforced buses in your garage? 3. Why does CJ hang around on the last bus instead of escaping?  This is purely a plot device to enable him to die an heroic death and redeem himself for earlier actions when he subjugated the other survivors. 4. Why did the bloated fat woman become athletic once undead?  Why does being undead bestow such high levels of physical fitness?  (Fitness that was not there whilst the person was in life)?I really struggle with this last point and whilst I welcome the zombie movie mini-revival which is taking place - I have to say that I am a bit of a purist and prefer the undead to shuffle along.  All of this running around is clearly inspired by "28 Days Later" - but let's be clear - the creatures in "28 Days Later" are NOT zombies or undead, they are plague victims.This sounds like I am moaning.  I am not.  DOTD (2004) is a great film - an 8 out of 10 for me and I eagerly anticipate the DVD release.It is well reported elsewhere but if you watch all of the end credits then the fate of the survivors is revealed; you won't miss this closing footage because a thoughtfully used "tit shot" ensures that the credits keep your attention!  (It works for me)!References to other movies I noticed included: PSYCHO - Ana falling in her bath and pulling the shower curtain down whilst covered in blood. NIGHT OF THE LIVING DEAD - Ana's car rolls down a hill and strikes a tree. 28 DAYS LATER - Substitute mall security guards for British Army troops ruling over the survivors; the virus based contagion and the athletic zombies sprinting to catch their prey. DAWN OF THE DEAD - Protagonists holed up in a shopping mall whilst the undead roam outside. ALIEN - although the filmmakers shied away from actually having an undead baby burst from the unfortunate Luda's body. TEXAS CHAINSAW MASSACRE - the scenes where Zombies are despatched from the outside of the bus and the horrifying scene where the blonde (don't remember her name) is sliced through - Tobe Hooper would have loved that scene in his movie! ZOMBIE FLESH-EATERS (ZOMBI 2) - Zombies occupying a remote island accessible by yacht. SE7EN - the head in the box.

Review title: Fast! Gory! SCARY! What more could you want in a Zombie movie?
Review_body: There are moments in this film where you WILL lurch, gasp, shudder, and, depending on your stomach, vomit.  I was very impressed with this remake. It does not strive to regurgitate the original.  Instead what we get is a fresh and dynamic take on the original film.  In the very basic sense, the plot structure is the same:  people seek shelter from cannibalistic horror in a shopping mall.However, the visual style, the acting, the characters, and the details are all different.  Whereas the original was more socially conscious, this remake seeks only to frighten and entertain.If you enjoy being scared and you enjoy that intense kind of anticipation and adrenalin rush, go see it.  But bring your barf bags!

I had great expectations - and I was not disappointed!More than just another remake of a classic picture. Very good special effects and a brilliant makeup makes the horror real. New ideas (the running zombies are now a real danger for all of our heroes) and a "new" plot with new characters! A very thrilling picture with black humor and bloody gore elements... I love it!!! My conclusion: Some people say, that you can´t call it a real remake of die original "Dawn...", because there are too much differences between the plots. But if there would be too much accordances, most of the people would say: "No new ideas! Why did they realize this movie? ... waste!" In my opinion it is one of the best remakes ever made!

Review title: zombie movies are freaky... THE END!
Review_body: i really liked this movie. i love horror movies, but zombie movies are the ones that scare me the most since dead people should stay dead! i haven't seen any good horror movies lately, so this is awesome. i like the fact that they go straight to the point: like, less than 10 minutes into the movie, hell breaks loose! and i also like the fact that they continue showing scenes during the credits since i hate it when we don't get to see the ending-ending in a lot of movies. the only things is, it didn't seem that believable: the whole running super speed/strength zombies. but it did make the movie freakier. there is one scene that i can't stop thinking about and it's the one with the dog and the sandwich going to andy, i was freaked since i'm a big dog fan. well, all i have to say is that you should watch it since i'm sure there won't be a really good horror movie coming out anytime soon!

Review title: Better than I guessed it would be
Review_body: I am writing this as a fan of artsy fartsy visual storytelling rather than one who loves gory graphical horror, or the zombie theme as a whole. I can't say i disliked DOD '04, although I don't think it is as masterful as the original. Keep in mind that DOD and DOD '04 are hard to compare since they definitely differ a lot in style and audiovisual expression as well as plot-wise. Perhaps Romero would have liked the possibilities new technology in film-making has brought with it, but the '78'er's the big advantage over 04 is the fact that horror easily gets a bit pathetic and not scary. A zombie model '04 is a remarkably scarier creature than its cousin of 1978; it moves as fast, or even faster than a living human and is a goal-oriented killing/eating machine. Thus one of the main points in the original movie is lost. The inefficient, slow ex-consumer stuck in a circle of reliving old habits and instincts in the mall of the '78 version is long gone, while horror movie clichés are planted everywhere. There is, however a very good take on the consumerism of today still left, revised but intact, and that sort of saves this new version from being gory rubbish, at least seen from an artistic and social commentary oriented point of view.The very important words Us & Them and the them still have their meaning here, but sadly, in a way, the threat of other human beings in the "chaotic end of the world zombie takeover"-sort of situation is in a way replaced by raging zombies that are pure monsters rather than stupid corpses suffering from hyperactivity The acting is, I think, more professional, even if not always much convincing here in Zack Snyder's version. I can, however say that I liked the urban, cynical, rich, modern, pathetic asshole ("Steve") played by Ty Burrell. Visually its prettier and creepier and more dramatic but also introduces the risk of too much action, which there definitely is. Together with the industrial heavy metal inspired soundtrack the taste of splashy, mediocre horror is present, luckily combined with an interesting picture of life in the early 00's. It's also sad that the sound mix didn't have what it takes to boost horror.Through the movie we get the chance to compare dignified deaths, stupid deaths and the messy deaths of fighters, but the outcome is always the same in a meaningless way that very well concludes the whole mood of the film, where the viewer can observe the danger of the most loved but always lying part of the human imagination: Hope.

I usually don't see movies like this... I usually don't see horror movies period. This was an exception because a certain magazine gave it an A and my local newspaper gave it a B. So maybe my mistake was having too high hopes for this one.According to the reviews, it was witty. Really, it was? Because I must have totally missed the witty part. Even that sarcastic guy who shows up was disappointing. I was expecting humorous comments. Didn't get 'em. The funniest part to me was when Ana was driving away and we get a bird's eye view of the town after the outbreak, and this car comes full speed, misses her Toyota by a few feet and slams into the gas station. It's not like I was looking for 'Frasier' quality intelligence here.It was also supposed to be scary. Nope. I jumped a couple of times, but that's really it. Gory movies are often mistaken for scary ones.The acting was... sub par at best. Where was the character development? Ving Rhames is always angry. Sarcastic guy is always... cynical. And Sarah Polley is always willing to rise to occasion, as well as that guy Michael.All in all, 5/10.

This movie is prolly in the bottom 3 movies ive ever seen!! first it starts off horrible, with the girl goin home and sees her kid as a zombie when she wakes up.. i was thinking it was a short film at first cause there was no introduction into the film.. and some how the kid got the sickness thing, from some unknown person... then they are at a mall, and that andy guy and vin ramns or whatever his name is, are writing messages back and forth to eachother???? waht the hell was the point of that...then the stupid girl and her dog... lets go chase after a dog into a crowd of 10000 zombie things.. then while in the mall, the movie just goes in a whole different direction, and like cuts to people having sex, and other crap... im not sure if this movie was a comedy or a horror movie... cause during the whole movie, everyone was laughing at how dumb it was.. im p***ed off that i spent 8 bucks on this crap.. i want my money back.. this movie was just like the 25 day.. but 100X worse.. im not sure if the director watched that movie and tried to copy it or what.. it was a cross between that movie and house of a thousand corpses... anyway i have to many bad things to say about this movie, and not enough time to say it.. i rate this movie -6 out of 10..

Loosely based on the original, this has fast moving , aggressive, smarter (although still dumb) zombies - unlike the shambling zombies zombies of the original. Continual action, quite a few laughs - watch out for a Burt Reynolds lookalike (and some other celebs) zombie being shot from the rooftop. Also some funny dialogue between the survivors. Great soundtrack too - particularly the end credits - quite stunning images cut into the credits together with a fantastic track - make sure you watch it until the very end! The original and this 'remake' is essential for anyone's film collection (well, ok, maybe not if you are a Sound of Music person).Right up there with the best zombie movies. Enjoy!

Review title: Resident Evil, eat your heart out
Review_body:
I'm not normally a big horror fan, as a majority of the "horrors" that I've seen have, at best, only one good jump-inducing scene, with a few cheap obligatory "shock" moments that rely more on surprise than horror to scare you.Dawn of the Dead is intense. Really intense. Intense intense intense... the pacing of the action beautifully creates the feeling that everyone is just hanging on for their lives, and breaks are few and far between. About mid-way through the action slacks for about 10 minutes, and I felt myself welcoming the mental break almost as much as the characters themselves.
This is a fun movie... make sure to see it with a group of friends, and don't get up to go to the restroom. And unlike most other zombie movies, the zombies are actually pretty scary... I've heard a few complain about the idea of a fast zombie, but the slow, shambling zombies of resident evil look absolutely lame in comparison to these fast, screaming unfortunates.
This is horror at it's purest- the crap's been cut, the action is inense, and nothing is sacred. Wow.

Review title: Excellent,even though I'm not normally a fan of horror movies
Review_body: It's kind of interesting, but I was invited to the movie premier in Los Angeles through a mutual friend...I am not a fan of horror movies(as mentioned above),but I thoroughly enjoyed the movie for three reasons: 1)It was really an action movie which kept you on the edge of your cf your seat through the whole two hours..Sure,it had some gore & blood, but it didn't make you throw up, unless you have a weak stomach..There are two scenes which made me a bit queezy, but on balance,it was exciting,quick,& never a dull moment.....2)The music was great!..The introduction by Johnny Cash appealed to some of us in the older generation & was on the money!.....& 3)there was some humor which was totally unexpected & seemed to provide a balance to a very heavy/dark theme.....Actually, I went home pretty exhilarated, which was the farthest thing in my mind when I entered the theater..So, I gave it a 10& there are only two other movies I've given that rating:"Scent of a Woman" & "One Flew Over the Cookoo's Nest"...Well worth seeing!!!...Thanks for the opportunity to express my opinion....Ed

I am 67 years old & my grandchildren prevailed....They said take us to the movie because we need an adult to accompany us..So I went with them, making sure that there was no one under the age of 15....After a myriad of previews,"Dawn of the Dead" started...The movie had me on the edge of my seat for the entire time(including trailers)....The music was great, there was good humor, there was what you might expect in the realm of gore(but it was more of an action movie).....All in all,it was a great movie & I came home really pumped up....A great movie far surpassing the original(which I turned off after 10 minutes)...Recommend it to anyone who still has a strong heart & not a weak stomach!!!!!!Ed

Review title: Bites its way into the top 20 horror movies ever
Review_body: I will admit I am not a huge fan of horror movies.  I decided to see this movie after seeing the first ten minutes previewed on channel 4.  It had me hooked and wanting to see more, as all movies should.  A very engaging and well done start.However, the rest of the movie, as i have found with many horror movies was a bit of a let down.  They seem to be full of wonderful thrilling moments that capture what seeing a movie in a cinema is all about.  Don't get me wrong it is a very good film, filling all of what is expected of a horror genre movie.  Am i wrong to want more from the genre?  I am beginning to think so after watching such recent horror movie's.Just as forgettable as it is fun.  A rollercoaster ride of a movie, but don't expect realism, innovation or any life changing moments.

Review title: Worth Seeing, even as a fan of the Original.
Review_body: Ok then, as an avid fan of the original i was sceptical about this new version, whether it could live up to the hype or not.However, i was very glad to say that i really enjoyed the film. The characters in the film are a nice mix of stereotypes - who complement each other very well while doing well not to annoy the audience. And it's good to see a bucnch of people in a horror film that actually use a bit of common sense for a change.The zombies in the film are great aswell, they are still primitive but from the trailer you can see how agile they are compared to their 1978 counterparts which of course give them an extra edge that the humans have to deal with. Hats off to the Special FX and make up in the film, they do a great job, the zombies look exactly what you would expect them to be.There is plenty of gore and action in the film but nothing too over the top, which is mixed in with a refreshing slice of humor aswell. The plot allows the film to build momentum, however, i think in the advent of films becoming longer it could've benefitted from an extra 30-40 mins in the middle.For fellow hardcore Romero fans: i'd recommend it - good film, and theres some goodies in there for our benefit too.For everyone else: Go see it, simple as because you'll enjoy it.My vote: 8/10

Review title: A more than worthy remake of the best movie of all time
Review_body: Some are bothered that there would be an attempt at a remake of such a classic as the original Dawn of the Dead. This is not a typical remake but as the director said it is a re-imagining. I loved the first movie and loved this movie. I absolutely refuse to compare the two as each has its own qualities and inspirations. I can only say I left the theater with an ache in my neck from the tension.The opening of the movie, as many have said, is as scary as any movie ever made. Although I would have liked to have seen more of societies break down, the opening credits did a wonderful job of a quick summary of the fall of civilization.The pure terror and shock that Ana must have felt was superbly displayed in the opening scene. Watching the DVD over and over, I can find different attacks and reaction by several neighbors. The whole scene does a fabulous job of showing absolute kaos descending upon suburbia.There may have been some disposable characters, and sometimes the characters did not behave in ways in which we think we would have acted. But how many times do large groups of people, under great stress always do the right thing. Overall, absent the unreality of the movie, I thought it portrayed the people in a very real way. Excellent acting, story, camera work and worthy of being a re-imagining of the best movie of all time.The DVD also explains many plot holes that may have been found in an initial theatrical viewing, either via Andy's tape, the news reports or deleted scenes.Finally do not turn the movie off before the closing credits end. This is one of the few movies to watch from the opening frame until the last credit is over.

Yes, I was at first pretty skeptical of this remake to Romero's memorable class-sick. WHY??? It's not like it was an older B&W B film, although I always preferred the original NOTLD in B&W for the grim mood it conveyed.Anyways, a friend convinced me to watch this 'remake' on DVD. I'm now very glad he talked me into it. The opening was smashing, and had me immediately engaged - not a single wasted second, thanks to good camera-work and tight editing. The sense of tension really grows as it appears that most of the world is now under siege from the killer-zombies. There is a strong, building momentum to the pacing and escalating menace which the characters now find themselves cast adrift in.The zombies move at a very fast pace in this version, giving it a riveting action edge. Comparing both the original and this remake is an 'apples & oranges' thing to me. Both stand on their separate merits, and actually compliment each other. Like showing two different perspectives of the zombie invasion from two different towns, and the similar gut reactions of both groups of desperate characters. Yay, I know, how does that explain why they are swift in one area and near-crippled in another??!! I'll consider any sound suggestions.For a taut entertaining horror/thriller this does deliver and it held my suspenseful interest til the end. The lead woman was the best character, followed by Ving Rhames who is solid and believable. I cared about the fates of everyone, and that is always a good sign, or, in this case, a bad sign. The sense of dread is prevalent throughout.One problem I had was that no one ever asks what is happening, what caused this; etc. They just accept it like recurring characters on a TV series. If you were suddenly caught up in this bloody nightmare, wouldn't you wonder what has caused this, and what the authorities are doing about it? The news announcers don't ever mention anything either or even express any wonder. Things like this can erode any suspense the film is trying to create.Otherwise, the zombies bear similarities to the infected 'zombie-like' killers in 28 DAYS LATER, but I found this to be a far better film. There are only a few gory moments, but they work within the film's tight structure. You may want to rent it some night when you're in the mood for a good zombie thriller. Just don't expect a great masterpiece.

Review title: Higher classed in the low class genre of zombie movies!
Review_body: Whenever I begin watching a modern movie with the slightest hint of zombies in it, my expectations are never high, and this was completely true for Dawn of the Dead. So, when I sat down to begin watching, I was expecting a movie more to the likes of the horrendous Night of the Living Dead 3D; definitely not up to the standard of a George Romero classic. However, Zack Snyder impressed and surprised me with this movie.The plot was obviously moderately based on the Romero take of the movie, with an all new set of characters. Combined with the modern CGI and effects we have today, this 2004 was a close competitor to the highly set bar by the OG of zombie movies.I loved the way the characters use ingenious methods of zombie aversion, and Snyder's modern take on the original shuffling zombie is a fresh take on this classical genre. Despite this, some of these zombie slaughtering ideas by the group seemed almost too comical for a movie without the comedy tag. Overall, Snyder's Dawn of the Dead is a great movie, with a revitalized take on the Romero benchmark. While it may not be equal to it's predecessor, this movie is a great, edge of your seat watch that I would recommend for any zombie lover.

When I first heard the 1978 horror classic dawn of the dead would be remade, i felt pretty skeptical, knowing todays horror movie makers tendancies to neglect story and atmosphere in favour of cheap scares(monster jumps out and yells BOO!) and over the top computer generated effects.My first qualm when seeing this movie was 'running zombies', I felt this displayed a level of dexterity which shows them less like creepy 'living dead', and more like living people infected with cannibalistic urges, obviously an attempt to keep in touch with peoples new idea of zombies as seen in 28 days later, and though this leaves less room for tension it does allow for some exciting scenes and some visceral action, the characters arern't too imaginative, most of them we know nothing about(eccept that they will die),and the movies attempts at humor often fall flat because they are dropped in with little subtlety. On the plus side this movie really does look good, the make up and effects are convincing and the story has enough new material to keep you on you interested, though this isn't the thoughtful journey of survival or suspenseful horror that was the original, it is a pretty entertaining action movie which wont make you think, but will make you watch and listen.

I've always loved horror movies. I REALLY like zombie movies and I know that the zombie survival guide is a must read. I've always wished for an Solanum outbreak in real life, as I was sure I was prepared to deal with them properly. Not any more. This movie makes zombies scary again. Now I'm not so sure I could survive. This is how horror movies are supposed to be, and if you haven't seen it, then you haven't seen enough zombie movies. Plus the ending is perfect.Overall it's a great remake of the original (which is a must-see as well). I was told that some of the original cast was involved, which is certainly cool, although you can enjoy this version on it's own.POSSIBLE SPOILER:Don't stop watching until the credits are over.

Romero's original Dawn of the dead is without question one of the best horror films ever made, as is the Original "Texas Chainsaw Massacre". With the re-make of that last film in mind, one could have very easily disregarded the remake of Dawn. But within minutes in Dawn's re-make you know you are in for a much more original film than Texas re-make.Dawn starts with Johnny Cash's "The Man Comes Around", how is that for an introduction, and what follows is just as good. The story floats around fluently, and just as in the original, much comment is given on today's society. This could easily have become an over-producted-special effects-gore fest, but instead, most scary moments are just brilliant editing and directing,as was the original. The difference between Dawn's re-make and Texas re-make is that both the original films had good story lines,a terrific premise,and were much better production than most horror films. The producers and director of the new Dead, have staid very close to the good elements of the original and have put in some new ingredients. Texas re-make kept only the premise and became, well a film massacre. This new Dawn of the Dead is one of the best horror films of recent years, and should give the director much recognition as was given to Romero after his first Dead film. Scary as hell, well made, good performances, excellent camera and editing makes Dawn of the Dead a must see film.

It seems most comments are coming from horror aficionados who have seen the original. I'm not one of them. I have neither the time nor the inclination to watch a movie more than once... Indeed I rarely watch a movie in its entirety unless it is really compelling. I didn't expect this one would hold my attention longer than a heartbeat. To date, I've seen it three times. It's a fun escape.At 40 I'm at the tail end of the baby boom. A lot of consumer goods and services are targeted at us boomers; it's a big demographic. This includes movies. As I've gotten older, my tastes have changed - mindless gore no longer cuts it. A lot of idealistic, corny, social commentary makes me roll my cynical eyes dismissively. And blaringly, loud, shock scenes are just annoying. Dawn of the Dead 2004 seems to have been made for boomers. The vicarious experience was just right. The non-zombie characters could be my friends or co-workers. The story doesn't stretch reality to the point of being silly; you only have to suspend your belief where necessary (vis-a-vis zombies). At the same time, it doesn't attempt to be too serious either. To put it in some perspective, the Die Hard films don't use a supernatural element, but are they really any more probable?***Potential spoiler ahead*** I enjoy pondering what I would have done differently had I been there. The mall was a good idea though an airport might have been better. I think that Andy would have had a hunting bow and could have shot an arrow trailing a fishing line across to the mall roof. With that they could have passed a rope across allowing weapons, food, and even Andy himself to get over. Anyway, enough said. See the movie.

DOTD 2004 is brilliant. We haven't had a noticeable zombie film in some time now, and this more than makes up for it.Its exciting, emotional, its tense. Its also dark but has a sense of humour that surprisingly works well with the rest of the film. I love watching horror/sci-fi, and thought I could stand any level of violence. But this film is particularly violent, and all the better for it. Unlike the original, the zombies can't easily be outrun; they have super strength and pose far more of a threat than the ones in the tame original ever did. Whilst it does share some common elements to the original, it is not an exact remake. This one is far superior. The people act how you would EXPECT them to act (such as the people in the mall) This one also leaves a lot of questions unanswered (just check the message board below to see), and a sequel has been announced.Let's just hope its better than LOTD, which I hear is disappointing.

Review title: This remakes place in the trilogy
Review_body: First of all, let me say this.... this is one of the most awesome horror remakes I have seen in a while. Many times you see a "newer" version of an old horror classic and it falls well short of the thrill and chills the original gave you. This movie set the scene in the beginning to show you how much we take for granted our everyday lives, and how normal they are, how dependent we are on the rest of society to remain "normal" and ordered.Then all hell breaks loose. The action and thrills were on par with the original (which I watched as a child and was on the edge of my seat). This movie did not have Romero's flair, but then again, I guess it wasn't supposed to. My only gripe about this movie at all was that the zombies were fast, not slow. 28 Days later introduced the "fast" zombie, but then they weren't zombies, they were just "infected".... but i know a zombie when I see one. This movie seems to me like it was trying to recapture the audience that went out to see and liked 28 days later. They did a great job, but I just wished the zombies were bit slower and they had've stuck closer to the main script. What really impressed me about this film the most I;d have to say is in the end, when they took the boat and landed on an island.... Fulci's next zombie flick took place on an island... nice hand off, someone did their homework.

2004's Dawn of the Dead is possibly the greatest horror movie ever. In 1968 indie filmmaker George A. Romero reinvented horror movies with the cult classic Night of the Living Dead. A few years later he brought the sequel Dawn of the Dead, still one of the highest grossing independent films ever. Director Zach Snyder keeps up the tradition with his 2004 remake of the classic. Snyder's simplistic idea of zombies running brought a whole new kind of terror to our generation. Instead of pussy-footing' around, this movie jumps straight into the action and oh is it sweet. This movie has possibly the greatest opening credits in movie history. The movie still has the same scenario of survivors trapped in a shopping mall which is surrounded by flesh-eating monsters. The actors performances allow you to get sucked into this movie all the sooner. I love everything about this movie, especially the color of this film. The makeup effects in this film are spectacular. The original theme of the film was about humans never being satisfied and the remake does keep this theme and also gives it an Alamo feel. Dawn of the Dead is non-stop horror action and truly gives justice to the original and should not be missed. I hope Zach Snyder is here to stay because he seems to be one of the few directors who knows what he is doing. If you only see one horror movie in your entire life make it this one. I give dawn of the dead 10 stars out of 10.

this is definitely one of the better remakes. I would have to say this movie is actually better than George Romero's original 1978 version, which was also pretty damn good. Starts off with one of the most frightening scenes of the movie. A group of non-infected civilians bunker down in an abandoned shopping mall and join forces with a few rental cops. They then struggle to survive and fight off what seems to be a never ending on-slaught of zombies who want to enter the mall. One thing that differentiates these zombies from others is that they have some pep in their step, they can run! The actors play convincing roles. There is extensive violence and gore, especially in the uncut DVD. You can clearly see this was produced with a decent budget by a major studio (universal). I highly recommend this movie. Get the uncut version on DVD if possible.

How do you turn the everyday world into a zombie nightmare in 10 minutes? Take a story from one of the worlds leading horror masters (George Romero). Hire a fairly unknown young director (Zack Snyder). Toss in a seasoned actor (Ving Rhames) and shake well ! I have never seen ANY segment of ANY movie, much less a remake, that has grabbed my attention so totally and unmercifully as the first 10 minutes of this film. By itself, this beginning would win all awards in my book for pacing, creepiness, action and absolute doom and horror.Once the adrenalin wears off, the rest of the film is amazing. Don't get me wrong.I am a huge fan of the original offering but this version can stand all on its own and is now officially my favorite.I see great things in this young directors future. The acting, special effects and storyline are all spot on.Thank you George and Zack for the roller-coaster ride to Hell ! Can we go again soon, please ??

Review title: A true masterpiece, this movie is the pinnacle of the horror genre
Review_body: Never before has a film had such a remarkable combination of perfect acting, an imaginative and lurid plot, and above all, believability. No movie has ever had such an impact on me, not even any of the hundreds of movies I have watched when I was a child. No accolades or awards will ever do this film justice. Dawn of the dead is the pinnacle of the horror genre. Nowadays, many movies have resorted to sudden plot twists and ridiculous dues ex machinas and other hanky-panky acting to keep its viewers awake. This is especially true in the horror genre. However, this movie of sheer perfection is completely realistic yet still contains all the undertones and values in United States as well as all the common plot devices.A mere ordinary American is subjected to an unimaginable horror in a way that seems far less distant than the other scenarios in other movies. This American is neither an omnipotent hero nor a coward, but an ordinary American. At first, the death and carnage is shocking to her, along with many others she is stuck with, but in the mall with all the now-abandoned merchandise, a disquieting routine sets in that shows the characters happily enjoying the luxury of the place rather than thinking of solutions. Eventually, conflicts between the characters threaten the survival of all, while a vastly greater conflict looms. It is under the duress of this scenario that all the facets of the ordinary Americans brought together in the mall is represented. For example, CJ, the most colorful character is a problem solver and rational man who has the most exceptional physical abilities as well. Most of the other characters get in his way but all have different ways to respond to the situation. It is because of this realism that CJ's final heroic act (that would have only been written off as senseless violence in other horror movies) is so heart warming and powerful. That simple scene was the most powerful scene in any movie I have seen because it represents what a true American hero would do in such a scenario completely accurately. He doesn't have a full two minutes to say a goodbye to his girlfriend, he isn't gonna save all mankind by single-handedly stopping a barrage of nuclear missiles, he isn't going to protect earth from destruction by aliens, but he does act in the heat of battle to perform one final believable heroic act. This is the only movie I would ever give more than a perfect 10/10 for, nothing compares to its elegance.

Review title: the trailer was better than the movie !
Review_body: The trailer for the movie was good.  Too bad the movie wasn't.  The eerie images had sensational angles, shadows, and lighting accompanied with music that matched went well during the trailer. It's a shame that we didn't see a lot of that in the movie.  It made the movie seem stylish and scary. When the film stops, melts, and the zombies try to come for the audience out of the screen, that was a pretty clever way to end the trailer.  They should have made the movie end that way, too!  Most of the scenes in the trailer were at the beginning of the movie before the opening credits.  In the movie, the director drew the viewer's attention to certain things that ended up to be insignificant.  What was the point?  Could it be to make us think it's going to have an interesting plot with twists?  Well, don't think too hard about anything that goes on because it's pointless.  Were the zombies everywhere?  How far do you have to go to get away from them?  And why did everyone end up at the mall?  Did the mall employees all turn into real zombies?  They should have put in computer generated flies around all the zombies.  Now that would have been clever!  This was supposed to be a horror movie, but it ended up more like a "HORRORble" drama with a few thrills thrown in during the first ten minutes.

Remakes. that word sometimes makes me cringe. we have a slew of them getting churned out of hollywood these days. some work, i.e. the ring and the texas chainsaw massacre and well, some don't. (shaft always comes to mind on this one.)as i entered the theatre with my wife and brother, my expectations were high for this. after a few trailers we were off and running. i had already previewed the first ten minutes of this film on the USA network and i was already intrigued. From there, the movie never let's down. We are quickly met with a few survivors who, as anyone already knows, decides to take refuge in the mall. When they arrive in the mall, they meet up with a few security guards and decide to whole up there for a while. later on, a few more survivors show up and carnage ensues.Now, what makes this one more different and better to me than the original are these few things:1.)when they arrive at the mall, it's closed. hasn't even open for business yet so there are no zombies inside.2.) the use of shuttle busses at the end was creative. i like that touch. use what you got.3.) the humor was excellent4.) the characters were great, especially cj and michael and ving rhames character. sarah polley was given a strong female character in ana. thank you for giving a strong actress a strong role.this movie is far better than the original and if you don't sit through the credits, you may miss something special.by the way, the whole baby thing almost lost me on this movie, that was the only one cheese factor.
