Let me start out by saying that I have not seen the original movie... well not at least all the way through. But I imagine that if any other movie would make a perfect remake of it, it would be this one.When I first saw the movie, I hadn't heard of it, so as a typical horror-survival horror movie fan I wasn't expecting anything. About 10 minutes into the masterpiece, I found myself on the edge of the seat. The movie wastes no time on the unimportant, but really gets through to the viewers.The best thing about the movie was probably the behavior of the people trapped in the mall - how they really looked out for each other (well, at least some of them) but meanwhile were ready to do about anything to save their own lives. Specially loved the Andy/Kenneth relationship.*SPOILERS*The cast was also perfect, as were the dialogs, writings, etc. There really is nothing bad to say about the movie. So why did I give it 9/10? Because the red-head (can't remember her name) really angered me when she was risking her and the group's life when going after that stupid dog. But in the end it did become the breaking point of the movie - they had to leave their secure mall and head out. It's still one of my favorite movies ever. Great job! Keep 'em coming.

I'm astonished that this movie is as good as it is.I had heard good things about the job Snyder did with it,but was stunned to find it is as good as Romero's original film.I saw the original back when it came out(1978?)and have been a big Romero fan since.I cant believe I'm saying this,but Romero may have been out done in sheer intensity.Sure,the social commentary which was so out front in the original barely registers here,but this one never lets you take a breath.While watching this movie I found myself so involved with the characters and thier actions that I had to stop myself from hollering at the damn movie screen when they were in danger.I wanted to help them.The acting is really good.The gore effects are stunning.If you like Zombie movies,or love George Romero,go see this movie.A+++

Note: my opinions will cause a furor to die hard fans of the original.I am old enough to remember watching Romero's original. Even as a teen, it struck me that the acting was bad, the zombies looked blue and some of the pacing was poor. The scope of this movie feels much bigger.Synders remake is superior in every way. Starting with the cast. the acting is just fine for the horror genre. The characters are less cardboard and cartoony than in Romeros. The effects are consistent and more realistic. The zombies are far higher quality and in more advanced states of decay, not just "blue". In this version, the zombies run. This didn't sit will with fans of the original. Given that the undead are a relentless menace that can be anywhere, this story amps them up. They have primitive hunting skills, strength like a human on meth, and they don't hesitate. They can climb and perform simple tasks. They are far more believable as a menace than slow, dumb, ambling zombies. you can't just pie these zombies in the face like a black comedy, they will run you down. They will stalk you like a rabid wolf, so you can't just cross an fence or climb a ladder and be safe.This films pace is far better, it does not lag like the original. The sub plot of Andy in his gun shop is masterful addition to play off in the story. You feel genuine sympathy for the character. You also feel a sense of hope when the cast develops a solution to escaping the mall situation. When they are escaping, there is a iconic scene of throngs of zombies you won't forget. It's an awesome spectacle that really sells the idea that they are outnumbered 400,000 to 1 by the undead.This movie does not resort to camp like the original, and there is a lot of action, and a lot of gore. It has a much glossier feel to it than the original and holds up to repeated viewings much better. I suggest you watch it in black and white for a different experience. This is the best (serious) zombie movie since night of the living dead. it is underrated by the rabid fans of the original. Young people who see this version first will not enjoy the original. They will look at the original as a cheap movie with slow, stupid zombies. If you like zombie movies, this is top shelf.

i really enjoyed this film. i'm a big fan of the original (and can't wait for the big oversized dvd set coming out towards the end of summer) and i enjoyed this rethinking of the basic premise of it a hell of a lot. great ensemble cast, innovative direction and killer musical cues. (johnny cash and the vegas lounge version of down with the sickness were friggin inspired) i sure hope the longer form dvd gives us a bit more on the character side, cause these people were far from 1 dimensional and i want to learn more about them all. favorite scene was the overhead helicopter shot of sarah fleeing in her car and the surprise event that happens right in front of her on the highway, it was the money shot that ended a 10 minute roller coaster ride that was the beginning of the movie.
(SPOILER)- man i hope they got away from those undead b**tards on that island, we never technically saw them killed, so i suppose there is  a slim  chance they managed to get away. i want twighlight of the dead from the same people responsible for this film, i want ving and sarah and the kids, and i want it sooner rather than later. this was a fun flick!

Having only "28 days later" and the Simpson's Halloween specials as reference for zombies, I'd say this is an excellent zombie-stompin movie. The roles played by the original "Dawn of the Dead" cast were also very cool. It lacks the social commentary of previous zombie flicks, but it doesn't detract from the experience.The film makes a point of establishing the reality of the world pre-zombie takeover, so the frequent defiance against of the laws of physics is troubling for some (anal science freaks like me). A filled propane tank ways 40 lbs. and there is no freakin way that they can be thrown that far, regardless of a ripped physique. Also, the number of direct headshots delivered by handguns is completely ludicrous, but now I'm being petty. If these attacks against the laws of nature scare the bejeebas out of you, maybe zombie flicks aren't for you.Snyder does a good job for a first time out director and the cinematography is superb. The music selections seem odd at first, but suit the film (all hail Richard Cheese!).8/10

Having recently seen the original (I bought it so I could get the Hellboy Sneak Preview DVD, plus I own Night of the Living Dead and Day of the Dead, I went into seeing the reimagining (the new Hollywood buzzword for remake) with an idea of why the first has such a huge reputation among horror fans.The original is slowly paced with a small cast.  The makeup is generally crappy, but some of the splatter effects are pretty good.  The blood looks like reddish paint.  The characters are pretty well drawn out and well-rounded.  The shopper mentality allegory still holds up well.  All in all, a pretty good movie, and I can see how it would have been somewhat revolutionary for it's time.  Romero knows his zombies.Fast forward almost 20 years and enter James Gunn, the writer of Scooby Doo the Movie and The Specials.The Specials, if you haven't seen it, is an extremely funny superhero parody film, and in my opinion, better than the bigger budgeted Mystery Men, which came out at the same time.  However you couldn't pay me enough to watch Scooby Doo.  I won't even watch the cartoons.Dawn of the Dead is definitely a post-28 Days Later zombie film.  The camerawork is flashy, yet at times, grainy, the zombies move at a lightning pace, chasing and often outrunning their victims.  Even aside from being a remake, the ideas are culled from every other influential zombie flick of the past twenty years, with subtle nods to the Evil Dead series, Dead Alive, 28 Days Later, etc.Despite the inherent flaws, the movie accomplishes exactly what it sets out to do.  It's a scary movie.  Everyone in the audience jumped exactly when we were supposed to.  We were grossed out when we needed to be, and we laughed when it was deliberately funny.  Overall, it's just a highly entertaining movie.The basic plot follows Ana (Sarah Polley from Go) as she wakes up one morning to find her neighbor's daughter in her hallway.  Ana's husband goes to the girl, only to get his throat ripped out, kicking off the action forthe rest of the film.  Ana flees, horrified, refusing to be approached by anyone, living or dead.  Shortly thereafter, she runs into Kenneth (Ving Rhames of Pulp Fiction), a cop heading toward an alleged safe area. Almost as soon as they set off together, they meet three survivors who have decided to seek refuge in the local mall.  Of course, at the mall, they meet a handful of other survivors, and begin to formulate a plan of escape.There are quite a few scenes of solid character building, making the major characters into real individuals, however the supporting cast are generally just caricatures.  But overall, there are just simply a lot of "cool" bits that, sure, they may be just filler, but it's interesting and exciting filler.Some of the cast of the original "Dawn" make cameos.  Ken Foree (Peter from the original) plays a televangelist, and gets to say the tagline in both films (When there's no more room in hell, the dead will walk the earth). Tom Savini (Special FX guru, and a biker from the original film) plays a sheriff who figures out a way to kill the zombies.Matt Frewer also has about 2 minutes worth of screen time in the film.  It made me sad, mostly to think that this is now his career.  Poor Matt Frewer.There is another character in the film named Steve, and the entire time he was onscreen, I could only think one thing: "That should have been Bruce Campbell."  The actor playing Steve looks like a younger Bruce Campbell, the character has that sort of smarmy, cocky charm of a Bruce Campbell character, he just should have been Bruce Campbell.The soundtrack surprised and impressed me.  Being a big budget studio popcorn/action film, I expected a soundtrack full of the latest altnewxradio friendly fm rock bands.  Instead, the music is mostly very offsetting to the film, giving it a little more of a creepy edge.  The opening credits are run to the tune of Johnny Cash's "When the Man Comes Around".  On the other hand, the end credits have Disturbed's "Sickness" playing, but to offset that, during the movie, the same song is played, but performed by Richard Cheese and Lounge Against the Machine.  I may seek out the soundtrack.All in all, I loved this movie, it creeped me out.  I love/hate zombies, and this did well by the zombie genre.Stick around for the end credits.  All of them.

I had insanely high hopes for this movie when I first saw the trailer a month and a half ago.  I don't know exactly what I expected, but I think I expected to much.In one of the first scenes, we see a girl skating away into the sunset, we know trouble lurks ahead.  That's fine and dandy, foresight, it's all good, but this movie ends up being so predictable in every scene to the point where it is boring.  Granted, we do get a few good surprises, but every time someone goes off alone, you know a zombie will be somewhere waiting. Every time you see a fail safe plan put in by the actors, you can almost forsee it verbatim, and that's what horror is not about.  At least not to me.  Maybe I was expecting an Evil Dead quality film.But i'm not all dissatisfied, you see.  The movie has style, humor and an overall feeling of hopelessness.  The zombies look great and the special effects aren't bad.  The actors, while convieniently labeled personality wise (or not developed at all) do a good, convincing job.  I would recommend this to a horror fan in a second.  But if your looking for the feeling that famous trailer gave you, you might want to go elsewhere.Also, Johnny Cash, and Richard Cheese, the people who put this movie together have good taste in music.

Review title: Surprisingly good remake of a classic
Review_body: As I first saw the trailer of DOTD 2004 I had a bad feeling. I've seen so many awful remakes of great movies. But this one really surprised me.Dawn of the Dead 2004 is a great horror movie with thrill, style, very good art direction and perfect (very gory) special effects. The mood is spot on and gives me the same feel like the original. The music is totally diffrent than the old Goblin stuff, but it also works very well. I was glad to see some of the original crew like Ken Foree and Tom Savini. Nice touch.All in all a "must see" not only for fans.

this was a great scary movie,i was scared to death as all of the other people who was watching it,  my girlfriend doesn't like the dead movies as much as i do but she went with me and she was scared also.the actors and actresses was great in the movie,i wish i could have been a zombie in that movie,the only part i didn't like was that the part where they had to shoot the baby but again i guess i would have too just to survive the ordeal,just think if it ever could happen it would be heck to deal with in real life.i give this movie A +++++++++++++++++++++++++ all the way i am going to see the movie every time i can in the theater as much as i can,when it comes out on video i am going to buy it to add to my collection.

Well, I just got back from seeing this movie and am still in a bit of awe.I thought it was a great remake of a classic film. The storyline and jolts were evenly distributed throughout that film. The humour was placed at a perfect point. I loved when they shot the zombies and labled them as "Jay Leno" and "Burt Reynolds". I thought that was sooo great. (SPOILERS) I didn't like how the ending went through the credits.It didn't ruin the movie, but I sorta wish they would have kept going with the ending without the credits interrupting what happened next. That was my short review. All together i really liked this movie and encourage those who like horror films to see this.

Review title: It's not Romero, but it's not Rob Zombie either.
Review_body: ***SPOILERS***   ***SPOILERS*** I haven't seen George Romero's version of Dawn of the Dead since it was first released on videotape, so I really can't say how faithful Gunn and Snyder followed the original story. I have heard that the original was more than a standard horror movie, but also a social commentary on American commercialism and consumption. Be that as it may, it doesn't detract from the fact that this newer version is a fun, fun movie with its own strengths and message. The message of course is that if you run across a zombie that looks like Jay Leno or Burt Reynolds, shoot the hell out of it and laugh your ass off, because there aren't too many things to guffaw at when the whole world wants to chew on you.The opening begins with Ana (Polley), a registered nurse in Everett, Wisconsin who is just leaving the hospital when her shift is over. When she pulls into her driveway, she sees the precocious Vivian, an 11-year-old neighbor girl who wants to show off just how adorable she is by showing Ana her newest rollerblading skill. Ana goes into her home, has amazing standing up in the shower while the water chafes your skin sex with her loving and perfect husband (who cares what his name is, he's Alpo five minutes later), and lays down for a peaceful sleep befitting an Angel.When morning comes, the sun is shining, the birds are singing, all is pure Disney until cute little Vivian enters the bedroom because either her television is on the blink, or there's no more raw meat at home to satiate her new born hunger. Poor old no-name husband feels sorry for the bloody darling because he knows what it's like to miss The Power Puff Girls and runs to Vivian's side to console her; then wham-o! No-name is running around with teeth marks in his neck and trying to scream, which is hard to do when you have a gaping hole in your throat. Somehow, Ana is able to put a door in between her and Vivian, who happens to still be hungry, and watches as her husband dies.and rises again. Instead of jumping joyously screaming, `It's a miracle!' Ana is fighting for her life because no-name would rather eat her instead of his usual bran muffin, which is wholly understandable. Ana barely escapes with her breasts still on her chest instead of in no-names gullet, runs out to their car, and there we get to see one of the coolest, `We're not in Kansas anymore' sequences ever made. Her once peaceful and placid neighborhood is now an open buffet for the undead. Fire and screaming is everywhere she looks, people running for their lives, and other people running for their breakfast. Ana gets into her car just in time before her husband can goose her from behind, peels out of her driveway, and hauls ass to anywhere but there while her husband chases her, which he quits doing once he sees some other prey unlucky enough not to make it to his Desoto. From a bird's eye view, we see Ana driving pell-mell on the highway where she causes a truck to swerve into an old farmhouse causing a spectacular explosion.then the opening credits appear.I was hooked, so was most of the packed theater there to see the show. I've got to hand it to Gunn and Snyder, because they really know how fish. I was baited, hooked, and reeled in only 10 minutes into the movie. The audience was thrilled. People were yelling, cheering, and laughing from beginning to end. Everyone was overjoyed with the special effects, the shock, and the dark humor that's prevalent throughout the film. I really enjoyed the subtle humor used with the 'muzak' used over the loud speakers in the mall.I'm sure that you all know that the survivors make it to a mall and that's where they make their stand, if you want to call it that. We meet the cop Kenneth (Rhames), a big giant bad-ass with a shotgun and an attitude, Michael (Webber), a guy that first appears to be there to either be a living villain or weakling, but becomes a principle character with fortitude and intelligence, Andre (Phifer), who is accompanied with his soon-to-be-bursting-baby wife, Luda (Korobkina) and CJ (Kelly), a security guard who has a superiority complex and a gun. The rest of the people may as well have worn their red Star Trek uniforms, which doesn't mean they all bite it, but that they aren't the emotional center of the movie at this point.But, the true stars of any zombie film are the zombies. I know that, you know that, and fortunately for us, Gunn and Snyder know that. No more of the lumbering hulks that are only dangerous if a character gets trapped or if the character happens to be a female. In Dawn of the Dead, the zombies have all taken track in high school. They run at blistering speeds, show acrobatic talents as they fly through the air, and swallow their food without adhering to the Surgeon General's warning that every bite should be chewed 26 times. They also show a greater strength in their problem solving skills, unless, of course, figuring something out would be detrimental to the plot.If you're only there for the gore, you won't be disappointed. There's enough of that to keep even the most disturbed individuals anchored in their seats. There are also some really cool explosions, imaginative death scenes, a cute little doggy to feel afraid for, and a very large body count. It also shows why you shouldn't play with Daddy's chainsaw while standing up in a fast moving truck, just in case you weren't sure. If more horror films followed the example laid out by 28 Days Later and Dawn of the Dead, there just might be hope for the waning horror industry. I might just become a fan again.

The plot is about a female nurse, named Anna, is caught in the middle of a world-wide chaos as flesh-eating zombies begin rising up and taking over the world and attacking the living. She escapes into the streets and is rescued by a black police officer. So far, so good! I usually enjoy horror movies, but this piece of film doesn't deserve to be called horror. It's not even thrilling, just ridiculous.Even "the Flintstones" or "Kukla, Fran and Ollie" will give you more excitement. It's like watching a bunch of bloodthirsty drunkards not being able to get into a shopping mall to by more liquor. The heroes who has locked themselves in, inside the shopping-mall to avoid being eaten by the hoodlums outside, are not better either. Even though they doesn't seem to be drunk, they give the impression of being mentally disabled. Save your money instead of spending it on this!

I thought this movie was good, fun in many situations, not very scary if you have seen horror before but good entertainment for a Saturday night. The only thing that bothered me was the color of the blood that flooded in the movie: not natural. The bad guy did a good job playing the pain in the ass. And what's a good thing in my eyes too: the color of the people didn't matter in this plot to their chances on survival.the fact that it wasn't so scary for me can be explained a bit because of the fact that similar scenes e.g. fights with the enraged undead appear in for example '28 days later'. Compared to 28D's the storyline of this movie is a little lighter. More concentrated on suspense.

If you are a fan of the original "Dawn of the Dead" that was released in 1978 by superior zombie director George A. Romero, you won't like Remake. I consider The Dawn of the Dead 2004 to be one of the worst remakes in the history of filmaking.  Dawn of the Dead 2004 is nothing like the original it was intended to be remade in, on the contrary, its its own movie.  It should not have been called dawn of the dead.  The original Dawn of the dead had excellent character build and delicious old school make up effects by Tom Savini.  The zombies were slow and stupid hence the name "zombie".  The Remake has far too many characters to like, accept maybe Ken ( Vingh Rahmes).  The Remake also had a diffrent breed of zombies than the original, the fast zombie which is a rip off of 28 days later.  The original Dawn of the dead is actually a HORROR movie.  The remake is more of and action suspense movie.  If you want to see a beautiful candy colored zombie movie watch the original ( 10/10) if you want to watch an action/thriller/suspense/monster movie then watch the new dawn of the dead(-10/10) starring vingh rahmes and sarah polly.

Review title: faster and scarier by miles leaps and bounds.....
Review_body: the zombies do that too by the way. this dawn was going to be a 1 in a million shot. it would either be #1: another hollywood remake that brings in the bucks, but leaves out the entertainment.  or #2: a fast frantic ride thru hell with very little room for it's characters and story. well it's #1 and #2 in a nice neat little package that IS another hollywood remake and it WILL bring in the bucks, but the entertainment is not only there but it often times feels so pressed in upon you that you have to crouch in your'e seat and just surrender to it. and #2 it IS a VERY fast and frantic ride thru hell but it actually seems to - be prepared to gasp - CARE FOR SOME OF IT'S CHARACTERS! the story is the same as it was in the original but this go-round we get to see it happen from the very beginning, the onslaught of what's to come.*but be warned this is a blood-soaked movie from 3 minutes in, to the last name in the credits* grade A entertainment!!!

Just for the record, I'm a die-hard Romero fan. I didn't mind the running zombies one bit...I thought the opening was first-rate, as well as the title sequence/montage. The zombie baby was OUTSTANDING, and was something I'd pondered and debated with fellow Romero fans for years. Even the VERY end of the movie (during the closing credits) was rather disturbing. I'm glad they removed the proposed scene w/the "zombie dogs" (and truth be told, I'm equally happy that Romero removed the proposed "zombie rats" sequence out of LOTD). The makeup was terrific, and the gore/head-shot effects were top-notch.I don't know a thing about making movies. But I can get a feel for good dialog writing as opposed to not-so-good dialog writing. I gave the movie a 6/10 solely due to the fact that most of the dialog was TERRIBLE. This was mainly the case when everyone got to the mall, and seemed to continue from there on out. Even despite CJ's redemption toward the end which makes him likable, he has some of the WORST and corny lines. Everyone (as seems to be the case in mainstream horror movies) was written to try to act and talk "too cool," and at times did not behave at all the way that people would behave (even in a melodramatic way) if this situation were to actually happen.Maybe it's just that I'm not sure whether the creators were going for a serious or satirical zombie movie. I don't think a good balance is achieved here. The opening is EXTREMELY serious, and then 45 minutes later, Kenneth and Andy are shooting celebrity look-alike zombies from the rooftop of the mall and laughing; Steve's getting some down below, and two twenty-somethings are having a relationship blossom by laughing and having fun after they just shot the girl's father an hour earlier (a VERY serious and sad scene). It just goes from WAY light-hearted to WAY serious too many times, IMHO.Overall this is a good movie, and I do watch it every so often. (6/10)

Review title: Zombies, violence, sex and shopping malls... What more could a girl ask for?
Review_body: ***This contains spoilers - I have tried to keep them relatively non-specific, but you have been warned :D***I must confess that I have never seen the original take on this film, and to tell the truth, the teasers I had seen for this remake had me thinking that I would be spending my boyfriend's hard earned cash on yet another cheesy gore-fest. I was so incredibly wrong!This film is incredible. The early normality as Ana (Polley) concludes her shift, and goes home to her suburban life only heightens the complete horror that follows. Aside from an undercurrent of foreboding, the audience can almost be lulled into a false sense of security that everything will be OK...And that is when the fun starts! What follows is one of the most amazing, action packed couple of hours of horror, blood and gore that audiences have been exposed to in the past couple of years. This film delivers where recent zombie exploits (28 Days Later, Undead, Resident Evil) have failed to. For a start, we see the 'disease' spread. The footage that depicts the spread of the mayhem is AMAZING - look out for the awesome aerial shots! And have I mentioned that these zombies are FAST and totally relentless, drawn to the living like bees to honey? They aren't incredibly smart, but what they lack in intelligence they make up for in determination, speed and their incredible ugliness (kudos to the make up team). Our heroine joins with other survivors, taking refuge at the local mall (all of those stores at their disposal - how sensible of them!) which was locked and somehow remained almost free of infection. One of the many highlights of this film is its ability to make the seamless switch from absolute horror to hilarious comedy, as our heroes make light of their situation; running amok in the mall (as you would!) and playing zombie celebrity shoot-out with the owner of a neighboring store. There are definite problems with the introduction of characters, as other survivors join our original five. It is hard to keep track of faces, let alone all of their names and relationships to each other. However, to the actors' credit, and because of the nature of the script, the audience feels for these people, no matter how shallow, or one-dimensional they are, because they have lost all that they know; family, friends, everything to this zombie plague.This film is sharp, fast-paced and well made (especially considering the director's previous credit is 'Scooby Doo'). The score and soundtrack are extremely cool, as are the opening and closing credits, and the film's ending is one of the most original I have seen in years. It is something that horror fans are going to want to see on the big screen; the explosive special effects and cool action scenes aren't going to come across as well on the small screen. Not everyone will love this film, it is bloody and relentless, but if action packed horror is your genre of choice (or if you have ever dreamed of having a mall at your disposal), I recommend Dawn of the Dead... Go, go see it now!

There is no need to talk about the many qualities of the original 1978 `Dawn Of The Dead' here. George A. Romero's movie has long since  been a movie classic, not only in the horror category. It is no surprise then, that in times of annoying remakes like `The Getaway' or the upcoming `Assault On Precinct 13', a certain feeling of scepticism is at hand when it comes to Zack Snyder's updated version of `Dawn Of The Dead'. Beside the fact that there is no need to redo a perfect movie, Snyder, as a director of commercials, didn't seem the best of choices to do the job. But maybe we were a bit prejudiced here. Snyder did a good job, he even did an outstanding job. Just as Romero's movie has many satiric elements and comments on the society of the 70's, his version perfectly mirrors today's fast paced society. A lot of action replaces atmosphere, comic relief replaces irony and unstoppable killing machines replace the old somnanbulists. But it all works out extremely well. With all the action, fast cutting and contemporary music, `Dawn Of The Dead 2004' really kicks ass. And it's owing to Snyder, that even the character development doesn't come short. Needless to say that this is not a character study like Romero's original, although Snyder manages to provide his panopticum of archetypes with enough twists and turns to develop sympathy. My advice is to watch this as independently of the original as possible. You will be rewarded with a roller coaster ride and maybe with one of the best genre movies the still young century has to offer.

Caught a sneak preview of this and the audience went wild at all the gore and action on display.  I haven't seen the original, so I can't compare, but overall this film is a pretty exciting rollercoaster ride with great special effects. The story could have been a little meatier, but then that's not what the audience really goes to this type of pic for. If you liked 28 Days, I think you'll get a kick out of Dawn of the Dead.

I'm at least a moderate fan of horror flicks, although not quite as avid as some of these zombie fanatics :)  Coming at this more from a neutral standpoint, I must say this movie has all the elements: suspense/drama, gore, character development, mostly superb acting, great cinematography... the movie kept me captivated throughout, and you actually sympathize with the protagonists.  Very fast paced, always keeps you on your toes and a few curve balls are thrown.  Perhaps the plot is lacking a bit, but really this is a superb movie.
Overall I'd give this movie an A-; see it in the movie theatres!

****Possible Spoilers**** I had the pleasure of driving past the Monroeville Mall just after watching the Re-Make of Dawn of the Dead...(which for diehards is where the first movie was filmed)...But anyways I would have to say I loved this movie, Sure the characters weren't as developed as the orginal but this one was more fast paced and too the point.  I liked the effect of having the more people inside that mall which lead to more people being picked off one by one. The gore was done right with just enough head shots and to say head impalings to go around.  The chainsaw on the bus was pretty cool idea too and to people that have seen know what happens with said chainsaw!!! The celebrity shooting game also made me laugh out loud. My only real problem is with the ending. Which is cool in it's own but could have been a bit more clearer, hey I'm a guy that likes closure so sue me. I just hope that this movie will inspire Romero to make a fourth film or for Zack to make another sequel. But overall I think people should just sit back and enjoy a great zombie movie with plenty splats and shocks..

Review title: Great modern day horror flick. The original 'Dawn' is of course better. But this one delivers a great plot like the original.
Review_body:
I saw this movie with my mother and my sister at 6:45 Eastern Time. I'm a die hard fan of Romero's 'Dead" Trilogy and am still very skeptical about this movie.  However,  it's one of the best horror films in years along with titles like 'Texas Chainsaw Massacre', 'The Ring', and for longtime fans of horror movies 'Freddy vs. Jason'.  I might add that 'Jason X' was one of the worst in years.  But it feels good that they're bringing back the classics and not ruining them as we've seen in years past.
The opening scene of the 2004 re-make of 'Dawn' is a great way to get your audience involved with a movie.  The gore, the athlete fast zombies, and some disturbing images are a good way to get this movie going.  The make-up was outstanding and the 'twitching' zombies were pretty cool. Seeing Ken Foree, Scott Reiniger, and Tom Savini in the movie were a thrill of its own.  However, they only had 20 seconds each in the film.  I believe they should have been involved a little bit more in the movie.
The acting overall was great.  Ving Rhames delivers a kick-ass performance.  More characters were in this movie to make it seen on many different point of views.  The gore is alright but the DVD should give us some guts getting teared out of a biker.  Oh, no only that graphic could be on the original 'Dawn'.  But this movie is great on a different level and is guaranteed to be worth seeing once, twice, or a few times.  I think it was better than 28 Days Later.  'Dead' fans already started running to the theater.  ** 3/4 out of 4.

You'll stop trying to save this movie. Stop trying to defend the producer. Horror fans stop trying to justify this as a must see movie. A child's imagination could put on a better zombie movie. The Mummy was a better movie. The mall scene, dumb. Malls are full of glass walls. All the zombies had to do was get his zombie arm and break the glass. A river of zombees, and the nurse escapes everything, impossible. As fast as those zombie moved, the nurse should have been bitten in the hospital.

Now I admit, when my friends wanted to see this movie, I really didnt want to go with them. This movie didnt really look that entertaining, and the zombie genre has been done before. But I had nothing else to do that day, so we bought tickets to Hidalgo and snuck into Dawn Of The Dead. Now, the movie takes place in Wisconsin, and actually mentions the city where I live, and I was completely shocked. I dont think you would realize how awesome it is to hear recognition for where you live when you dont get recognized that much. The movie, although sometimes unrealistic, is overall enjoyable. It has its funny moments, and moment where you question the actors choice. Example: Why the hell would you drive through a crowd of zombies to save a dog? Stupidity as its greatest. But in any case, the effects were good, and this is a good way to spend 2 hours, so I recommend going out and seeing this movie, and visit Waukesha sometime soon. We'll be waiting for you...

Review title: Nice Film, But Falls Still At Some Points
Review_body: I went into this film skeptical, judging from the content and quality of past "zombie movies", but this film surpassed my expectations at most times, but at times, it fell short of those same expectations. The film has a nice soundtrack and overall, the sounds period. The music leaves you wondering what's going to be at the next corner, but most of the time it is nothing, leaving you wondering when something WILL happen, and you never know when so it just jumps out at you.I had an epiphany tonight. I thought that all remakes of "B-flicks" had to have cheesy blood and skin effects. I was wrong here. The blood and gore is done near perfectly, the blood and wounds realistic and you feel how bad it would be if those events were taking place on you.There is no long "set-up" for it, but we jump right into an interesting story that doesn't have many stale points. At times, the story does get kind of lame like a "B-flick", which is slow and overdone, but that doesn't prevent this movie from giving you the zombie goodness that you want.One argument that I have with this film is that we never become enlightened on the origin of the zombies. It would of been nice if we could of at least known the reason the zombies were appearing. Maybe if they would of remade "Night Of the Living Dead" first that disappointment would not be in existence.Overall, a nice movie, but has its bad parts, like any film. The acting isn't stale and stiff, and the actors fit into the characters perfectly. I'd recommend this movie for any zombie-movie-junkie, but if you're easily queased, don't see this unless you expect to cover your eyes a lot of the time.John Hughes (with the assistance of Cory Darenzo)

First of all, I am a HUGE horror fan and I've been dying to see the new Dawn of the Dead. I hate to admit this, but I finally just saw it this weekend (5/22!!) You at least have to give me props for checking it out on the big screen, even if it was at the cheap-o movie theater. It was $3.75 well spent! Even though the movie was kind of scratchy because i guess it's made it's rounds, I was still pretty much into it. I'm a big fan of the original DOTD. I've owned it on video since high school and I've watched it a lot! So, I wanted to go into watching this remake with a clean slate. Even though I liked this remake, it did seem a lot like 28 Days Later, which I thought was better, but they are both still nothing crazily new or radical on the zombie genre [actually, I think 28 Days Later copied from the original DOTD]. I don't think I'm giving too much away here (plus, if you haven't seen it yet and you're a horror fan, you're worse than me!!), but this is a warning that I might mention a couple of the killings. Anyway, the girl in the beginning who starts out as a nurse is very cute, in a girl next door kind of way. I know I recognize her from something else, but I think she is older and hotter now. Although, her husband in the beginning looks like he could be her dad. Showering with her. Creepy. I wonder what the director Zach's deal is? His directing was really cool, though. I like the opening when the nurse has to escape her own house and then drives through all hell breaking lose in their suburb and the camera keeps backing up further away and you see a car crash into the gas station and it blows up. Once they get trapped in the mall, I think the acting is really good, but I liked all mall stuff in the original DOTD better. But the acting and directing do lift the movie. I liked getting to know the characters and the tension of whose a zombie or not [that fat lady was so totally a zombie  how could they not figure that one out faster?] And, I want to pay mad props to Mhiki Pfieffer for getting his name in a Enimen song and delivering a zombie baby all in the span of one year! I Won't say what happens at the end [the very end] but I liked it. It was cool and wasn't like your typical Hollywood ending per se. So, in a nutshell... Too much like 28 Days Later, and nothing earth shatteringly new or fresh, but still a pretty cool movie, with good acting and directing. I say, go see it!!

Before I saw this movie a number of people were recommending it as one of their favourite movies.After seeing it myself I cannot see how they could rate it so highly. To me it seemed like just another average horror/disaster movie. It was incredibly similar in plot to 28 Days Later, and provided nothing strikingly original. In my opinion 28 Days Later is better because of the early atmospheric scenes of deserted London, but both movies fall apart towards their ends.Dawn of the Dead does have one saving grace - a scene involving rooftops, celebrities, and a high powered rifle...

I have to say, though fairly new to the zombie genre, this has to be one of the worst zombie films I have ever seen. I do say that Tom Savini's work is one of his best, but still, flashy gory make up, and flashy explosions do not make up for the loss of plot, depth, character development or over all story in general. This movie breaks with the tradition of zombie characteristics (they can't run, they're dead for God's sake!). I rated this around a 4. This movie would not as bad if solely on it's own merit,however, the fact the director is piggy backing on George Romero's current Trilogy, with out the social messages, or overall script complexity really hurts its rating over all. To dispel accusations that I am anti-new zombie films, or that anyone but Romero can't do a zombie flick, just know this, if you really want to see a good zombie film, go see Sean of the dead. THat parody is twice as zombie-riffic as this.

I was looking forward to seeing this film. Missed it at the theaters and then I didn't get around to renting it until recently. Caught the first ten minutes of the movie when they showed it on TV- great promotional idea for this movie (bad promotional idea for Elektra though, but that's another film altogether ...)I personally didn't get the sense that this phenomenon was global, just that this was a small town gone bad. I do like the opening credit sequence with Cash's vocals and all- very cool! Loved the chaos that ensued at the beginning, loved CJ and the security mall a$$holes once they got inside. After that it become a bit muddled and boring. CJ's character becomes a likable guy for some reason which really sucked because he played such a great bad guy! THe film went from being ... well .. semi-serious to comedic from moment to moment. The Mikhi Pfier sequence didn't really have a good payoff for me. And the single worst part of the movie is when the red head girl risk her life and their rescue mission to save a damn dog!!! WTF? Just like when Rippley saved the cat in Alien, this is a terrible cliché that should not be brought back! Horrible, horrible. Of course, things pick up towards the end and it becomes fun to watch once again. But you know ... the stuff in the middle was just plain terrible. Sarah Polley was really great! So was Ving Rhames. I liked him but i'm not sure why, I guess I just like Ving and that's good enough for me. I enjoyed the zombies as well. Especially Polley's bf that guy just wouldn't stop! I won't compare to the source material, even though I am a Romero and zombie fan but all in all it just wasn't that great of a film. It's all pretty disappointing in the end.

Review title: The original one still is the best
Review_body: Not a particularly bad movie, no. There are good things about it. One example: the fast zombies. Special effects are newer than in George Romero's original, but not THAT newer, after all. And: gory sequences are not as scary as in the original movie. I believe the feelings of fear, claustrophobia, pain and horror are not as vivid as in the original movie. This movie is occasionally scary, but it just does not manage to reproduce fully the "magic" that Romero was so good at. One more thing: I did not like the pseudo-philosophical junk that "explained" the zombie plague: we are corrupt, we are evil, there are prostitution, homosexuality, drugs, abortion, blah blah blah... I can do without such "lectures", thanks.

Review title: Can't wait to see it again!
Review_body: To really like this type of movie, you need to be able to use your imagination, and ask yourself "what if...?"The intro, which plays for almost 10 minutes, is really intense. When the credits start after the intro, there is a song which fits the video clips during the credits really well. I like that song, it reminds me of something bad and evil...The casting is very good. I especially like the nurse, the "bad" guy with the black cap, and Andy, the rooftop shooter!What I don't like about the movie: the scene with the woman giving birth to a zombie-child. It's just too grotesque/bad-taste for my taste!

Review title: My top vote for "Best in Genre"
Review_body: I must confess that when beginning to view this film I expected more gratuitous bloodshed and slow-moving, emotionless zombies......Oh contraire, indeed! What sets "Dawn....2004" apart from ALL OTHER such films (including NOTD and the original DOTD) is just that.....the speed with which the condition leading to zombi-ism spreads and the "zeal" of the zombies is without precedent. Acting is 1st class and editing is phenomenal. One thing that sticks in my mind RE the plot is how the dorky lead Mall Security cop starts out as a frightened tool, and in the end turns out to be the top hero of the day, making possible the "escape into the sunset" of the remainder of the surviving party.......I particularly like that sort of character development......It puts the "value" in "redeeming social value" that we do so crave in films of this genre!In closing, this is not only a MUST SEE, it is a MUST HAVE IN YOUR DVD COLLECTION!

Review title: Well, what do I have to say? VERY good
Review_body: Well, I remember renting Dawn of the Dead last year on video after reading some enthusiastic reviews and hearing about other zombie flicks. Well, I borrowed it... and I was blown away. Just like when I borrowed Braindead a few months earlier.Dawn of the Dead is a very good zombie film. The plot is almost identical to the original (which I am currently trying to watch), and it makes for very good viewing. Even more amazing about the film is the fact that it is a DIRECTORIAL DEBUT. How about that?!Well, if you haven't seen it, here is the plot: Something - a virus, possibly; it is never explained - is causing the dead to rise. Not just in a small area, but worldwide. Spreading like wildfire, anybody bitten by one of these things will transform anywhere from a few minutes to a few days later. And these things need to feast on the flesh of the living. A group of survivors, including a nurse, a cop and a pregnant woman (and a guy that sells TV's at Best Buy) take refuge in a massive shopping centre.Well, that's all I am revealing for now.The opening sequence - which is one of the most breathtaking I have ever seen - is slightly more edgy than the rest of the film. But just slightly. Ever so slightly.Some classic moments - the "flying" zombie, for instance - are just ingenious. Again, I am not spoiling it.You want a good way to pass a lonely Saturday night? Then watch this. You WILL not regret it.-9/10-

Wow! What can I say about this? This is by far probably THE BEST zombie movie I have ever seen!!! The zombie make-up effects are just stunning; so gory, realistic...and the techniques they showed in the Director's Cut were fantastic!!!! Seeing this movie on the day it premiered was great. The whole theater was packed and everyone loved it!!! This movie has some really great scenes/lines. One of my favorite lines would have to be Kenneth going "If I put my foot up your ass, will that be your problem?". I really enjoyed that although this was a horror movie, there were some comedic elements incorporated within. The actors were just stunning in this. The actors who played the zombies were excellent. I don't even remember the last time I was so scared from watching a movie before going to see this in the theater. The original 1978 version was great as well. Both George Romero and Zack Snyder are phenomenal directors. Another thing I really enjoyed about this film was that the zombies were fast-moving, as opposed to the traditional slow-moving zombies. I really believe Zack Snyder really did the original justice with this remake.

Review title: It works!!! My god, it works!!!
Review_body: I, too, was surprised about enjoying this movie. I expected a gore fest with nothing else, but was in for a pleasant surprise. The big thing was trying to figure out who lives and dies, which always makes for fun. Also, the humor but crisp and fun. After a barrage of killing zombies, our "humans" are stuck in an elevator playing, you guessed it, "elevator music." The character of CJ breaks us up by saying "I like this song." Funny stuff. Sarah Polley was OK, at best. Ving Rhames was great, as was CJ, whoever he is. The ending credits sort of ruined some of it, but not completely. I think it would have been best left out. For a person who does not like horror movies, I recommend this one.

Review title: Watch this if you want the best of the best
Review_body: Its a lot of zombie-movies out there. A lot of them are good and some of them are poorly made. This one isn't in the same category. Its to good. All the friends I have shown this for.. Not all of them even like zombies. They all love it.It's good actors, good environment, good shooting.. And a very good story. Other films like shawn of the dead, land of the dead, day of the dead are close but they are a bit messy. This one keeps the red line all through the movie.I would like a number 2 of this movie. Like what happened after all of this.
This is simply the best zombie movie ever i think Zack Snyder did one hell of a good job!! And the muzack is outstanding!!🎶🎵

When I first heard "they" were redoing "Dawn of the Dead," my heart sank. How could anyone recreate the magic and thrill of the 1978 classic? Well, they didn't ... but the movie was entertaining enough that I have now watched it thrice.The opener really sucks you in. It's creepy, visceral, and glues you to your seat. It's so good, in fact, that those first 5 minutes provide enough juice to carry you through the rest of the movie, no matter how bad the rest might be. Fortunately, the next hour and a half is pretty interesting, too.The directing and photography really help the film; it creates a cold, wet, slippery atmosphere well-suited to the zombie sub-genre. Normally the shaky, documentary-style camera work would be inappropriate for a zombie flick (I find it irritating in almost any movie), but this one is different from other zombie movies in ways that make the technique tolerable.As scary and fun as "Dawn of the Dead" is, it lacks something. Maybe there was too much heavy metal in the soundtrack, or maybe the characters did one too many unbelievable things. But I've never just sat back and said "whoa," or had much to say to my friends about the movie. Like cotton candy, it's tasty and you'll probably want it again, but it leaves a funny, unpleasant aftertaste.The new "Dawn of the Dead" stands head and shoulders above most Horror films that come out these days. But it hardly clears the original's waistline.

Review title: Very well done, but one problem............
Review_body: Zombies can't run. It took the scariness out of the whole movie. The movie, overall was excellent, but the running zombies distracted me from the real scary parts.I believe that George A Romero (pretty much creator of the zombie genre) would agree with me, the running zombies were a put-down. The reason zombies can't run is because their brain reacts too slowly. Yes, they may be able to run, I mean with healthy joints and muscles, but they don't because it's just something they don't do.The redeeming qualities of this movie were:(spoilers!!! be warned!!!) Great cinematic value. The zombie baby (which I predicted in the first 20 min. of the movie). The ending. The ending was very well done. I loved it. I liked how James Gunn, the writer, had the surviving characters go on a boat (which is mentioned in the original movie, the part with the cops, you know the one) and then the characters get killed. Perfect for this movie.Oh, almost forgot, the whole underlying concept of the original movie was forgotten. Yeah, the story is pretty much the same, but they forgot the moral to the story. If you have ever seen the original, you know what I mean.

Dawn of the Dead isn't really a film I'd usually be interested in (I'm 13..hello!!) but I was bored, switched on the TV, flicked through the cable movie channels, and there it was.. 'DAWN OF THE DEAD' So I thought 'what the hell? I have nothing better to do anyway'.. The best part of the movie is definitely the opening where Ana's lover awakes to see the silhouette of the 'undead' Vivian in the doorway, and as she walks closer you can see her ripped and bloodied flesh..that was just creepy..however, the moment was kind of ruined when she started feasting on his neck..not so creepy anymore! Just silly! They should have left more to the imagination..In general, the movie was quite clever, but a bit too serious. My advice? See the spoof 'Shaun of the Dead' instead! Way better!

Review title: An incredibly average zombie film with the same name as a classic
Review_body: It is impossible to evaluate the success of this movie without comparing it to the original. The fantasy element of living in the mall which drove the classic film, of having all the creature comforts of civilization amid the apocalypse, is missing entirely. The social commentary of the original, that consumerism has become so instinctive that even zombies would gravitate towards the mall, is missing entirely. This isn't "Dawn of the Dead"; this is just a movie that has a mall in it. Also absent are any compelling characters. While the original focused on no more than four survivors, the number is more than tripled in the remake to diminished effect. There are no nuanced portrayals here; the cast never transcends flat character descriptions like "the tough nurse", "the pregnant woman", or "the jerk security guard". As we see them dispatched with the indifference we might reserve for reality show contestants, none of these characters make much of an impression. Original film actor Ken Foret has a brief cameo as a fundamentalist preacher, and in his less than two minutes of screen time he provides a more powerful performance than any of the main cast.The fast zombies are more comedic than scary. Whether they're sprinting after cars like cartoon dogs, bashing their heads through doors, or squealing like pigs as they are picked off by gunfire, the undead never seem to present a credible threat. For all its enhanced budget and updated special effects, this "Dawn of the Dead" does not offer anything that cannot be found in the previous four decades of zombie horror. Once again we have to sit through the usual bickering between survivors over who will lead, the standard "bit by a zombie and waiting to turn" play for our sympathies, the predictable ill- advised trip to the basement. All this and more has been done before, and executed more effectively.Zack Snyder has always been an amazing visualist, and this is one way in which the film redeems itself. The full scope of a neighborhood descending into chaos is revealed through a camera mounted on an escaping vehicle. Two characters saying a tearful goodbye is broken into multiple cuts from several perspectives, distorting time and drawing us into the moment. The daylight scenes appear overexposed, amplifying the idea that this catastrophe is happening in our real world. Sadly, no amount of skillful cinematography can help this mashup of worn out horror movie banalities.

Review title: Better Then I Initially Thought (Possible Spoilers)!
Review_body: When I first saw this movie, I thought it was enjoyable and entertaining, but that it only existed on a superficial level. I believed the sole purpose of this film was to provide an action-packed reformation of the original Dawn of the Dead. Being that I had been a fan of Romero's a year prior to the release of this film, I had the notion that remaking Romero's vision would be hard, if not impossible. Although nothing will equate to the original Dawn of the Dead, this film is not that bad at all. It's just an alternate outlook on a classic zombie film.Zack Snyder's envisioning of such a classic concept prevails. The visuals of this film are stunning. Snyder knew the vision he was trying to create and it simply worked. The film closely follows the theologies of the end times and the Rapture; it achieves a sort of apocalyptical vision. Except instead of Satan, the Anti-Christ and demons... you have zombies. Everyone is trying to protect themselves and their homestead, some with brute force, and they are just trying to cope with this sort of "Hell on Earth." This film really does excel visually and retains a sort of nightmarish quality to it. And one aspect of the film I particularly like is the transformation and the stages of the zombies. In the bonus features to this film, Zack Snyder tells us that he created different stages and levels of the "zombie infection." I found this idea to be very creative and unique.Good film: 7/10.

I liked this movie because it contained running zombies. I have seen a lot of "scary" movies that only had walking zombies, and those are boring. With walking zombies how hard is it to just run from them? But with running zombies you know you're not going to be able to get away without putting up a good fight. The makeup for the zombie's was good also. It made it seem real. None of the two dollar movie make up most "scary" movies use. The acting was a little off in some parts, mostly in the beginning. The ending was pretty good cliffhanger, also. This movie, in the end, does have it's faults, but it does keep you on the edge of your seat waiting for more.

Review title: So frightening I couldn't sleep for days
Review_body: From the total-apocalypse-with-accompanying-Johnny-Cash-end-of-the-world-theme-tune grand opening, to the very last few sickening seconds, I was spellbound by dread by this film like no other I've experienced in the last decade.This film pulls no punches. This is the end of the f****n' world here people, and unlike the original Romero flick this one leaves you with no reassurances. You can't outrun these zombies, you can't hide and eventually they will get you and they will kill you. And then you will become one of them. Zack Snyder has done an incredible job here, and made a horror film truly worthy of the Dawn of the Dead name. Managing to incorporate true scares, action and even humor, he's created a horror classic. And this isn't just the 'cat jumping out of the dark closet' type cheap shock tactics. This is the creeping sick you'll feel for days, even months later, the uneasy feeling that only true horror gives you. Not since the original Exorcist movie has a horror film so affected me. This film creates a frighteningly real zombie holocaust, one that won't leave you in a hurry. You've been warned!

The director's cut of this movie is one of the best horror films ever made. I am a true fan of the original (I own both Night of the Living Dead and the special edition Dawn of the Dead) but for pure entertainment, I feel this one is better than either of them. It is both graphic and funny and gives the horror fan everything they can want. Be warned-the theater version is choppy in parts and leaves the viewer scratching their heads on how some sequences came to be. Stay with the DVD unrated version and if (and only if) you are a horror fan who can appreciate (tolerate?) gore, you will have a great time with this film.

This movie was total nonsense, at no point is the viewer informed as to WHY the zombies are running around nibbling people to death, I'd never class this as a "horror" movie, more of a blood and guts movie at best, I wouldn't recommend this movie to anybody and in fact I have warned people about how pathetic and boring it truly is. The only positive things in the movie are two scenes, first and foremost the credits are a joy to watch, and secondly the scene where the girl is thrown into the bath tub, VERY realistic I thought. It's very sad in today's world that the only way a movie can be interesting is if it contains high amounts of blood and violence, I would much prefer to watch a movie that messes with my head and has a seemingly plausible plot, this movie does not fit that criteria.

This is why I give DoTD a 10. The storyline, plot, acting, action, even the atmosphere. I actually laughed my a** off at several points. This movie is definitely one for the hall of fame. Just because it's a Romero movie gives it 2 points instantly. If you haven't watched it or didn't like it, then how do you know what they'll be like. Dawn of the dead is an immediate hit & will be seen as a cult classic for a fair while. My Rating = 10/10 My reasons = acting, direction, writing, plot, action. My verdict = Rent it out & watch it till you know the mall off by heart. Dawn of the dead is an instant comedy hit but not one to let the kids sit and watch.

This is an absolutely amazing movie! I can't really think of any other way to state it. Zack Snyder has done an absolutely amazing job, and for his first movie, it's really not bad at all...The action alone is amazing, but in the unrated director's cut, the look we get at the characters up close and personal really adds a lot to the storyline. Even if you're not a fan of horror movies, this is definitely a must-see, because when you look past the "blood and guts", all you see is an amazing piece of work.This film comes highly recommended... not only for excellent acting and casting, but also directing and presentation of an awesome story.

I rented this movie.. and on the cover..it was like exclusive director cut,very violent...blah blah blah...but it was not scary or even entertaining...it was a boring movie(like Titanic..people are trapped and have to get out).If you knew you're father just got shot..(you know the whole "Turning in to a Zombie thing").Why would you leave a safe place..and crash a truck in the hardcore center of 2000 zombies to get a dog??And why did not any one check one the pregnant couple??And that fat woman,who is "dying" starting to turn urine yellow??I don't know... but maybe she could become a zombie!!The people in this movie are as dumb as Paris Hilton...i don't like the characters..and i don't like the movie...

Review title: some just might like it better than the original . . .
Review_body: I've really been looking forward to giving this a chance since i heard about it some time last year, and I've got to say that this really wasn't the movie I expected.  It was WAY better!  Zach Snyder has put a fresh spin on an old idea.  It's really impossible not to compare this with its 26 year old predacessor, but that not what I was really interested in.  This is a rethinking of the story.  New characters.  New locations.  New zombies even. In case you haven't heard the zombies run at full speed now.  While I will admit that I wasn't too thrilled to hear that they were messing with a perfect formula, it does work perfectly for THIS movie.  Lets face it, zombies of the old days aren't very scary in this day and age and especially not from a director that had previously only worked on music videos with fast cuts and quicker pacing.  I'm not knocking the guy, its just that with the pacing of this style of movie, I think the fast zombies work much better.  This movie doesn't let up for one moment.The tension never lets up in this film.  Not only was I leaning forward waiting in anticipation for the next scare, but I was also very interested in the survivors.  All the characters were drawn out very well, and you really become interested in what will become of them.  There are plenty of nice situations that arise that are very subtle homages to Romero's classic as well as some of his other films as well.  Without ruining anything, I will say that there are at least 2 character types from each of the original classics.  Long time fans won't be disappointed with the story.The effects were great.  From what I have heard, there were some CG enhanced scenes, but I don't really think anyone noticed.  It seemed that they were using rubber and fake blood for most of it, but some of the gorier scenes had me wondering how they would have done it.  All the effects were very well done.  A movie like this MUST have outstanding effects to stand out. It reminds me of the over the top effects that were prevelent throughout the 80's horror movies, with each new one trying to top the last by killing someone in a creative way.  There were at least a dozen times where you could here the whole audience simultaneously cheer and gasp over a creative scene of gore.Overall, this was a great movie for horror fans and action fans alike.  It won't win an Oscar or anything, but thats not what this kind of movie sets out to do.  You should be going to the theatre to be entertained, and that's exactly what i paid 8 dollars twice to go do.  I always seem to be critical on remakes of classics, but this one is different enough to look at it as a seperate movie all together.  These kinds of movies don't show up very often, and its nice to see one get released with a nice sized budget and get a wide release.  All you purists out there don't worry about this being a crappy remake.  Once the studios see that this knocked "The Passion of The Christ" out of the number one spot on its opening week, there will be a whole slew of crappy zombie movies out there to target your rants at.  Enjoy it for what it is and don't trust scuzzy mall security guards!  :D *****

Usually I hate all things remake, but this may be the one exception. It's not the best movie, not even the best zombie movie, but it is pretty good. Compared to the original movie, the remake is, let's say, cooler, not better. The film gets you into the action right away and to be blunt, it is intense. Heads splatter, zombies rise, and babies are born in one of the most bizarre scenes I've ever witnessed in a film. The script is well written for the most part, all up to the end that is. I don't care how cool of a dog that was, if that was me, Chips would be zombie chow. It's a fun remake that replaces the great characters of the original movie with great action.

Nice movie may have opted for couple more stars had zombies not been made into track stars. You're the walking dead you shouldn't have world class speed. They're already dealing with overwhelming numbers why make them all Usain Bolt.

Review title: Not a terrible film, but different.
Review_body: I've been a George A. Romero fan for years now. When I first heard Zack Snyder was remaking Dawn of the Dead back in 2004, I was skeptical but excited. His film disappointed me a bit, but only because I was holding it to the standard George Romero created with his 1978 film. The main thing to remember is: Zack Snyder and George Romero are two different people, and the 1978 and 2004 versions of Dawn of the Dead are two different films.Basically the premise is the same. In fleeing from the zombie-creating plague, a group of people takes refuge in a shopping center.For me, personally, the worst thing about the entire film was the character development -- or lack thereof. In Romero's version, there were four main characters: Peter, Fran, Stephen, and Roger. With a low amount of characters, it's easy for a viewer to relate to them, to learn along with them. In Snyder's version, there are over a dozen: Ana, Michael, Kenneth, Andre, Luda, CJ, Terry, Bart, Norma, Tucker, Frank, Nicole, Monica, Steve, Glen, and Andy. With such a large number of characters, it becomes more difficult for the filmmaker to give any of them significant depth. No one in the movie has any sort of revealed "past", except for Ana's, whose past is limited to the first 20 minutes of the film, and Michael, whose past is limited to the few statements he makes in one scene about being a great father and terrible husband. For all it's worth, the greatest showing of any kind of human bonding was between Kenneth and the owner of the gun store across the street, Andy. The director's cut includes a bonus feature which details Andy's last few days -- This lent a comparatively large amount of depth to his character -- But only when compared to the small amount of development the others received.The film DID hold something for fans of zombie flicks -- The zombies. They look better now, owing to the differences in special effects between 1978 and 2004. None of the zombies holds any real significance, however, except for Luda when she turns. Romero's zombies were always more pitied, more sad -- Stuck in that miserable existence. They were still only "motorized instinct", but they seemed to have more depth. Maybe it's just me, but depth means a lot to me in a movie, and especially a remake of one of my favorites.Snyder's Dawn is worth watching for fans of zombie films, but don't expect George Romero, because that's not what you get with Snyder.

Review title: More action, hopelessness, and apocalyptic scenes!
Review_body: They so need a sequel but this time keep it fast paced. the only problem with dawn of the dead was the scenes i wanted to last were over too quickly. They should have shown more world chaos like NY engulfed in zombies and more scenes of people being attacked in her town. For a sequel the beginning apocalypse should last a good 20 mins as we are given groups of characters we think will live but after the initial zombie breakout it is whiddled down to the movies main characters. Also more scenes of hopelessness the zombies is scary because he is relentless...exploit that.Finally don't slow it down in the middle keep the escape going through the whole movie moving from safe spot to safe spot. the ending did this well but again it was only for a few minutes. I have the first one on DVD and heres to hoping I get to purchase the sequel one day. All in all the best zombie flick I have seen.

The original ranks as one of my all-time favorite horror movies. I did enjoy many of the new characters and plot twists. The acting was far superior to the original. Here's my beef: Every now and then, the characters would engage in some utterly absurd action that was clearly contrived to throw suspense into the story. For example, when Michael investigates the noise in the sporting goods store ALONE, without telling anyone else where he's going (and Michael's the smart one!) For me, this just shatters the suspension of disbelief and reminds me that I'm watching a movie -- a movie that isn't even crafted well enough to hide the seams in its plot.I found the entire subplot with Mekhi Phifer's character incredulous. His completely irrational choices are explained away when he suddenly appears to have gone insane. Unfortunately, nothing in the story sets up the mental collapse of this otherwise cool and collected character. His brief conversation with Ving Rhames does nothing to foreshadow a descent into madness. His desire to bring his child into the world and give it a better life than his own hardly sound like the ravings of a lunatic.Oh, and the girl who goes chasing after the dog!!! Oh, puh-leeze!!! I also disliked the epilogue. Why, oh why, would you dock your boat in a potentially hostile shore? Nobody thought to scout the shoreline first? Or drop anchor in the harbor, then take a dinghy to check out the coast? The bleakness of the ending felt fashionably, smugly pessimistic and hateful toward characters I had grown to care for. I do prefer the ending of the original, which is ambiguous but does at least leave room for hope.

Review title: It's a shame to have George Romero's name associated with this version at all!
Review_body: The story had so many holes; questions, missing pieces and throw in an out-of-character moment that ... (I can't say. You have to see it for yourself). The actors tried. You watch to see who is going to live and who was going to die, but when it's over you realize you didn't care. It's difficult to make a remake, but in this case I wouldn't had said anything if the director cheated a little and took some ideas from Romero. "28 days later" took the thunder out of these zombies and that movie, even though the director denied it, was somewhat of a combination of Romeros' dead movies (watch "28" for comparison; it's not 10 times better, just better). The producers threw the equipment and experienced people to surround the new director, but it was a Freshmans' attempt. I had to come home and watch the real "Dawn of the Dead" to get this remake (rehash) out of my system.

I saw the original movie in my childhood (14 or so) and at that time it made me feel very creepy, I was afraid to go to sleep fir two nights... I saw more zombie movies during that period, but none of them was as good though.Now I am a grown up, and just saw the 2004 version. It's just as great as 28 years ago, and I have the same creepy feeling again. Not many horror movies can do that to me these days! Luckily the 2004 version has not only improved it's special effects. Also the zombies do not walk anymore like play-mobil puppets, but they actually run. But what I still do not understand is why they do not eat each other...If you want to get scared, go see this movie!

As someone who isn't a big horror movie fan, i will admit i wasn't best pleased when my friend put this on during a film night. I normally find zombie movies in general pretty pointless, but..I will admit i loved this movie. The beginning was oddly chilling, supposed to be 'normal day', but it caused a chill in my spine.The characters were believable and i empathised well with them.If it had just been pure horror the whole way through, i might not have liked it so much, but there were comic moments that broke the tension a bit for me.All in all, 9 out of ten.

Review title: If your going to remake a classic - Heres a fine example of how it should be done
Review_body: Being a fan of the original i went to the cinema to see this expecting the usual dull inferior Hollywood remake and was more than surprised to find a hugely enjoyable re-envisioning of George Romeros classicZack Snyder (director) and James Gunn(writer) have done the impossible and created a , dare i say it, SUPERIOR version of Dawn .....This time round the film has a much more pacey feel to it and is filled with some truly engaging and memorable characters - CJ the security guard springing straight to mindFor the gore fans there is bucketloads of it sloshed around the screen and some genuine "jump out of your seat" moments to cause even the strongest of hearts to beat a little faster!The script has been changed enough from the original to give it a fresh new feel whilst still sticking to the originals core elements, and feels much more satisfying all roundAll in all a very good debut from the first time directorIf you like Zombie films - this is a must!!8/10

This remake was better than I expected. The only major complaint I have is that there is a little too much comic relief, but otherwise this is a fine addition to the "Dead" world. I hope that it makes mega bucks, so that hopefully George Romero can get the financial backing to make a top-notch fourth and final film in his original series. The special effects and zombies are well done, the quality of acting is far above any found in most zombie films, and it is not overly gory. It will be interesting to see what deleted scenes will be added back in the DVD version of the film. Some purist fans of the original Romero version will probably be full of complaints about this movie, but I say to them ,the original version was not a perfect film by any means either, so give this one a chance, I think it will grow on you.

Review title: The Best Zombie Movie I Have Ever Watched
Review_body: I am a fan of zombie movies to begin with, as I find myself engrossed in the very concept itself. While the original was great, this is the kind of remake that shines so brightly with skill and performance at all levels. Improved in this movie are the cinematography, editing, acting, and storyline.Unlike too many (but not all) other zombie flicks, the zombies in this film are relatively agile, and thus pose a believable threat to those who remain un-undead. No brisk walking speed will keep you away from these infected creeps. This aspect alone is a great welcome to the zombie genre, though this film is not the first to implement this feature. This is the first zombie flick I have seen that incorporates a high quality storyline, and attention to detail. Not missed are the plot points that merely occur to fill film space, as events unfold with good cause, and not that "it just happened" rubbish that inflicts poorly created film art. Also of great skill are the technical aspects, giving great special effects, superb editing, and a director that kept his eye on the details.If you're not a fan of zombie movies for any reason other than an aversion to gore, then this is a great film for your zombie cherry to be broken. If you are a fan of zombie movies, I would fail to see any reason this film would do anything short of astonish and terrify you.

I watched this one on a press preview and thought it was quite good. Though fun is a more appropriate word than good cause surely this is no oscar material. I can't remember anything of the original so I wasn't bothered with comparison all of the time.What I liked best is the fact that it didn't give any stupid explanations for the virus. It's just a nice mix of action, gore and comedy and it has no customary beginning or ending. Works perfect for watching with friends cuz there's no real plot to follow.Fans of Romero might be offended by this, but like I said, I don't remember the original so I wouldn't know.
