I am a rabid fan of Zombie movies and I was waiting for the day a decent Zombie movie would come out that would be comparable to 28 Days Later. The remake of the original Dawn Of The Dead was done splendidly and is very scary. Scenes range from a quiet and calm morning turned chaotic to a dark and forlorn parking garage scene that chills to the bone.The whole movie is an atmosphere of despair and the characters struggle to overcome the fact that life as they know it has ended. There are nay-sayers who state that the movie slows down and is boring in some instances and there may be some weight to that argument but during these times there are essential character developments that take place.New technology allows the zombie scene's to take shape in a graphic and visceral form and the cinematography makes the movie move coherently and solidly. This movie is indeed very addictive and I do own it on DVD. When I watch this movie I can't help but think, what would I do if I was placed in there situation and would I be one of the one's who would journey to the island in hopes of somewhat of a life.All in all zombie-movie fans finally have a new generation movie that uses all the elements of the original version and employs new methods that combined provide a very scary and awesome movie. I was so impressed with the way the plot was storyboarded and in my opinion there were no boring moments in this movie at all.

Review title: How would you enjoy waking up in hell?
Review_body: After having seen plenty of movies with this basic concept in which people hide in a mall for mutated creatures, I can say this was a good watch. Though I have seen better movies about strange mutants and dangerous viruses this one was certainly worth my time. I have seen this movie recently but have watched and enjoyed alike movies before. Films such as the Resident Evil series can easily be compared to Dawn of the Dead.The movie and actors themselves manage to express the human emotions and thoughts at the brink of destruction very well. "Who to trust and who not" is an essential thought. Leaving your loved ones for the sake of your own life. It's all about certain decisions we have to make. However there is a lot of pain and misery, you will for sure not miss the several funny scenes spread over the movie.One point of critic I have to make is the sometimes what awkward scenes that come out of nowhere. For instance, I did expect certain elements as nudity to stay away. Also did I not enjoy the movie as a horror movie at all, it had way more thrill than horror.So if you have a night free and want to enjoy a good movie? Dawn of the Dead will be at your service.

Review title: Why I gave Dawn a 10 (well, maybe it should have been a9).
Review_body: I've been to thousands of movies in my lifetime and own hundreds of videos and DVDs, so I am a fan but not a bona fide film critic.  This is my first online review.My wife and I saw the original Dawn of the Dead 25 years ago at a midnight show and left wired enough to talk each other down till the morning. Perhaps a quarter of a century has inured us to the violence a bit since we just watched it again (rental video) last week prior to yesterday's venture to the local multiplex to see the remake/"reimagining" and were mostly unperturbed by the revisit.For some reason, I was hooked on the new Dawn months ago from the teaser and, subsequently, the actual trailer.  The Sparklehorse song in the former fit perfectly and the suburban shot followed by killer Vivian and closing with the burned projector film of the latter was intriguing in its own way. So I was primed to see the movie, usually a recipe for disaster since preview expectations are rarely fulfilled by the finished product.  This time, however, they were.The cast was uniformly believable and, more important, empathizable (at least with the good guys who got sorted out along the way).  Even the playboy jerk had several relevant lines.  Polley was a good, strong female lead (with another great rebuttal -- "No, I'm a * nurse" to a query about her medical skills) and Rhames a cheerable, if reluctant, hero.  The camaraderie, such as it was, worked, and visceral me-first survival gave way more often to self-sacrifice.So, what's not to like?  The fundamental premise that a classic got remade? Doesn't wash.  These are two different movies with the same name and similar premises but very different attitudes.  (Better special effects didn't hurt, either, although this new version was oddly less disturbing sans zombies munching on dismembered body parts.)  Speedy zombies (except for the "twitchers")?  No problem; hey, they're hungry and, as always, persistent. My attention was held for the better part of two hours; the story was interesting; the outcome ambivalent; the characters arisen to the task at hand, becoming coldly rational to the divisions between life and death and zombiedom; the music weirdly appropriate; the black humor welcome respite. No, Dawn of the Dead isn't Citizen Kane nor is it a sacrilegious assault on the horror genre.  It's solid filmmaking that's entertaining and thought-provoking.  Otherwise, I suspect Romero would never have put his imprimatur on the remake.

Anyone who has seen any zombie flicks will agree with me when I say that this is the best zombie movie period. And only for one specific reason. The zombies are VIOLENT!!! They run and scream at you with a bloody horrific quality. If you are looking for the zombies that walk at you and moan like they are having intercourse, this is not the movie for you! This movie also starts off with action right out of the gate. The only other movies to challenge Dawn of the Dead is 28 Days later or 28 Weeks Later.Dawn of the Dead is the only zombie movie that I can watch a hundred times over. This is the best zombie flick period!!!

Review title: When there's no more room in Hell, the dead shall walk the Earth
Review_body: I have just watched this movie this afternoon, and I must say, I came out of the cinema feeling drained of all energy.  What an EXCELLENT thrill-ride of a movie this is.  It seems that 28 Days Later had more of an influence on this film than the original did.  It looks to have been shot on Digital Cameras too; the picture had that same look about it.At first, I was disappointed that the Zombies were not the usual slow moving lumps of dead flesh that I knew and loved......that quality alone seemed to make them even more menacing in the Romero classics (of which I am a MASSIVE fan, by the way).  It didn't take long, tho, to accept the new look Zombies......again, probably helped by the effectiveness of the assailants in 28 Days Later (as they were obviously not Zombies in that film).......and this only added to the whole 'edge of the seat' action/horror of the movie. And as for 'jumping out of your skin' !!!   There are a few moments where I physically left my seat, I jumped so hard.The special effects are obviously a little more advanced than in the original....not to take any credit away from Tom Savini, who worked wonders in the original.....and some head shooting and chainsaw scenes were some of the most bloodthirsty I have seen in a long while.There are some really funny moments in this movie too.  Look out for the 'Celebrity Zombie' shoot-out  in particular....and also the fantastic parody of the 'chainsaw, blood-spurting in face scene' lifted from The Evil Dead 2. The guy that plays this scene has more than a passing resemblance to Mr Bruce Campbell.  I did get a little worried about the developing pregnancy sub-plot......was half expecting something not unlike the film 'It's Alive' about the killer baby.  Luckily, it wasn't too bad.  Fans of the Zombie genre may also spot the obvious references to the Lucio Fulchi movie "Zombi 2" or "Zombie Flesheaters", as I think it was called in the US.....tho wait for the closing credits.....whatever you do, DO NOT leave until the film absolutely ends !Also look out for cameos from at least two of the Stars from the original film;  Tom Savini as a straight talking Cop, eager to dispatch the Zombies as efficiently as possible.....and Ken Foree, who utters the infamous phrase that was the Tagline to the original.......' When there's no more room in Hell......the Dead shall walk the Earth '9/10

I just saw this movie tonight, and in my opinion, is the best horror movie I have seen in 10 years. The acting from all involved seemed appropriate. The timing in the movie was excellent. It started out with some tense moments in a hospital then moved straight to a pretty intense, fast moving introduction until they got to the mall. Then the action kept up almost to the point where I would have been ready for it to stop, but then it started focusing more on the interactions of a very diverse crowd in a very stressful situation. This went on long enough until I was ready to be scared again, and they pulled it off. Admittedly you have to let yourself be scared by this movie, but if you are like me, you watch these movies just hoping that there will be more than one time that you at least jump a little, and they pulled that off for me. There was also some nice humor scattered throughout, some truly disturbing moments, just an experience overall. Anyway, this might not be as good as the original (I finally found a place to rent it, will watch that this week), but considering that they did not rely soley on special effects and gore to scare you (in fact, they didnt try at all, there was good use of moments where you expect something but you just arent entirely sure what). I'd say this is the best attempt at a horror movie since the 70's. Somebody here really had a grasp at what horror is really about and I'm glad.

Review title: a terrific zombie film and great to watch.
Review_body: A great film to watch and is terrific because of the combination of action and suspense like at the start of the film for example when Anna's boyfriend luis turns into a zombie and suddenly attacks her, then it turns into tension when she's in the bathroom, but she luis outside of the door, and the music is good witch builds up the tension and suspense, then luis suddenly smashes through the door and tries to get her, overall a great film to watch because of the action and suspense.This combination also works at the start with the girl zombie and later on at the mall when Michael hears a zombie in the janitor's cupboard and slowly walks to the door,opens it and then find a zombie eating the janitors guts, classic.

This movie was almost as good as the first one which is a complement since the first film is a classic.  There are many movie remakes these days which try to show an updated version and usually ends up being very "cheesey".  While there are a few things I would have not done with this film it is VERY entertaining.  While the main idea of the movie is here and has many parallels to the original there are many differences as well.Some of the similarities are the zombies of course, once you get bitten you turn into one.  Shoot them in the head and they die.  The few survivors take refuge in a mall.The differences are the speed of the zombies.  The origional had them walk slowly towards you which, in my opinion, makes it more suspenseful and makes the zombies look more ... well dead I guess you can say.  The fast moving zombies in this version is exciting as well but just gives it a very different feel.  More of an adrenaline rush then a scared feeling.  There is no biker gang in this one which was a really nice touch in the first.  And in this movie seemed more of a stand-alone film while the original was obviously a sequel where everyone knew about the zombies from the beginning, again in my opinion was a little better since we already know what the zombie problem is about.Some of the things I found to be kind of stupid in this movie (and there are only a few) is when ***SPOILER ALERT*** Nicole (the young girl in the movie) went out in a truck to save the dog.  And she actually made it. Give me a break...  If it was that easy to get food to the guy in the other building they should have done so earlier... Another thing is the way they hooked up the trucks... reminded me too much of the old show the A-Team... and why did they put bobwire on the tops of the trucks... they are zombies who do not feel pain.  Why put them on there. Also there were many zombies in the parking garage where the trucks were? And lastly... I wish we got to know the characters better... they all seemed a little flat.... and they should have shown Mekhi's character going a little nuts to explain better why he acted the way he did.....  other then these few things I thought this move was perfect...Hopefully this helps some.  I think everyone who loves horror, action and black humor would enjoy this film.  Hopefully this movie will pave the way for more zombie movies and may have George Romero make a fourth installment to his living dead movies.

Quite simply one of my favourite films of all time.I loved the nightmarish quality of the original 1978 sequel. This is different with far more action, faster pace, bigger budget and lets face it, far better acting. The opening sequence is so well done and utterly shocking. The title sequence is inspired and has spawned many copies since. The quality of the casting, sets and makeup could not be bettered.If you haven't seen it, you must! I would have loved a remake of the Day of the Dead to this level of quality.I saw this twice at the cinema and many times since on DVD.

I can't remember the last time my heart pounded so long after leaving a cinema! Great performances, well done characters! And for the first time in ages, a perfectly timed movie length-wise!! [not too long, not too short]And how much scarier are zombies when they run at full pace?Dare I say it.... Better than the original?Alright if I was gonna nitpick anything - it would be why couldn't the many thousands of zombies break the mall windows? But I hate nitpickers so I won't let that get in the way of my rating.OK before the purists eat my brains let me put it this way.Not as clever as the original but definitely more entertaining.*****

Review title: Do yourself a favor a watch the original
Review_body: This movie was a horrible remake of what in my mind is a classic movie. I have watched the original so many times it's probably unhealthy. Every Halloween I bust it out while I'm carving my pumpkins, sad I know but it gets me into the mood I guess. I'd have to say that the best portion of the movie was the credits. Not because it meant the movie was over, although that was a good thing, but the zombies you get to see by this point actually looked half decent. As for the rest of the zombies in the movie they look pathetic. Most of them look like they were out of some 'straight to video' piece of crap from the early 80s. And what was with their eyes going metallic looking?!? The biggest problem with this movie, aside from boring stereotypical characters who you can easily predict when they will die, is that the zombies seemed based on the ones in "28 days later". Which really aren't zombies after all. Dawn of the Dead, like the rest of the series, should be about ZOMBIES. So they shouldn't all look like they just woke up from an all night drink fest and be able to run like marathon athletes. They should be lumbering, nasty looking, mindless creatures that are truly dangerous by their sheer number. Not because they can outrun most people up a flight of stairs.It was a true challenge not to walk away from this one.

i saw the movie, and was blown away.  the music, special effects, and directing really stand out.  the movie starts and does not relent for an hour and a half.  it just rocks the whole time. check it out and im sure you will love it.  i know some of the hard-core fans of the original are hesitant to see this movie, but i can assure you this movie truly takes its hat off to the original.  they even have some of the original cast making cameo appearances, and named one of the stores in the mall after gaylen ross from the original. you  will have a blast watching this movie, and i can not wait to see it again.

First of all, despite popular belief, rigomortis (pardon my spelling) sets in after hours of being dead. Dead bodies turn to zombies in a matter of minutes or even seconds. Rigomortis can be stopped in a dead body by simply excersizing the muscles, breaking up the rigomortis. So it makes sense that a dead body WOULD actually be able to run, jump, swim and skate normally if they wanted to. Second of all, the idea of "When there's no more room in hell, the dead shall walk the Earth," is just a theory of what is going on. That COULD be a possibility, but there are many others. Notice that when a person is bitten they are poisoned by the bite and die and are reanimated. (The next sentence could be a spoiler!) Yet, when Ving Rhames' character probably gets blood in his cut, he lives. Perhaps this disease or epidemic is infectuos only through the zombie's saliva, or maybe a bacteria in their mouths. There was also talks of "If this was a disease then how'd it infect the whole world in one night?" Try and think for yourself on this one. Maybe terrorist organizations created a man made super virus and set it off in every major country. Who knows? All in all this movie was simply put AMAZING. In my opinion it is even a better movie than the original. It seems to capture more of an apocolyptic feel to it. I'm buying the limited special collector's edition if there ever is one.

!SPOILERS AHEAD! Let me just start by saying, I'm a huge fan of Zack's Movies (No, Not That God Awful Owl Movie Abortion) I'm talking about Watchmen. Now as far as Dawn Of The Dead goes, this just shows how good Zack is with interpreting an idea that has been done and transferring it to modern cinema. Now I am very respectful to the old Dawn Of The Dead, however cheesy it may be to most movie goers now, it still made a huge dent in the horror movie crowd introducing a group of people under siege by zombies in a new surrounding. This movie does a great job enforcing that idea into a modern time. The cast could not have been more well chosen. The old film's image is still upheld in a new environment with great prestige. The only reason I didn't give it a ten is because, come on, its a zombie flick! You like zombies, this is a must see!

Review title: This movie while not as good as the original...it's damn good
Review_body: This movie totally exceeded my expectations.I loved the original by George Romero and was hoping that they wouldn't trash this movie.I work at a theatre so I went to see it at an employee sneak peek and I tell you what.When the end came...the real one after the end credits...I was really happy that the new generation of directors and hollywood didn't screw what I consider to be the premeir zombie film.Now the new one is not much similar to the old one minus the fact that it takes place for a majority inside a shopping mall...but these new elements that the director brought in made it great.First of all I have never been a fan of fast zombies but in this film they pulled it off great.This movie would've not been nearly as good if they hadn't had a fast zombie to fight with.The action in this movie is great.There is alot of action in it and they have just enough to keep it in the horror genre.Everything was done really well in this movie...now on to the bad stuff...The movie had too many characters.It wasn't that they were bad but you didn't really need that many people...it took away from that "we're all alone" feeling.Next on the list...exposition...I wanted there to be more of a background...how did this start...where did it originate from...but the plot throughout the film was really well done.But i tell you it would've been alot better with maybe 15 more minutes in the film for exposition.Another element while appreciated that I didn't like was the comedy.You have to have a little bit but they tried to turn plenty of it into a comedy...too many one liners.Overall I give this film a B+ on an all movie scale and an A on the horror scale.It was a great horror film and a good movie all around.I recommend this to Dawn of the Dead fans as well as new comers to the genre.

I just got back from the theatre and i have to say this movie ROCKS!!!!I loved the original and i was very sceptical about the remake because i didnt think you could improve on an almost perfect movie but man was i wrong-I have only one complaint and it involves a small infant but i wont say a whole lot for those of you who have not seen the movie.the casting was perfect...Ving Rhames,Sarah Polly they were meant to play those parts and they were even able to include cameos from Scott,Ken and Tom(who btw had the best line of the movie!)The makeup was not overdone and the special effects were outstanding-I think this is the version Romero might have wanted the first time because he said in his commentary of the original film the he wanted more zombies and there were a ton of them in this film.Some people criticize the film saying you dont need running zombies but i felt they were done very well-if you were hungry and was starving for food i believe you would run for it also.I felt for these characters even the not so nice ones and I think that helps make a great film-you feel sorry for the not so lucky ones and cheer for the unlikly heroes and feel the suspence in a dire situation.A very good movie and i can't wait to see this again.Ty

This movie met all my expectations and more.  From the trailer I know it's a movie with fast zombies instead of the slow ones from the original.  That alone hooks me and draws me to the movie; I've never been able to get into the old "Dead" movies Romero did.  I mean, come on, the zombies are so slow you can run circles around them.  How scary is THAT?I never watched the original Dawn of the Dead (only saw Night and Day), but I liked what I see here.  Right of the bat, the action takes off 5 minutes into the movie.  This movie isn't about panic, it's pure adrenaline packed into an hour and a half.  The action is fast-paced and relentless, helped by the zombies that can probably run faster than you can.And I just loved some of the irony in this movie, in moments it's deeper than most horror movies.

I just saw Dawn of the Dead and all I have to say is, GIVE ME A BREAK! The movie begins with some "unknown" virus that reanimates the dead who are infected, fine that makes for an interesting Zombie movie.  This epidemic is apparently world wide, although the cause is never actually revealed. They continually make reference to the armed forces and how they are trying to contain these creatures.  The United States military was subdued and virtually annihilated in one days' time.  You learn in the movie that "Fort Pastor", the army base near this city, is destroyed and is a "blood bath". In other words the United States Military armed with armored tanks, Assault Rifles, and Air Support, is less suited to the task of fighting these creatures then 6 average joes wielding pistols and shotguns.  Oh yea...and let's leave the safety of the mall to drive to some Island out in the middle of no where.  This movie takes place in Milwaukee?  Apparently there are tropical Islands out on Lake Michigan now...and how exactly did those creatures get to that Island or infect it?  Weren't they supposed to be mechanically illiterate? So boats are ruled out? and they cannot swim....This movie is littered with holes, save your money!

Review title: More of a nod than a remake *minor spoilers*
Review_body: As the summary reads, this is more of a nod to the original Dawn than a true remake.  True, the premise is the same but that's really where it ends. First off, the cast is much larger than the original so by sheer numbers alone, there isn't as much attention given to detailed character exploration as some would like.  More due to the performances of the leading actors than the script, I did find myself caring about some of the people in this movie. A lot of the characters are one dimensional and even those fleshed out a bit are more broad sketches than multi-layered personalities.  This really isn't a complaint because, for better or worse, this is a horror film and my expectations for such a thing in this genre have been lowered to the point thru years of viewing bad films that a little bit can go a long way in this type of film.   Second, the journey to get to the mall is much faster than the original.  I didn't feel it was necessary for the characters in this version to get there any later than they did because it would have really slowed the movie down.  There isn't the sense of impending dread in the remake like there is in the original; this film simply moves at a different pace.  Not really better or worse, just different.  In fact, that can be said for the movie as a whole.  It's not the original Dawn.  They simply can't remake that film for many reasons, not the least of which is the social commentary in the original wouldn't seem particularly relevant to today's audience.Now on to the review of the movie itself.  I have very few complaints with the remake.  I felt that segments were unintentionally funny, especially with Mekhi Phifer's (who really did deserve a better forum to showcase his skills than the tired subplot he was saddled with) character Andre.  I also felt there could've been more background given on Michael (Jake Weber). There seemed to be hints given about him through out that I'm not entirely certain were born more from the screenplay or the actor's performance. Also, the romantic chemistry between he and Ana (Sarah Polley) was sadly lacking.Now on to what I thought worked.  Ok...I'll admit it: I liked the zombies. I've read some comparisons to 28 Days Later in the other comments which I do agree with due to timing more than anything else.  The concept of zombies that don't stumble and stagger isn't really a new one, though.  There's an Italian zombie film that features such beasties (the title escapes me). And, in all honesty, 28 Days Later did lift a bit from Day Of The Dead in the last 45 minutes or so...  The opening to this film is great.  I feel that it goes about showing the utter chaos of the situation in a more jarring fashion than the original.  I realize I'm jumping on the band wagon here, but Ving Rhames is just awesome in this movie.   This is a bit random, but I couldn't help but be reminded of Lucio Fulci's Zombie during the end credits...I'd give this movie 6 1/2 out of 10 stars.  It's not great, but it's wildly entertaining.  It's not the original Dawn, either.  I think if one walks in expecting a straight retread of the original than they'll be disappointed. If it's taken as a different film with the same premise, then I think that it stand on it's own.

Review title: Not as thoughtful as the original
Review_body: SPOILERS!First off, I really liked this movie.  It lacked the expected 10 or so minutes of extreme gore ("feastings") that is in evidence in all the Romero films, and I think it was better for it.I did see a couple of inconsistencies and they always gnaw at me (no pun intended!).  At the end, as they leave the marina on the sailboat, you can see an island off in the distance.  Anyone with a sense of geography for Lake Michigan and the Milwaukee area should know there are NO islands there (you'd have to travel some distance up the coast to find some, and they're certainly not visible from anywhere near there).Lastly, as the owner of a 28' sailboat myself, there were a couple things I thought weren't particularly realistic.  First, the size of sailboat (I'm estimating 35'-40') should have a fuel tank of 30-35 gallons.  Half a tank of diesel (sailboats burn fuel VERY slowly) would give a range of 100+ miles.  Secondly, it is a SAILBOAT.  Being out of fuel isn't the end of the line....  Also, boats that size have dingies.Finally, I believe they were looking for an "unihabited" island.  There are a few small population islands further north (Mackinaw Island comes to mind) that would be a better destination and would require some "work" (killing of zombies) to clear but would be a good long-term home....Just my thoughts, but I welcome your thoughts/comments!

Review title: Some good twists, but overall a disappointment as a remake
Review_body: If you can forget this is a remake, it's not bad for an "escape" movie. It's got enough gore and action to keep you entertained, but for a moderate stretch in the middle where not much happens.  The opening sequence is absolutely terrifying, and pulled me right in with it's chaotic apocalyptic nightmare.  Once the characters get to the "mall," however, things slow down to a pace that makes me a little bored.The audience is never made to feel like the zombies outside are a real threat to the living in the mall.  The atmosphere is not bleak-- rather, you can almost forget about what's happening outside as the characters have fun inside the mall.  There's even comic relief (there were no comic moments in the original; it was completely dark).  I suppose this part of the movie was supposed to be about character development, but the movie even fails at that.  Most of the character development is shallow, stereotypical, and it is difficult to understand the motivations behind some of the characters' actions.While it may seem like I hated the movie, the last thirty minutes or more are edge-of-your-seat thrilling, so the payoff is good.  As far as comparing this movie with the original, I would definitely call this movie a disappointment.  It's too flashy!  There is slick heavy metal music, blatant product placement, comedy, and cheap attempts to make you feel emotional without anything deep or philosophical under it.  The original made you feel as if something terrible had happened to humanity.  This film only makes you feel as if something terrible has happened to the characters in the film, most of which you could care less about.

As a fan of the original Romero films and the genre in general, I was somewhat apprehensive to see what this film would do with the material. Fortunately, the result was an onslaught of gore, awesome looking modern-day `fast' zombies, well honed homage to the past, and snippets of originality from the writer/director that make this a truly excellent addition to the zombie film collection!  While House of the Dead (last year) had its good moments (and its bad as well), Dawn exhibited quality filmmaking all the way through.  I really enjoyed the energy, visual effects (gore) and cinematography, and the characters in this movie.  So many horror movies these days forget that characters are as important as the rest of the action.  Not here.  If you are a zombie fan, and you enjoyed 28 Days and/or the original Living Dead movies, you really should see this movie on the big screen.  There are some really great suspense sconces that we could never have imagined back in the 1970s.   Enjoy!

Having been a fan of the original for many years, I wasn't expecting much from this. But, it's brilliant! Never has a remake made me want to watch it over and over! The characters are brilliant, the Zombies are ace and there's some fit ladies in it too! I recently got the directors cut on Blu Ray and have watched it over 5 times!Watch the closing credits all the way to the end, you have to! I didn't the first time and missed some good scenes! Get it on DVD and watch the extras too! They rock!Trust me, if you like Zombie flicks, you'll love this!!!

Overall the movie was actually pretty good.  I loved the original and was excited to see the remake but feared that it would be a disappointment. It was evident that in addition to the large cast there were several other changes that were going to be made.  However, I was pleased with the outcome although it could have had more suspense.  There were a few flaws but I expected that.  After seeing the movie I was glad that the remake made several changes.  Dawn of the Dead (1978) is a classic horror movie, especially for that day in time.  It can not be duplicated.  Besides when classic horror pictures are redone and try too hard to be faithful to the original (Texas Chainsaw Massacre, Psycho, Night of the Living Dead), they suck.  I give it an 8 out of 10.

First off, I've been a fan of the original for years and I was extremely skeptical on what a remake would be able to achieve considering the source material.  That being said, James Gunn and Zack Snyder have put together not only one of the best remakes of any film I have seen in years, but a true classic within the zombie genre itself.  Is it as good as the original? It's hard for me to consider that since one of the things I love about the 1979 version is that it's so...well 1979!  I couldn't expect a 2004 version to include a ultra low-budget effects department, Goblin soundtrack,  and the Brown Derby Luv Pub.  This version definitely has some elements of the Scream/I Know What You Did Last Summer generation of horror film-making, but for the most part it improves the movie rather than turning it into another post-1990 crapfest.  There are enough sly nods to the original to demonstrate that Snyder is a fan of the cult classic, but he still makes sure to  let the audience know that this his own masterpiece right from the opening scene.  Most importantly, the film doesn't cop-out like last years 28 Days Later did. Snyder thankfully realizes that a movie about the apocalypse should stay true to it's theme from beginning to end. There are still a couple of minor flaws. The film does unfortunately shy away from the original's underlying message about consumerism, but that would be difficult to pull off in any film in 2004 since the film industry is now such integral part of that anyway.   I also would have loved to hear the hilarious mall muzak that played during the 1979 version's closing credits, but Jim Carroll's People Who Died and Johnny Cash's Man Comes Around are fantastic replacements.In the end, Dawn of the Dead 2004 is not only a film that should satisfy purists of the original classic, but also a refreshing revisit to the zombie genre that will hopefully inspire other filmmakers to do the same.8/10

Review title: Gore galore, with witty humor and an interesting soundtrack
Review_body: (Warning, some spoilers ahead) Starting off, I have not seen the original "Dawn of the Dead", but i have read about it.  I must say that after watching this version it makes me wanna see the original. Let me say this, however, i think this movie should be judged on it's own, not compared to the original in every detail. The movie starts off with no credits, the first ten minutes show the main character(Sarah Polley) going through her normal routine of being a nurse, getting home late from work and chatting with a little neighbor girl, and the going inside and talking with her husband. Let me just say they get a little romantic in the shower.  The next morning the husband wakes up and sees the same little neighbor girl at the bedroom door. The boy approaches the little girl and gets bitten on the neck and goes after his wife, who narrowly escapes through the bathroom window and drives away through the neighborhood seeing all the chaos and gore going on.  Then the credits start playing with Johnny Cash's The Man Comes Around Playing in the background.The rest of the movie deals with the nurse meeting up with several other survivors who seek refuge in a shopping mall and then eventually make a plan to make it to the marina and get a boat to escape to an island.  I won't mention anything about the escape, except that it involves armored buses and chainsaws.This movie is not really scary, it is however very gory.  The zombies are really terrified looking (especially the little girl).  The special effects are solid, mainly because they are not overused and nothing in this movie is too over-the-top or fake.The acting in this movie is about average, but you don't need Jack Nicholson or Russell Crowe playing main points for this movie to be a success.  The actors do their job in this movie, which is to move the story along and not overact and screw everything up. The best acting in this movie belongs to Jake Webber, who plays an everyday guy named Michael who is just trying to help as many people as he can while still saving his own skin.  He is the only character that you care about and you want him to live.The most intriguing thing about this movie is the soundtrack. The Johnny Cash song during the credits, the Air Supply song, "I'm All Out of Love" playing in the elevator as they make their escape. The best part of the movie for me was the montage showing what all the character's in the mall were doing to pass the time.  During this, the song "Down with the Sickness" is being sang and played with an acoustic guitar, which, to anybody who knows who the band Disturbed is, it will make you laugh or at least smile.The way to sum up this movie is to say, it's very enjoyable and very interesting.  It really doesn't fit into any movie category, except maybe future classic.  "Dawn of the Dead" has just as many humorous moments as it does terrifying, but that is what makes it enjoyable.  The only problem i had with the movie is the sudden ending, but that works well, i just didn't want it to end.  Director Zack Snyder has done something special, and i look forward to his future productions. I give this movie 9.5/10

Review title: Best horror movie in a decade?
Review_body: I was aware that I might be disappointed with Snyder's movie, but I have to say that it really surprised and shocked me. The energy of the movie is quite extreme as is the action. It is a miracle how this major passed German censorship, they are usually quite fast to turn down violence, but none of it here. I liked everything about this movie, especially the movie's credits and the fast running zombies, or the ending. I think the gory content is extreme for a major movie. Will watch this one at least once more.A big Hello and thanks a lot to Mr Snyder from me and all of my friends!10/10

Review title: Barricade your self in the nearest Theater and see this one!
Review_body: If you are a big fan of Zombie or suspense filled horror movies then this is a movie for you. Not exactly a remake but a retelling of the old 'Dawn of the dead. The same premise is there, survivors seek refuge in a mall from the Zombie horde, but all else is gone. The Special Effects are well done and the acting is on par with a decent movie. Much better than the Zombie movies of old. Not to mention the shambling zombies of old are gone. The fresh ones will give any track star a real run for their money.So in short if you go see one horror movie this spring see "Dawn of the Dead"I give it 4 Stars out of 5P.S. This is not a movie for the Kiddies. I saw several parents consoling young ones out side the auditorium.

"Dawn of the Dead," remake of the original 1979 film, delivers on all fronts.  It starts with a bang, submitting us to some very scary and disturbing imagery (my favorite being the bus window scene).  "Dawn of the Dead" continues the trend of updating the zombie for our time.  Back when "Night of the Living Dead" came out, it was supposedly a parable for communist paranoia - they could be anyone, anywhere, even our neighbors, and they're OUT TO GET US! The slow, encroaching threat of the red nation... "28 Days Later" showed us zombies that were based somewhat on modern tempers going to hell.  Air rage? road rage? consumer rage? There's a reason the virus was called "RAGE."  A metaphor for how seemingly decent people becoming virtually feral at the drop of a hat in our society - I see this up close every day, so that hit home with me. Here, the zombies take a note from 28 D-L and are faster, smarter and more vicious than any movie before.  Their speed and violence is also a perfect metaphor for terrorism in our age - it comes so suddenly, with such an amazing cost to humanity, and it seems that we just can't stop it no matter what we do.  It's everywhere we go, and it's not going to go out without taking a few of us with it. The writing of the movie is tight and pulls no punches.  This is a horror movie in the TRADITIONAL sense.  Forget that teen-level garbage with a bunch of nubile high schoolers being chased by some idiot in a mask.  This is a callback to when horror movies were written for an adult audience, and they're not out to be gentle or provide tongue in cheek humor.  They go for the jugular and they don't stop until they're holding half of your throat. This is an excellent, excellent movie, one that was well crafted, well acted and genuinely scary.  Intense and frightening in every sense of those words.  If it suffers from anything, it's a slight lack of character development, but they got more development in than I was expecting. 9 out of 10.  Twenty-first century horror has arrived, and it's not for your kids anymore.

Review title: Great Movie in its own right!
Review_body: Ok, I though they played this one perfectly!  When is a remake not a remake: When it is completely re written from scratch.  The mall was a plot device used to give fans from the first movie a familiar "place to call home" Other than that it is not the main focus of the movie as in the first one. Next you may tout Romero and put the 1st version on a pedestal but, Romero did a great job with the budget he had.  the first was campy and the zombies shuffled around slowly but hey it worked!  In this movie as in all of the "DEAD" movies there is never explanation given as to why it happens it just does!  Even with the better makeup and increased action the Dead aren't the focus as much as the interplay between the characters and their isolation.My main issues are with the credit scenes.  They sail off... to where? they are in Wisconsin the clips make it look like they are out of water so; last I checked they couldn't be at sea! The fuel thing was ridiculous they are in a sailboat. And why couldn't they fish for food?  Eventually the DEAD would decompose and slowdown.  And why in the remake of Night were the dead fighting over a rat but they don't eat dog?

This is really some pleasing disgust. I have the original dead trilogy and dawn is my favorite of the three. Non the less i think this is a brilliant remake If I've ever seen one. It has all the morbid tension and sick feel of the first film. It also manages to add a few personal touches which makes it both original and even more scary then the first one. I love it!! I would love for more directors to do what Zhan have done for this one. I see nothing wrong in a good remake, especially if it steps away from the original and creates something new and better as this one does. Then again you don't really have to compare the two. The original have many things in it that this one can never live up to since that production is of a totally different nature.
