I just got back from seeing this film, and I am so revolted by it. I've been a big fan of zombie flicks from the past, especially the romero and fulci flicks and this movie just saddens me. All I could think was rip off of 28 days later, and ruining of the original dawn of the dead. Heck, the movie starts in a hospital, leads into a dramatic loneliness seen, then the alarm clock imagery followed up by riot footage and a red on black title sequence so similar to 28 days later - oh and not to mention they sped up the film half way through, and of course magically all the zombies were fast paced atheletes - even a bloated obese woman, it made me feel bad knowing this movie was made in a america with a much more bloated budget than that of 28 days later, a movie that I feel made some steps forward in a genre that hasn't hardly been improved on since the early 80s. This movie also consists of a ton of plot holes and loose ends. Ridiculous. Absolutely. Now the group of friends I saw it with said it was OK as a gore film, but being a zombie fan and recognizing whats been done and why made this movie falter so badly. There's a million one-liners, some funny scares, a couple tributes to the classics (cameo by savini, head zombie, baby zombie, etc.), but it doesn't really do them any justice with the film as a whole. I say, if you're a zombie movie fan and you don't want to waste the eight bucks I just wasted, wait for it to come out on video, maybe there'll be a good movie in the special features on the dvd, who knows. But yeah, terribly unoriginal, and arrogant.

Since seeing the original Dawn Of The Dead as a teen back in 1992, I was definitely pumped about seeing the new DOTD as soon as it came out. Of course, "remake" is basically the kiss of death when it comes to getting fair and unbiased reviews before the movie comes out, especially when such a genre-defining film such as DOTD is remade. So I hoped against hope that my dreams of seeing a modernized DOTD that was worth seeing would materialize. Did it ever!! I entered the theater on March 21, 2004 (by myself as my girlfriend would have nothing to do with it) with great anticipation. Strangely enough, I was one of maybe a dozen or so people in the theater (which makes sense as I went about 2:30pm on a weekday) and got comfortable. The first ten minutes was among the scariest and best openings of a movie that I have ever seen. It was simply a rush to see the world go completely insane so quickly. The opening theme song ("The Man Comes Around" by the late, great Johnny Cash) was perfect in setting the mood of hopelessness. For me, the tension and the action did not let up until the end credits (and if you've seen this movie, there is still plenty going on during the credits as well). The fast-moving zombies and the sheer numbers of them, especially during the end "escape" really was great, too. I was also pleased that this film did not resort to the now Hollywood-cliché of computer-generated every thing. There are some (not many) spots where CG was used (most notably during the escape where there appears to be about 100,000 zombies in the mall parking lot attacking the shuttle buses. About my only complaint is that I wish there was more of a lead-in (as well as action) of getting into the mall as there was in the 1978 original. However, I came away very satisfied and hoping for a sequel to this fine horror film.

Review title: great horror movie that should please die-hard Romero fans and inspire new ones
Review_body: POSSIBLE SPOILERS, I DONT THINK THEY ARE BUT SOME OF YOU MIGHT, THEY ARE VERY VAGUE THO........i saw the movie last night at an advanced screening in manhattan, and all of my expectations were definitely met. i loved it, and every1 in the audience started clapping and cheering when it ended, something i havent seen happen in a long time. (do not leave right when the movie ends, zack snyder and company give us a little bonus footage during the end credits, a pretty creative and cool feature of the movie.) this was easily the most fun i've had watching a movie in a long time (besides Kill Bill). i have been a die-hard fan of the Romero Dead trilogy since i was like 10 years old, and i'm now 22 so thats 12 years of zombie support. like many others, i was a little nervous when i heard about this remake, but rest assured they nailed it and have made a great update that brings the story into 2004, embraces the fast-paced nature of modern horror, but also delivers a mood of nostalgia and uniqueness courtesy to zack snyder's creative directing skills. the only similarities between this and the original is the basic plot: survivors of the zombie plague take refuge in a mall and must learn to adapt within themselves and stay alive. other than that, this version takes the plot in many new directions, all effective and commendable. while there isnt the underlying consumerism theme or as much in-depth character studies as the original, the makers of this version wisely decided to focus more on the survival aspects, leaving the magic of the original alone. there are many likeable characters, especially those played by jake weber, ving rhames and mekhi phifer, all three give great performances and really bring you into their respective worlds of pain. ty burrell and michael kelly are also effective, adding enjoyable moments of comic relief that sparked big laughs from the audience i was with. sarah polley has a nice "girl-next door" appeal that makes her character very real. the rest of the characters are a bit thin, and you don't really get to know them much, but i expected this being that there are 15 people hiding in the mall and the film is an hour and 35 minutes. some of the best moments in character study included Kenneth's relationship with Andy in the gun shop across the way, Andre's desire to start a family and give his future child everything he didnt, and the zombie/ celebrity look-a-like shootings. please believe, there are plenty of zombie head gun shots, and the level of blood and gore is rather high for a hollywood movie. not as much flesh-eating as the original, but there are a few key money shots that cannibal hounds will enjoy (including a nice open stomach shot with a zombie feasting on insides). those looking for a lot of zombie action will be extremely happy, and the amount of zombies is crazy. very little CGI effects are used, and when they are, (like an aerial car crash shot and several zombies being ran over by a truck) they are done very well and do not look too fake. this was the most fun i've had at the movies in a long time, and i will definitely support and pay for this movie numerous times when it opens.(another cool thing was that when tom savini, ken foree and scott reiniger made their cool cameos, several people in the audience clapped and applauded, showing that many true Dead fans were in the building.) Zack Snyder has done an exceptional job for his first film, and he shoots each zombie attack very clearly, without the dizzying camera shots or quick editing found in 28 Days Later. he should definitely be commended, and the film makers should too for several small tributes to the original (like Gaylen Ross store and when the character Bart replies to Tom Savini's sheriffs comments by saying "see, that is a cool guy, he knows what we need to do" or something along those lines). this is the best horror movie to come out in many years, as it embraces its horror and doesnt insult the audiences intelligence at all. this film has many memorable moments and should stand alone nex to the original proudly, as long as original Dawn fans realize that this is a completely different approach to the story. the zombies found here are pretty scary, armed with great make-up and intense as hell, making for edge-of-your seat action sequences (such as the rescue of Nicole in the gun shop, the the sewer chase and the Arks drive thru the zombie-infested parking lot.) (how CJ makes their commute thru the lot easier is a really cool scene and received applause from the audience.) bottom line is this: zack snyder and universal pictures should be highly applauded for what they have done here, making an amazing zombie movie for 2004 that should go down as a zombie classic. old-school zombie fans should be very pleased, and new-school moviegoers should gain a nice liking for true zombie horror. make sure every1 runs to the theatre on march 19 and sees this movie, i promise you wont be disappointed at all. job very well done.

I think you have to have a certain mindset going in, when you see a movie like this. But I was blown away. Stunned. Awed. At times hilarious, but never campy, this truly scary movie is the most "human" ZOMBIE film I've ever seen. The characters are written with true depth and it really says a lot that this movie attracted truly top notch actors. Everything, even down to the music selection, was incredible. The tone of the movie was perfect. The way everyone worked together and eventually became a team really seemed realistic...not a bunch of hokey, horror movie cliches. Containing one of the most frightening opening sequences you'll ever see, this is simply a movie I'll never forget and will enjoy for years and years.

It was interesting that Zack Snyder decided to take the 28 days later path than the original Romero route, if he had done then i believe the film would have been slated simply because it is not as intelligent nor does it possess the social commentary that Romero's original did.What i did enjoy about the film was the fact that it made its Zombies out to be a real threat to the characters, unlike Romero's who really mounted nothing more than a nuisance. What is more, it always managed to install a sense of dread and I have to admit it made me jump on more than one occasionOverall, a pretty good job if I may say so !

Since i havent seen the original I have no comparative basis for which to base this review on.  I can say what Dawn of the Dead was an OK zombie movie.  If you are looking for a plot line, go somewhere else, because this movie offers none whatsoever. If you are bitten, you die, then become undead, simple as that.  The opening scene was probably the best part of the movie, offering a very chilling experience.  Unfortunately after the opening scene, the movie goes downhill and feels very drawn out with almost no action between the beggining and the end.  The movie just feels overall like old material and cliche.  If you have seen 28 days later, this movie doesnt seem very different. Overall I would give this movie a 5, maybe better because they shoot Burt Reynolds.

I would say zombies don't convince me when they are so sped up and super strong. The choice of a new species of zombie (as in 28 days later) induces cool action scenes, with characters turned into real gunslingers for the occasion (the foreheads of all those poor devils seem to be strong bullet-magnets). But we loose that horrible gut feeling we can have when we see a corpse, thinking it could be us, reinforced by the fact that this corpse is a moving parody of the living. These zombies are too much alive for my taste: if they are not as brainless as they used to be, they are less repulsive. They look more like mad people to me than creepy undead. That being said, some people may think slow zombies are a bore...

One of the best horror movies in recent memory right here people. If you are a fan of the genre stop reading this and go buy a ticket; if your not a fan of the genre, stop reading, go buy a ticket, and you will become one. Makes good as an homage to the original. tons of gore awesome directing. The first 10 minutes alone goes down in my books as one of the greatest openings of all time. What makes Dawn an exceptional movie, is the fact that the characters have depth. Just as soon as you start to like one of them and appreciate his/her quirks he/she wither reveals another layer r gets DEAD. If I were Romero, I would be proud to sit through this brilliant remake of an almost unremakeable horror classic. Do you self a favour, go see DAWN OF THE DEAD. 10/10

I'm a very avid fan of zombie movies, and like any huge fan I am very familiar with the original Dawn of the Dead. It set the bar for apocalyptic zombie fests and contained a brain inside its gory exterior. The new Dawn doesn't have that. In fact, the new Dawn doesn't have anything that made the original so great... aside from the mall, of course. That doesn't make it a bad movie. If this movie were named something else, I wouldn't have a single complaint... I would be raving about how fantastic of a zombie movie this was. But they decided to have this as a remake of a Romero classic, and they ripped out everything that made the original so... original. The new Dawn is scary, visceral and fast paced. If they would have slowed it down, and stepped it back a bit so the viewers could get a chance to know the characters, and see the characters reaction to their situation it would have paid better homage to the original. They're different movies, and they are both great in their own right. The new Dawn is excellent in its own way, and in itself sets a new standard for zombie movies. Hopefully the zombie movie will stay around for a while. I would like to see how this sub-genre fleshes out. Only time will tell.

Review title: Everything a horror film should be
Review_body: Being a bit of a closet gore hound, I was curious to see the film even before I was handed a free preview pass.  It was so much fun and better than I anticipated - let's just say that I wouldn't have minded if I had bought a ticket (which is lots more than I can say about Day of the Dead, Night of 1000 Corpeses et al).Lots of gore, lots of 'boos' that make you jump out of your seat, brilliantly shot, great soundtrack, comic relief ('serious dramatic scenes' within the confines of a gore flick that make the audience laugh, and superb effects and zombie mayhem that made the audience applaud) -- basically everything a horror flick should be. Kudos on the remake.  Better than the original.

I attended a preview screening last night and as a die-hard fan of the original I can honestly say that this movie (for the most part) kicked serious ass.It did a great job of forging the basic elements of the the original into something suitable for a modern audience without cheapening it. Great gore and action setpieces, great performances, great moments (the mid-film musical montage in particular is fucking priceless) and a very well executed ending.As with any modern horror film there are a few logical "what the fu**?" moments and I do wish the movie had taken more time to develop the sub-plot involving Mekhi Phifer's character and his wife but overall the movie accomplishes what it sets out to do in spades. Any zombie fan with an open mind shouldn't find too much to complain about. Can't wait for the uncut/unrated version DVD.

This movie was awesome. It scared the bejesus out of me as times. I am a fan of Romero's movies and a fan of horror movies. To me this movie didn't feel like a remake, it felt more like a reimagining. The opening sequence sucked me right in. I prefer zombies to be slow and stupid, but if "28 Days Later" was a reinvention of zombie horror, then i guess having the zombies be fast in this movie is a good follow up on that concept. Survival horror movies rule!  I loved the Jay Leno zombie part that was hilarious. The soundtrack was great too. I liked the version of Disturbed's "Down with the Sickness" not done by them- but as like a swing/jazzy kind of song. I hope the DVD has a lot of deleted scenes. If you liked "The Passion of the Christ", go see this movie.

Review title: One of the best zombie movies I have seen yet..
Review_body: Wow!  This movie was really great!  After hearing that Dawn of the Dead was going to be remade, I thought that it was a great idea because the original was also good, but it needed some revamping here and there.I checked out the official site for the remake a few weeks ago and the trailers intrigued me, including the ones I watched on television.  And after finally seeing the movie this afternoon, I have no regrets.  This movie will surely make you crap your pants, especially if you watch it in the theatres.  I have to admit half of the time I was holding my hands over my ears, but it didn't keep the movie from scaring the living hell out of me.The introduction was awesome, it starts out just showing the life of an average Mom and then it ends with her waking up to a nightmare.  Even the opening credits will frighten you in a sense, since it is packed with disturbing images and clips.This movie just kept me on the edge of my seat the whole time, and there were countless times where everyone else in the theatres along with me screamed and gasped from some of the zombie moments. The bad sides were there were a few unnecessary sex scenes which I don't mind, but I found them to be totally out of subject with the plot.  Eh, that's the kind of stuff that's in most good horror movies anyway. Nothing like a good ol' slash of sex and gore to disturb your audience even more.A 9/10!  I'm definitely planning to get the dvd when it comes out...  But for those who haven't seen it yet, you MUST watch this in the movie theatres when you can; the experience just won't be the same if the first time you watch it is on a dvd!

This movie kept my interest from start to finish, even though, it has the same name of a movie i've watched at least 10 years ago for the first time(im young). When I first heard about this movie I was like everyone else, very uneasy, knowing hollywood was remaking yet another classic. But not only was this a remake of THE zombie movie, I mean the phrase zombie movie and Dawn should be stimeutanous with anyone that is a fan of the genre.Now on to the remake. I went in this movie expecting nothing close to as good as the orginal. And thats what I got, but this remake is a total different movie. I appreciate the pace that it goes, although sometimes you find yourself catching up to the story, over the brisk pace. I think this is by far the best zombie genre movie to come out since Return. For a zombie and Action movie, this is a Gem, that delivers all the goods and more, it is a None stop trill ride.Go see it with an open mind, I dont think youll be disappointed.

May contain minor spoilersThe dead are back.  Dawn appears to be part of a string of neo-zombie movies that have hit theaters recently, including Resident Evil and 28 days. This one, however, is the first to be directly inspired by the original zombie mastermind, Romero.  Dawn was the most engaging of the original dead series, and is the clear choice for a remake.  It is the brilliant juxtaposition of a setting familiar to all consumers, the mall, and an outrageous situation, zombie chaos.  Romero also tossed in a hearty dash of consumer bashing as the zombies waltz around the mall to ludicrous background music.The 2004 version of this film takes the same concept, and injects it with a fat syringe full of adrenaline.  The zombies no longer stumble around, and bump into things.  They are ruthless hunters that know exactly what they want, and know that they have to haul ass to get it.  This makes the movie a much more tense experience than the original.  Snyder takes the serious (almost dry) nature of 28 days later, and blends it beautifully with humanistic (at times silly) tone of the original.The key to the success of Dawn, however, is that it is unlike most recent remakes.  Planet of the Apes or Bedazzled, for example, were both asinine remakes that whither when in the light of the originals.  The complex ideas were lost, and replaced with action and special effects.  The Movies were not updated; they were numbed for a modern audience.  Snyder, Gunn, and company were able to update the film with out numbing it down.  Sure, there is a lot of gore and some CGI, but the story is still controls and reigns in all the special effects and big budget hoopla.Of course the film does have its weak points.  One that comes to mind is when Ving Rhames attempts to recite a line from the original.  It is a thoughtful hypothosis on why the zombies flock to the mall, but Rhames gives the introspective line an awkward tough guy quality.  Still, Rhames shines in a bathroom scene with a little bit of religious rhetoric.Colorful (but perhaps stereotyped) characters, fast moving action, interesting situations, the scariest zombies to grace the screen yet, and all based on a Romero classic.  Justice has been done to the original, and the bar has been raised my friends.  This film breaks new ground for edge of your seat zombie mania.Zombie Fans 10/10 General Film 8.1/10

Anyone who doesn't think this movie deserves a very strong ten out of ten needs to have a screwdriver worked into their ear.I loved the originals, but Romero is, at best, a schlock director. Savini's remake of Night of the Living Dead was better than all three of Romero's, and Romero would have been nothing without Savini.This new movie grabbed me from the beginning, and worked me hard. There were plot holes big enough to throw a zombie baby through, but who cares? I got my moneys worth, and I can't wait for the next one. I agree with everything positive the above commenters have said, and then some.This silly thing wants me to be wordy, and have at least ten lines, so I'll just say that if I had been the character in the gun shop, the movie would have ended a lot differently. And I do tire of the standard "Charlie, go check the horses" cliche where some shlub(s) go off into the dark to see if they can be killed like Star Trek Red Shirts.Nevertheless, this was a movie that, if the Oscars weren't such a sad joke, would be a worthy contender for the camera work, if naught else.

Review title: A great film, regardless of it's predecessor
Review_body: Many people are giving this film low scores based simply on the fact that it's based off one of the best zombie films of all time.  I say they're morons.  Drop the Romero-elitist attitudes and recognize this film as a separate entity that deserves an unbiased and objective review, just like any other film.Now that I've said that, I'd like to say that this movie was simply awesome. This was one of the best zombie movies I've ever seen, and also a fantastic horror/action film in general.  I loved "28 Days Later" moreso than most, but this film blows it out of the water.  The movie sucks you right in from the very beginning.  The directing, costume/makeup and camera work is downright phenomenal for this genre.  All too often with past zombie flicks I've found myself less than pleased with the way shots were done, the way action was communicated and even the appearance of the zombies.  Not so in Dawn of the Dead.Character development is good and not overdone.  By that, I mean you learn enough about the characters to really relate to them, but you're left with enough room to imagine yourself in the same situation and develop your own view of each of the characters, instead of sitting there watching long close-ups and inner-thought dialogs wondering what the hell is going on in the character's head while the writer futilely tries to communicate some deep emotion.  This is a zombie movie, we're not here to ponder sentiment, we're here to be flung head-first into the dark, frightening, hopeless experience of Hell on Earth, and that's exactly what has been delivered with "Dawn of the Dead".I gave this film a 9/10.  It's my new favorite horror movie of all time (the former being Romero's "Night of the Living Dead").  You will get the crap scared out of you, and if you like horror movies at all, you will love every second of this one. :)

Review title: well worth the price of admission for me
Review_body: Not a "remake" so much as a "revision" of Romero's famous original.  While some of the more appealing elements of the original are gone (like most of the "mindless mall rat" aspect of the zombies), and others of the original rules are bent or broken, I'd still rate this as the best zombie movie since, well, the last Romero-inspired film (Day of the Dead).With a bigger budget, bigger stars, and bigger effects, the movie is somewhat more of an action film than the original Romero series...and that worked quite well for me.  My own personal rating of a flick like this depends heavily on the creep factor, the adrenaline factor, or a combination of both...and as far as I was concerned it delivered.Could this movie (and last year's far more turgid 28 Days Later) signal the revival of the true horror flick?  Well, yes, it could.  I personally found it refreshing to have zombies that moved fast -- and the nature of the film is powered up by that notion.  Imagine BlackHawk Down crossed with the original Dawn of the Dead.  There are a number of big, fast-paced, grab-your-attention-and-don't-let-go sequences that had me gritting my teeth in both tension and enjoyment.Final analysis -- there are only a few obvious improvements that could have been made, I'll go see the flick again for a second round of enjoyment, and I'm already looking forward to the eventual DVD release.  Two thumbs up (that's all I'm equipped with).(Oh yeah...did I mention?  All the blood looks =real=, as do virtually all of the gore effects, a rare event in any horror film).

Ok, I am a big Romero zombie movie fan and own copies of the trilogy including the remake of Night of the Living Dead so I was very excited (and nervous) when I found out about this remake. So on Friday I took in the second showing (didn't want to skip classes for the first). I bought my ticket in advance, went alone (my wife and friends are not so big on the genre) and hoped that this movie would not be a letdown. I was very pleasantly surprised. From start to finish, this movie had me glued to my seat pondering at one point the best time to get up and use the washroom. The plot moved briskly but without missing any important details. There were many subtle jokes made throughout the film as well as many allusions to the original, however if someone half-watched this movie they would not miss any important plot details. I'm not sure if I like fast zombie approach as I found that the original slow moving zombie added to the suspense. But all that being said it worked just fine. The direction was good, with some things seeming to jump out and hit you. The special effects were very well done, and the characters were believable. I would not hesitate to recommend this film to anyone and may even go see it again myself. One point...STAY FOR THE CREDITS a lot of people got up and left as the credits started to roll and they did themselves a very big disservice by leaving.

Review title: A Fast Paced, Scary, Must See
Review_body: I loved the original, and I loved this one, maybe a little more.  To compare the two movies is like comparing apples and oranges.The Similarities: The main characters are in a mall, one of them is a black cop, one of them is pregnant, and the walking dead (in Dawn 2004 the running dead) are intent on snacking on them.  That's where most of the similarities end.The Differences: The original had a slow building sense of dread and tension and was full of Romeroish social commentary regarding consumerism, racism and the haves and have nots of society.  Within the first five minutes or so of Dawn 2004, you are jump-started into the fast paced world or zombie horror.  All throughout this movie, I literally found my heart thumping furiously in my chest.  As far as the social commentary was concerned, I don't think there was any.  I could care less about social commentary anyway.  I go to the movies for the entertainment value and Dawn 2004 paid off handsomely.  In the original, there was a certain amount of slap stick humor that eventually became very dark and serious (i.e. the bikers in the mall).  Fewer characters in the original led to more character development. Dark humor was present in Dawn 2004 (i.e. the celebrity shoot off).  In the original, if a zombie got after you, you might want to pick up your pace to brisk walk if you didn't want to become a protein snack.  In Dawn 2004, if a zombie got after you, you better be gettin jiggy-wit-it or you're gonna get chomped.I loved both movies.  Both of them entertained and scared me thoroughly. I gave the original a two thumbs up rating.  I have to give Dawn 2004 two thumbs and a roscoe pointed skyward.

this one blew the old one away. there wasn't a drawn-out part of this one in which the survivors just hang out. that's taken care of in an entertaining montage. there's better action, more plot, more characterization, you're with the characters more. there's so many stages to the movie, so much happens. it isn't a satire like the original, which works for this movie. it works like classic adventure stories work: it's about people finding strength and sticking together in incredible struggles. it's the best "regular" movie of any zombie movie i've seen, and perhaps the best zombie movie. one of the ten best movies of the past year or two. the classic was fantastic. this one was better.

Being a faithful follower of George Romero's Dead trilogy (Night, Dawn, and Day), I was somewhat satisfied with the remake of Dawn of the Dead. It has great action!!!! However, it lacks in some areas. There are too many characters, thus leading to a lack of character depth. The running zombies just didn't cut it for me as it reminded us of the ghouls in 28 days later (i.e., seemed like a sequel to 28 days later at times). Finally, if the dead are returning to life, then why is it only those who have been bitten?!?!?!? Those shot or dying of natural causes do not re-animate!!!! That's a major difference from the trilogy and Romero's concept. MAJOR FLAW in my opinion. On the other hand, the action is great and does an amazing job at causing tension and anxiety in moviegoers (I think I checked every room in the apartment when I got home). Also, the story line is good enough to maintain one's attention. I suggest loyal and new fans go see the remake, all will enjoy!!!! Little piece of ADVICE, stay till the end of the end credits.....there are some extras to the story line...don't leave the theatre until everthing is done!!!!

Review title: Exelently funny disgusting tribute. A must see.
Review_body: The first few minutes of the film are pure genius. The build up of the situation with the zombies is fantastic. The zombies themselves are a clever mix of the zombies from the original trilogy and from the recent '28 days later'. They still trudge around groaning in the classic chillingly mindless way. But then they see a human and go beserk and start running ferociosly towards there prey with all their strength. They are fantastic mindless killers.The gore is second to none in quality and quantity. This film is the result of the director and screenplay writer being true fans of the genre paying tribute to all classic zombie movies. This is not a remake. So if you see other people winging that, "it's not as good as the origional" just ignore it. GO AND SEE THIS MOVIE for yourself. Ignore the title and accept it for the quality modern horror that it is. This is one of the very few movies that had potential, recieved the budget it desrerved, was taken seriously by all involved, was directed in an origional and peasingly clever way, and was pulled off as one of the most entertaining movies in a long time.The movie doesn't get boring at any time. The comic relief between the scary, frightening, disgusting (very), and genuinely sad moments is timed perfectly. You will know exactly what I mean when you hear the jazz version of 'down with the sickness'. Everyone laughed and some even applauded the timing.This film is a fantastic cinema experience. GO and see it at the big screen while you can. A must.PS. The ending is great. Stay seated through the credits.

Review title: Even though different from orig it was done very well
Review_body: Even though this movie was shot differently and the details were different. It did have the same gist of the previous release.  Also what is great, the ending makes a more seamless transition into day of the dead.  And the cameo from Tom Savini was great.  I am sure not many people picked up, but it was great!  This movie could not have been remade any better.  Zack Snyder did an excellent job!  I have seen all the others several times and I could watch this one over and over and over as well.  For someone to remake a classic sets them up for disaster if they are not careful and this remake was an absolute success!   I could go on and on about the differences between the original and this one.  But is not worth it, as they are two distinct  movies that stand out.  Can't wait to see what else is next, as many classics are being remade.

I went to see this movie on Friday night, I liked this movie.  I tried not to get my hopes up too much because the original is such a great movie.I think this movie was more of an action movie, where the original was more creepy because they built the characters more and there were less action sequences.The new version was made more creepy for me, having it based in Wisconsin, hearing the Milwaukee Emergency Broadcast System, seeing Milwaukee Squad Cars, and the County Bus.  Hearing that Miller Park is no longer safe. Living in Milwaukee all my life, having these points made it a little more realistic for me.Also very cool were the cameos by some of the cast from the 1978 version of Dawn.  Scott Reiniger (Roger/General), Ken Foree (Peter/Televangelist), and Tom Savini (Motorcycle Gang Member/Sheriff).  Those were the three my friends and I spotted.Anyway, all in all it was a good movie, but not in the same category as the first.

The internet, because it is so high-tech, allows for many useful functions and uses. One of them is to let me tell everybody (who can read) how f***ing spectacular this movie is. No previous zombie film... maybe even ANY horror film... comes close to delivering as much terror and awe as this theatrical legend does. Any pessimist or coffee shop-employed, movie critic wannabe can just shove a cracked baseball bat up their ass instead of bitching about how "It wasn't as good as the 1978 version." or "It reminded me of 28 Days Later...) WAAAH!!! Cry me a river and drown yourself in it, douchebag. This piece of work has a potpourri cast of characters that really beautifies the film and makes you think "It's great that these people are here, respecting each other as humans, charging foward each day in an attempt to survive... however, it is sad that it took a tragedy of this magnitude to get them here." Besides the characters, it has a great soundtrack for the type of film it is and shows vast improvement over the 1978 versions cliche disco-horror music. The lounge-version of "Down with the Sickness" and the closing credits song are absolutely fantastic. The movie itself is a great evolved piece of George A. Romero's screenplay and is a testament to his genius and Zack Synder's courage and prowess.

Review title: The definitive horror in every way. THIS IS HORROR AT ITS WORSE!
Review_body: I like to see horror movies to escape from reality at times.  The only trouble is most of them feel fake or to make Hollywood happy it's toned down or it gets a "happy" ending.  The original Dawn of the dead gave you a feel of terror and helplessness... but probably due to a low budget it couldn't go all the way so it wasn't ferocious enough.   Every missing aspect of the original has been integrated in this update and it never lets you down. When you leave this movie any problem you may have in your personal life is nothing compared to what the world is perceived as in this picture.  Even without reflection you feel some sort of comfort to be on the other side of the screen.  A real horror movie isn't made to give you cheap scares, it's made to terrify you.  If it achieves that, you know that the movie deserves its due credit.  In every possible way Dawn of the Dead 2004 is the best horror movie ever made in history and since the last "best horror movie" was the original Dawn, I don't think it will ever be topped... well maybe in one case: Since this movie was rated R, the DVD will probably be released as "Unrated" like the original Dawn was.  If that is the case it could well be the most disgusting movie ever made as well! (Day of the Dead (1984 Unrated) is still the champion because of its realism.)  Most people can't think with this frame of mind but if you keep the frame of mind I'm writing about, you too will enjoy this masterpiece!

O.K. 1st, I loved the first 10 minutes when everything was just chaos, people waking up to their loved ones trying to eat them. I wish they would have shown more of that.Zombies running, jumping & climbing was cool, even though they did'nt do that in the original. But what I did'nt like is that the zombies did'nt kill and eat EVERY living thing including that stupid dog "chip". In NOTL Dead 68'  Zombies ateRats, Bugs, Worms even burned remains of people, any flesh they could gettheir hands on. But in Dawn OT Dead 04' they did'nt have a taste for little chip.Hopefully, in the sequel the zombies will remember to put a little HOT SAUCEon the none human flesh, TO BETTER THE TASTE!

I must say, i havent seen a decent horror movie in some time, and already loving the first Dawn of the Dead, i was really looking forward to this one. I wasnt let down. I wasnt expecting to see an oscar winning film here, all i wanted was 90mins of entertaining, leave my brain at the door blood guts and gore. It is never going to top the original, because that was ground breaking, but it comes very close. The story being similar in the fact that there are zombies and they are stuck in a mall, thats about where it ends though with regards to this. The main change which made it a lot more exciting was the fact that the zombies were fast and more terrifying, no longer thinking, "its alright they can just walk round them"! The film is in your face right from the word go, and rarely lets up until the end, but the end is a tad disapointing though. I would recommend this film to anyone who enjoys this genre. Great stuff! 9/10

From the first 15 minutes of the film, I quickly decided the newly revamped Dawn of the Dead was my new favorite horror film. This feeling carried me to the very last moment of the credit reel. The directorial style and cinematography brilliantly blended new aspects of thriller genre camera work, basic narrative portrayal, and the same kind of old school shots found in the original version of the film. This adaptation picked up the horror where the original version left it more as subplot for the in-your-face down-your-throat satirical attempt at political statement and assult to capitalism and the blossoming consumer market. Don't get me wrong, the political aspects weren't entirely unfounded and were well thought out in some aspects. It was saturated with symbolism and hit on some major discussions of the time. My problem with it was it wasn't about the zombies! If I want political rhetoric, I'll watch an Oliver Stone flick. If I'm watching a movie entitled "Dawn of the Dead" I want zombies. I want ripping and eating and blood and gore and let's not forget fear for lives and too-close-for-comfort escapes. The new version was full of all the aspects I crave in a good horror film. Suspense, gore, character connection, and those nice little moments where you actually pop up from your seat a bit. Honestly, I must admit I don't know what makes the original a classic but I am surely glad they decided to do the remake. Granted there were a few holes in the plot, moments that you say to yourself, "Why the hell didn't they just do that a couple weeks ago if that was an option?" However, I suppose that's just a constant in the horror genre. If everyone was logical not nearly as many people would be killed, situations could be better averted, and we would have no plot to unfold.

Review title: you get what you pay for
Review_body: Just seen dawn of the dead and would like to say i was very pleased with what i saw, i walked into the cinema not taking anything too serious or expecting a master piece, just some gore and violence satisfying fun.This film gave me that and then some, the camera work and style of direction was superb, the humour dark and overall atmosphere of the film was very foreboding.I especially liked the fact that the zombies could run (Like in 28days later) and didnt just shuffle along. (Lets face it, how could zombies take over the world if all you had to do was start a brisk walk to escape?)The makeup is excellent, the acting wasnt as wooden as expected, and the cringe inducing action will keep u wondering how much further things can go. Its also amazing what you can do with a credit sequence these days :-)

I'm begging for a refund and to be paid for the 2 hours of my life wasted watching this movie. NO real story line, no surprises, nothing other than zombies who kill people, but only when the people are dumb enough to get close to them. Lots of potential in the beginning, but once they hit the mall, there is no story, just a random series of events leading to an ending. I think they threw in a little bit of nudity in the middle to get people who were drifting away to focus for a few seconds... Good Lord, Waterworld was better than this piece of crap. I know 5 year old kids who could have written a less predictable script. How did they get out of the situation when the gassed the zombies and burned them? Did that eliminate ALL of the zombies down there? How in the world did every person in that movie learn how to shoot like that? I thought they were going somewhere with water when they showed the dramatic shot of the nurse washing the blood off her hands in the fountain and then the 'twitcher' splashing around in there...Where did these people come up with the ability to trick out those shuttles? All of the sudden they're welders and metal fabricators? Come on...

When I saw this version of Dawn of the Dead of course I didn't expect this to blow away and be even better then the 1979 version of Dawn of the Dead cause hey a remake can not beat a masterpiece.  But the nontheless I still thought this version was a great movie and I enjoyed it greatly, the ending was a bit of a suprise and honestly sort of reminded me of another zombie me called well Zombie back in 1980 cause of the whole island and zombies on the island thing.  Ving Rahems, Sarah Polley, Mihkei Phifier, Jake Webber and the rest of the cast was excellent and didn't do a poor or cliche acting job as other zombie movies do often.  The violence and gore was good, but could of been more graphic and violent like the original Dawn of the Dead was, but of course the MPAA won't allow it so I understand (I guess we will have to wait for the unrated version to come on DVD lol) the fast, running zombies is a depature from the original and traditionally slow moving zombies, but we are in the 2000's now so hollywood has to conform to today's standards so the running zombies are ok.  Anyway to end my comments I do not think this movie in anyway will be nominated for an academy award, but this should certainly mark the return of the living dead or if u don't get what I'm saying the return of the zombie movies.  Now I'm just wondering if the Italians are going to remake Zombie since they made the original Zombie right after the original Dawn of the Dead was made.  Anyway from the looks of it this movie will be a huge hit as I'm writing now 4/2/2004 it grossed already $44,000,000 and still counting.  Shout out to the cast, director, and crew who made this version of Dawn of the Dead u guy's did an awesome job.

I wasn't sure if whether the original could be outdone or not. I am happy to say that this remake was totally AWESOME. The acting was great,the special effects were great and overall,I was very impressed. I am hoping that there may be a sequel to this once that all is said and done. The ending did place a little doubt in ones' mind as to what the outcome was. The updated version of how the zombies moved and carried themselves was definitely needed. The fact that the zombies moved as fast as a normal person made it even more exciting and convincing. I guarantee you that if you take it upon yourself to go and see this movie,you definitely will not be disappointed. I took a friend with me to see it who really isn't into horror flicks and science fiction,but he left the movie theater totally satisfied. He said that he couldn't wait for it to come out on DVD.

as a fan of the original, i was pleased...i wasn't sure what to expect, but it was both entertaining and scary...it took the "28 days later" approach combined with the Romero version of "turning" into a zombie...i liked that...it was also the only flick i've seen that a zombie does a certain thing...and i've seen a few zombie flicks in my day...it was more of a homage than a remake...the mall setting, but even that was different...the dialog was snappy and the directing was definetly decent for someone who, i guess from what i know, directed commercials before this...disturbed's "down with sickness" was a fit well...it won't win any oscars, but, on the popcorn scale...10 for me.

I love the original Dawn of the Dead, so I just had to go see this remake. And I thought it did well in adding in new stuff, while still staying close to the original screenplay. I also loved the cameo's they had and that truck that the old lady drove in the beginning was also from the first film! And if the end made you say, WHAT! Thats It? THATS THE ENDING? Well, if you remember, it is similar to the end of the original Dawn of the Dead. Also, my favorite part was when the guy Andy, the guy in the building across from the mall, is shooting the zombies that look like celebrities! I thought that was funny!I liked all the comedy in this film a lot! Anyway, this movie is good in my book!

Review title: You have to see this film!!!!!!
Review_body: I went into this film not expecting too much from it as the original was utterly crap, cheesy in every sense of the word. However the film took what was a great original concept and made it into the film it was destined to be. When the film began I thought it might spend the first half hour explaining how the zombies came to be, but, I was thrust right into the action about five minutes in. The very first zombie scene in the bedroom had me jumping out my chair at every second, I was astonished. The film manages to keep up it's great suspense and also throw in some great humour without making the film cheesy. I will also give you a tip for when you go to see it, do not leave right after what you think is the ending as the credits roll the real ending comes alive on the screen which I found to complete the film as the first ending was a bit too cliched and the proper ending left me wondering. Not only does it outclass the original in every way but it's also excellent as a stand-alone film. Everyone MUST see this film!!!!

Review title: School report about this wonderful film
Review_body: Dawn of the Dead was recreated just a few short weeks ago. The original screenplay, written by George A. Romero, was combined with the one written more recently by James Gunn. I think Gunn did a wonderful job keeping the original story intact while adding a bit of humor and his own style to the movie. The movie was directed by Zack Snyder and produced by Eric Newman, Marc Abraham, and Richard Rubinstein. It was done by Universal studios and was released in March 2004. The movie is rated R for pervasive strong horror violence and gore, language and sexuality. The leading actors were well chosen in my opinion, and include Sarah Polley as the lead actress and Ving Rhames and Jake weber as leading actors. I think this movie fits in well with Romero's former films. Although it has a bit more humor to it, it still retains the original gore and horror. This movie will shock you at some points, and have you giggling at others. It's a wonderful remake of a wonderful movie. The plot can simply be summarized as `zombies are killing EVERYONE,' which is to be expected when seeing a Romero film. It starts out in a small town, showing the havoc that this new virus is reeking. No one is sure exactly what is going on, but the only sure thing is to watch your back at all times. People are on a rampage, killing and eating everyone in site. One woman runs into a cop, who lets her tag along with him. They soon find 3 more folks who are heading to the mall. As anyone who has seen the original will know, this is where the bulk of the movie will take place. The long series of scenes at the mall are very different. Some are humorous, while others are violent and gory. The movie rolls onward as the plan their escape from the mall, and they venture outward. The acting was very well done. I very much enjoyed how Ana, or Sarah Polley, didn't act like most women in zombie movies. She took situations head on, and didn't scream and whine about what was occurring. Kenneth, or Ving Rhames, was a very good team `badass.' He made sure stuff was done right. Michael, or Jake Weber, added a sense of romance, while still adding to the comedic value of some scenes. As in the original `Night of the Living Dead,' we are given someone to hate. We hated `Cooper' in that one and we definitely hate, or love, Steve in this movie. He did a great job of p***ing everyone off and saving his own ass in all situations. All things considered, I think the cast did a great job of recreating this masterpiece. Several camera angles were used throughout the movie to show that a surprise was coming. You see someone go to a door and slowly open it, showing a close-up of the person of the door handle, only to find a zombie jump out at them. The slowed down movement lets you know something is going to happen, but it always scares you when it does. I don't understand why, but this technique seems to always do its job. One technique which has been widely used lately, was the combining of comedy with horror. This movie however, I believe utilizes this technique to the fullest. `Scary Movie' for example, completely got rid of the horror while adding a large amount of comedy. This was somewhat of a letdown as it turned from horror spoof, into `stupid teen comedy.' `Dawn of the Dead' added comedy amidst the horror, but only at appropriate times. At times where there was a break in the action, or times when you would least expect it, the writers through in a joke, or ironic situation to keep the viewers laughing and scared at the same time. The production techniques used and many of the camera angles added to the already wonderful story in the film. I've read before that there was symbolism behind the mall itself. The original was put out at a time when malls were beginning to gain popularity. People were flocking to malls to get `whatever they wanted' in one place. So these people, in a time of terror, go to the mall. Some believe Romero was mocking the population in some respects, since these people did not spend all their time trying to better their situation, but used much of it just getting `whatever they wanted. This time however it was free, and it showed the greed of humans. Greed, or in this case selfishness, can lead to stupid situations. One man ties his dead, now `zombified,' wife to a bed in an attempt to bring his unborn child into the world. He knows the pain and suffering he is putting his wife through, but continues to do it. His situation does not, however, end up exactly as planned. This is another way Romero and Gunn could be mocking the population. I think the underlying theme behind much of this movie is that humans are stupid, greedy, and self centered. I would give this movie a 10/10, had it been filmed in Monroeville Mall. (Since I am from Pittsburgh) However, I will still give it a 9/10. I highly suggest seeing it, but not until you see the original. I would also suggest seeing the original Dawn of the dead, Day of the dead, Night of the Living dead, and Return of the dead, although Return is not a Romero film. I would also urge you to go see this movie now. Don't wait for it to come out on video, as it is one of my favorite movies of late. The humor adds so much to this wonderful classic, which can appeal to any audience, young or old.

Review title: Zombie movie fans will LOVE this remake
Review_body: I am a HUGE zombie movie fan and I anticipated to watch this movie for a long time, but never got round to it since I could never find the DVD. I found it and watched it today with my friend and I was mind-blown. Finally, someone has got it right. Remakes tend to be a bit rubbish but this was fantastic. The plot was great, the beginning was perfect, the actor/actress choices were amazing and the whole movie kept me on the edge of my seat. I did not want this movie to end at all. The character development was great throughout the movie and I defiantly had a favorite and least-liked characters. Zombieland was also a fantastic movie, just like this one and if you liked zombieland I suggest you have a watch of this. I give this a 10/10!

Review title: The film that should of been Resident Evil!
Review_body: I heard about this film and seen the adverts/trailer on TV. After taking a keen interest to the trailer i was wondering in my mind is this a real horror with gore blood and guts or is it another teen movie where 6 teenagers are stuck in a building one by one mysteriously disappearing with no logical reason only for the film to end with the pretty guy and the sexy girl survivng! This film is so not that!This is chilling and frightening..it is the sort of film that when you walk out of the cinema you think a blood sucking zombie is going to jump out and start chewing away at your flesh! The main thing that makes this film real is that there are extremly little (if any)unrealistic computer generated graphics..its all done on make up and good acting! (when i mean computer generated graphics i mean like the Licker that appears at the end of Res Evil movie) It all starts off in a hospital where a main character is working as a nurse..being rushed on a wheely hospital bed is a guy who has a bite on his head *making this seem like something that requires stiches and can be treated easily"..at this time everything is totally normal..then when this young nurse go's home and gets to bed after a hard days work she and her husband wake up to something disturbing!...this is where it begins!...the horror starts here!lol enough of me banging on..the film has that feeling of suspense that you need in a horror movie "OH MY GOD WHATS GONNA HAPPEN...oh no its only a pussy cat" sort of stuff where you think something bad is gonna happen and then it is just nothing at all,but then something will jump out and make you need to go to the toilet really badly! The film also has alot of comedy to it..one part..where the survivors are on the roof of the building where they escape to and across the street of a spectacular wave of living dead people is a man who owns a gun shop sat on the roof with a sniper rifle!..he on his own and Kenneth (Ving Rhames) are talking by writing down what ever it is they want to say on a whiteboard..they play chess but also Kenneth tells the guy which Zombie Celebrity lookalike he wants to shoot (like Burt Reynolds looking zombie) but its little funny bits like that make you realise that only in a film they can shed light on being trapped in a building surrounded by infected skin eating dead people!The acting is fabulous but what makes it hard to believe is how the characters react to some of the situations. All in all this is the best horror i have seen yet (could be an all time great) and i would rate this top of the list as a must go see for 2004!This one gets 8/10

Oh my goodness. I am a huge fan of zombie movies but I have never seen one like this, this made me laugh, cry, flinch, and left me with my mouth agape. Some things were a little bit unrealistic but I think that was added for the humor, the characters had a surprising depth while at the same time being a little bit predictable. This is now one of my holy grail moves. If you're considering watching this, do it, you will not be disappointed. The only reason not to watch would be if you get queasy with gore, in which case you should probably avoid the whole zombie movie genre. The ending was great, a little predictable but when you watch through the credits you really get the full closure. The cinematography was great, the acting was amazing, and the characters were quite realistic. Great film.

Review title: Just brilliant fun . What a Zombie film should be .
Review_body: 10 out of 10. Just what it says on the tin . Gore, laughter and bittersweet.

I don't get it. Why is it that the critics, who often dislike otherwise good movies over petty details, actually LIKED this thing? I hated this movie.Warning: contains spoilers."Dawn of the Dead," or more precisely, "Yawn of the Dead" is another cookie-cutter horror movie for the masses. As the movie progressed I picked out so many things I hated that I couldn't fit it all into one review.A note first: I am judging this based on its own merits as a stand-alone film. I believe movies should be judged on their own, and I have attempted, as much as possible, to enjoy it as its own entity, without comparing to the original. However, since it does bear a resemblance at some points, I have had to compare just a little to illustrate a point. The movie begins pretty well. I knew the little kid was going to die, because otherwise she had no reason to be on-camera so early and for so short a time. Predictable. Willing to ignore that, it started pretty well. The city in flames, everyone getting killed... I had no problem with this early part and found it did quite well to bring about a feeling of apocalypse.The movie went downhill quickly. The woman in the beginning forgot about her dead husband within 5 minutes. Why? Because they didn't want to concentrate on character development. This is the major problem I had throughout the whole film.Another example of this: the conversation between the police officer and the young man in the bathroom was interesting. I would have liked to see more of this, see their opinions and conversations grow or shift as the movie went on. The problem is, again, the director wanted to throw a reference to religion in so he could say he did so, but didn't want to bring it up again, like he did with so many other concepts in the film. Religion is brought up, briefly, with a televangelist talking about "When there's no more room in hell..." but this is obviously thrown in only to use the tagline from the original. It makes no sense here, where the zombies are a result of a virus, and I can't see a Christian preacher saying this in any event(in the original it was quoted from a Voudon priest). Note I'm not calling the characters by name. Why? They were too 2-dimensional for me to remember, to be honest. I couldn't remember half the characters in the film most of the time.Another example. In the original, we learn that the woman is pregnant only after hints, secrets, foreshadowing, etc. In this one, two characters meet three characters, and BAM one is 8 months pregnant. Why? Because the director wanted the sudden shock of pregnancy, but didn't want to do as Romero did, byt actually using character development to lead up to the revelation. That would take actual work with a plot and with dialogue, and this movie is just about blowing people up.The way the characters get to the mall is similarly contrived. When the two characters meet the other three, they ask them "Where are you headed?" One of the three responds "We're going to the mall." Which, of course, just happens to be right behind them, so that no time has to be taken up traveling to the mall or talking or anything. That scene was about when I realized the film was going to suck.The whole movie is contrived, just like that scene, with weak(or no) dialogue and zero character development, except for the security guard wil suddenly becomes a good guy. The "surprise ending" was lame, also. I have no problem with characters dying en masse, but seriously, think about it. Did it really make any sense?The major problem with the film is one I've been mentioning. The movie had too much crammed in, and not enough attention given to any one part. We have all the themes of the originals, really: religion; people fighting themselves while they should be fighting the undead; a fear of what is causing this menace; a pregnancy in the midst of this terror; innocent victims rescued and taken in; waiting on the military; and so on. The problem is, instead of concentrating on a couple strong themes and working them, the film has all of these things thrown in and then doesn't really pay attention to any of them, opting for zombie massacre footage instead.Similarly, instead of having three or four characters developed and continued strongly, we have a dozen or so characters, most of which appear nameless and pointless, and which the audience doesn't care about.I might have liked the movie more if I hadn't been in an audience full of idiots. Some people behind me started laughing when the one guy on the other building said he was starving. Yeah, that's real funny, morons.On that note, I would like to say that the one part of the movie that I did like were the scenes where they were playing games with the guy across the street, or having fun in the mall in general. Those were decent scenes, and I think, aside from the graphic sex in one part, would have fit into the original movie really well.One last thing: I saw a bunch of little kids in the audience. What's wrong with you people? Why the hell are you taking children to see this kind of movie? I mean if the graphic violence and profanity doesn't offend you, what about the nudity and sex? Is this appropriate for your children?Overall, on a scale of 1 to 5 stars, with 1 being useless and 5 being perfect, I give it ** stars. Not quite horrible, but below average, certainly.

Review title: Good film, unfortunately with some flaws.
Review_body: Now this is a film you don't get to see every day! The mere fact that this film's a remake and does only suck a little makes it special, but what nearly a real gem these days, if there weren't those stupid flaws I mean, is the exclusion of clichés (well, the most of 'em). Like, if this was the typical profit-oriented, no-room-for-artsy-stuff flick, it would drown with the other crappy attempts to make money of abusing the good reputation and cult of its originals. But actually, this one succeeds in combining modern video-clip aesthetics with effective cinematography and good storytelling.The films first ten minutes are hilarious. Not only because the opening begins with the end of the world right away, but also because the credits begin not until those ten minutes. Another plus is the avoidance of any explanations for the zombie-phenomenon and, oh the word "zombie" isn't mentioned at all! It's disappointing, to be honest, that the heroes don't coincidentally find a book, left on a table somewhere, that describes them how to get rid of the plague and that standard lines, like "I won't leave you here!", are missing. Well, for the satirical aspect: it is really ironic seeing that, with the problems that come from the 4th amendment, only gun carrying people survive at the beginning - Matt Groening will probably like this message. What unfortunately really flaws the film and nearly destroys it, if there weren't those action-packed scenes following after, is firstly the aspect of everyone shooting the zombies in the head (the only way to kill them) with a near 99% accuracy, which is something one can live with since only gun-crazy people survive the attacks and reach the mall. Secondly, there is a scene which really is ridiculous (and I don't mind spoiling it), where a woman risks her life for a dog and after that having everyone risk their lives for the same stupid woman. What also bothered me was the Character of Steve, whose job is nothing but being an asshole and - surprise! - dying at the end, leaving all the "good guys" to survive. But aside from that, it is a really good film which has its moments - whether they are funny, action-loaded or exciting.

This movie has it all. The beginning of the epidemic, strangers coming together (or not) humour, some brutal scenes and a great ending.
The best z-movie there is

When I heard they were remaking Dawn Of The Dead, I figured it was going to be decent. The remake of NOTLD was just a modernized version of the original and that's how I figured this on would be. No, instead there were running zombies, who didn't even look all that dead and a stillborn zombie baby. Now that's just wrong. If I wanted to see Mekhi Pfifer deliver a stillborn baby, I would watch ER. And the fat zombie woman that was clearly a guy in a dress. There were none of the characters from the original film. Ken Foree was a preacher who said his old characters tag line, but that was it. And it looked like somebody left a light filter off of the camera. I have seen home movies with better lighting This movie should have been named "Dawn Of 28 Days Later". It was pure garbage.

I anticipated this movie for quite some time, and was pleased to find it was awesome. I love the original, of course, so I was expecting a lot. It was different, and the zombies were definitely faster and more advanced than the previous. I'd have to say all in all, I loved the movie. It was full of action and seriously kept me wanting to see more from the moment I sat down.The ending wasn't great though. I couldn't tell exactly what happened, but I suppose it was good to let us wonder, in a way. The whole baby thing was a little freaky. I was happy to see an elevator scene! I gave it a ten... there's no comparing to the original but as far as horror movies go, this was good.

Review title: Great action added to the original fear
Review_body: As an old horror/splatter fan i was really looking forward to this remake of Romeros classic horror pic, and I turned out to not being disappointed.The plot is much like the original movie, 90% of the movie takes place in a shopping mall. The dark humor is still there, and so are the conflicts between the main characers. The biggest different from Romeros film is the added action sequences, which are much like the ones in 28 days later (which also is a great modern Zombie-tale).The only real flaw is the patriotic under tones which shines through in a couple of times in the movie.This is a must see for all movie lovers who wants 100 minutes of "jumping in the seat", "laughing like h..l" and "biting their finger nails".Enjoy the film!

While it lacks the social commentary of the original, what it does pack is a king size action punch. This is a scare/shock fest from beginning to end and to that extent it's one of the best in years. While I do favor the original I honestly don't feel this can be considered a remake. Of the few similarities that both movies share, the shopping mall being the most obvious, they're quite actually very subtle. I understand that filming of a sequel is to begin shooting early next year. How you make a sequel to a remake is beyond me but if it's half as good as Dawn of the Dead 2004 then I shall be waiting in line at the theatre to see it. As a Zombie film collector (39 and still growing LOL), come October 5th, this film will make number 40.

Review title: If you have not seen this movie yet, see it.
Review_body: First off I know this movie was a remake but it's one of the best movies I've seen in years. I don't even know where to start describing savage and brutal this Zombie flick really is. This is not your average zombie horror flick where everything is normal at the beginning and the living-dead count rises gradually over the course of the movie,the living are horrifically outnumbered throughout the entire movie. Special effect's 10 STARS, hands down, no question's asked.period. I've watched it about 15 times already, Yeah it's that good, and I usually don't care for horror flicks. Cant wait for the Sequel!!!! "When there is no more room in Hell, the Dead WILL walk the Earth."Favorite Line: "You have got to shoot em' in the head, they seem to go down permanently when you shoot em' in the head. And after you shoot em' in the head, you've got to burn em'". -Wisconsin Deputy Sheriff

Review title: Tribute to classic B film flicks.
Review_body: This movie is a pretty good tribute to the g(l)ory of old Zombie flicks. I'm no expert, but chainsaws, shotguns, gasoline fires, and stakes seem spot on. Off course, this movie did spend a lot more money than the 70' or 80' horror flicks (counting for inflation). So there is a lot more of everything.As always, I was annoyed by the sub fifties IQ level of the main characters, but that is what these movies are all about. Screaming at the screen, WHY, oh why don't you try something else? Like what I just thought about... Oh well, I guess they're not especially fit for survival.What amazes me is the utterly hostile reaction all characters meet each other with once they first meet. Is this how Americans greet each other? In a disaster area? They kind of grow and become more humane during the movie, but no reason is given for their ape like behavior in the first place. Well, it is a splatter movie, who needs character development anyway?But still, I feel there is some attempt of character development in there somewhere. It feels wrong, it is disturbing. It just fails

Review title: A reason not to be scared of remakes.
Review_body: Although I don't usually approve this is quite simply one of Hollywood's best efforts at reinventing a classic. The opening sequence alone is amazing, it is a perfect view of what the apocalypse would look and feel like from a single person's point of view, and it sets the tone for the rest of the film beautifully. And with obvious additions of FX(which weren't available, I know), more characters, a wider scope, and more comedy (great cameos) as well, as much as I know it cant replace the original it comes calling. With an abundance of sequels, and remakes out there, and more coming I'm sure, let them follow suit of Dawn and don't lose sight of the original, add to it.

But damn! this movie was awesome! Actors were best, they all fit to the movie perfectly. Especially Ving Rhames and Michael Kelly were damn good! Review title: Can somebody explain why this movie gets more than 5?
Review_body: I just finished watching dawn of the dead and i am terribly sorry for the time i wasted. My first thought was, why don't i log on to IMDb.com and see the rating?? And i see a rating of 7+!!! What the hell?? This movie is a complete waste of time to watch. Everything is set up, and you can tell that every scene. I mean, one moment all the dead are overflowing in the streets, and the next moment there are only 5. Or on one moment they can smell the living from very far, and the second moment they can't track a living human 5 meters away, until they hear a noise coming from there. And these are just some examples. The movie is full of Hollywood clichés.Go see fight club. Don't waste your time.

I was not a fan of the 1978 original beyond one viewing. Maybe there's this great sebtext people talk about, but I never found it and, if it was there, I never found it interesting enough to pay attention.Dawn of the Dead in 2004 is slicker, faster paced and has a well told story. No, the character development won't rival some of the major epics of our time, but it's a horror movie. People don't watch it for the romance or the emotion. You're watching to be frightened and to be entertained. A little gore doesn't hurt either.There is enough character development along the way that I did care about what happened to these people. I didn't care about many of them, but I did care. Ving Rhames is a great actor in his own right and Sarah Polley has the potential to be an action heroine as she plays off the ludicrous horror well and sells the action very well.I highly recommend this movie to a fan of horror, young or old. It does borrow effects ideas from 28 Days Later, but that is forgivable as I believe this is a better movie.

Review title: A decent remake, but could have remained more faithful to the original.
Review_body: This is a decent remake, but it could have remained more faithful to the original. The attackers in this movie behave more like people infected with rabies than zombies. When the undead spot their potential victims, they charge at them at full speed. And, not every victim rises from the dead, but only those that are bitten. Sound familiar? In previous "Living Dead" movies and knockoffs, attacking zombies stumble around like, well, zombies. And everyone who dies comes back, not just those who are bitten. This is an obvious rip-off of "28 Days Later." However, if we can get past the similarities, this movie has enough thrills, gore and suspense to be very entertaining for fans of the genre.

Review title: If you're looking for rabid crazy zombies eating stuff with two legs
Review_body: this is the film for you. After one of the years best beginnings where a large number of people dies in innovative and otherwise funny ways, a not shabby bunch of actors get crammed into a mall with some stupid security guards, and together they shoot zombies, all to a very agreeable soundtrack. At times funny, at times slightly terrifying, and at times just plain crazy cool. The zombie effects look great, for a change, and the pace of the piece is somewhere between comfortable and full throttle heart attack speed. There's also very few elements of sucking plotwise here, as in opposed to the last third of the punier 28 Days Later.

Review title: Excellent Movie But Not Dawn Of The Dead
Review_body: The movie was great,definitely one of the better films in the genre recently.Unfortantly I don't think it should have been called dawn of the dead.First of all the "zombies"had more in common with the infected from 28 days later,in both transmission And mobility,than any resurrected dead traditional or otherwise.I don't see how they can run full speed considering they are reanimated flesh,and dead tissue goes through rigor mortise.As for similarities to the original, it has a mall and a few lines of dialog lifted from the original.but with those gripes out of the way,I must say the movie was great.The story was tight ,if not to deep.The inclusion of a zombie baby birth was something i've wanted to see in a movie ever since reading Brian Keene's novel The Rising.I also thought the character dynamics as they were stripped down to their essence in the struggle for survival to be very interesting.All in all though,I personally think this movie is best viewed by forgetting its a remake of Romero's film,and take it in as it's own creature.Under those circumstances the film is in my opinion a very welcome addition to the undead canon.

I found this film to be truly awful, mainly because I don't like action films. I don't consider it to be a zombie film or even a horror film. Zombies are supposed to be slow and stupid because they are dead. Their muscles are supposed to have been damaged, decayed or suffering from rigor mortis. Their brains are dead and thus incapable of thought, this results in stupid behaviour and lack of coordination. This unnatural behaviour contrasts with what we expect of a human being. In other words we are disturbed by the abnormal movements of the zombie-human. This is horror. In this film, the monsters run about and act more like insane but otherwise normal humans. They are not creepy at all. They do have an exciting shock value. This is action.The director obviously had so little idea of how he wanted his zombie extras to behave that he resorts to some pathetically cheap shaky camera techniques. If you can somehow forget that they are supposed to be zombies you might be able to enjoy this as an action film, but not a horror film. It should not be called Dawn of the Dead.

Review title: The Re-Birth of the dead left me craving more!
Review_body: I didn't quite know what to expect when I ventured out to the cinemas with three of my best mates to watch the remake of Dawn of the Dead nearly ten years ago. The only Zombie movies I'd really seen were "Night of the living dead part two" and Michael Jacksons Thriller. (If you can call that a Zombie movie). Let me tell you people I don't think I even blinked during the whole movie. It was as fast paced as the movie Speed, as gory Brain Dead (well maybe not quite that gory) but it was also laced with humour everyone could enjoy and some humour only a few select geek minorities could. It's a simple but entertaining story and it makes you think, "what would I do in that situation?"From the opening credits with Johnny Cash's song over the top to the end credits where we get to see what REALLY happens in a Zombie apocalypse, I was glued to the screen. I saw the movie four times at the cinemas and even snuck my 13 year old nephew in on one occasion and it was so good he had nightmares for a month!10 out of 10 for this one kids.Bane
