If there was an entrance from the outside - reinforcing the buses would have been impossible - as there would have been a constant stream of ghouls..?Please enlighten me... so I can get some sleep over Christmas ;-)

As far as horror movies go, this was pretty average. Its best feature was, quite definitively, the special effects. The zombies looked pretty realistic, along with the blood and gore which would accompany their deaths. Unlike other horror movies, you feel more immersed because of the realistic zombies.It lacked in other departments, though. For me, it was only exciting in the beginning and the end. The middle was long and tedious, broken up only by the occasional event -- which often turned out to be a dud. There was one really strange part (more strange than scary, which is a reoccurring theme in this movie) which sort of livened things up, but other than that, it was dull in the center.The acting was convincing. There were few lines that sounded forced, and it all seemed pretty natural.Overall, a good watch if you're a fan of the horror movie genre, or if you love special effects. Most people will probably find it about average.

Review title: A genuinely scary movie, and a lot of fun. Run, zombies, run!
Review_body: Having missed this film in theaters, I have only the Director's Cut DVD to go by, but I must say "WOW!" Snyder and Gunn's adaptation of George Romero's 1978 zombie thriller is a nonstop roller coaster of suspense, despair and horrific thrills. This film gives the audience a scant five minutes or so to get comfortable in their seats, and then sends them rocketing through a story in which you must ask yourself, "What would I do if the end of the human race seemed to be upon me?" You will see so many basic human emotions in the face of such an unimaginable tragedy: shock, denial, acceptance, sorrow and anger. You will constantly put yourself in the characters' places and ask what you would have done differently. You will marvel at their instinct for survival, applaud them when they succeed and feel the frustration when they fail. One of the more controversial topics of discussion in regards to this movie is the swift physical capabilities of the zombies. This is a stroke of genius in the making of this film, however. When you've seen zombie movies in the past, you've often watched as the zombies s-l-o-w-l-y stagger towards their prey, often dragging a leg behind and reaching them only because the character ran away screaming, yet continuously turns to look back, and finally trips on...nothing? I for one was never impressed. That was never scary, it was disappointing. When the zombies are constantly running towards everyone they see with only the maniacal urge to kill, however, it becomes a seriously frightening concept. How do you defend yourself against groups of dead people who feel no pain, have no fear, experience no fatigue and move as fast as you can? I highly recommend this film for it's action, it's shock value and it's ability to portray the basic instinct of human preservation. It may not win an Academy Award, but this is one fantastic thriller for the 21st Century.

I am a huge fan of the zombie genre and I 'craved the flesh' of a good modern day zombie flick. I watched the DVD directors cut version of this movie with high expectations as this was my most anticipated movie of the year and I just loved it so much I had to write a quick review on it. Dawn of the Dead is a modern day remake of George A Romero's 1978 Dawn Of The Dead. The story follows several survivors of an epidemic of undead, as they barricade themselves inside the local mall to survive the growing zombie plague. The movie is filled with many tense, thrilling moments where it is comically broken with humour; this is a good thing that adds a human factor into the movie. The performances were believable and realistic given the whole Armageddon scenario which was pleasing to see and a great choice to include the character known as Andy. Without doubt the true stars are the zombies. The makeup for the undead was nothing short of amazing, with by far the best visuals and makeup of any zombie movie. Some scenes are superb like the opening scene where Anna (Sarah Polley) wakes up in the decrepit, crumbling world where society is falling apart with the zombie infestation and the great shots of how huge the zombie population has grown.. The movie does get into a good rhythm with enough character building and action sequences for the audience to care about who lives and who dies. IMPORTANT NOTE: Don't turn off when the credits roll because the movie keeps going. The final scene of the movie sticks to the back of your mind after watching, leaving your imagination to do the rest.I haven't seen the original 1978 Dawn Of The Dead, but I loved this rendition. Dawn of the Dead is a brilliant must see movie for any horror fan.

Review title: One of the better horror remakes.
Review_body: First time I watched I absolutely hated, considering it was a remake of one of my favorite movie's.But the second time I watched it I began to enjoy it, and besides it's many predictable moment's and clichéd character arcs and the odd weird scene, it was very enjoyable zombie flick, and although it does not live up to it's name, it's defiantly one of the better horror remakes. It is also probably one Zach Snyder's better movie's, considering his made some terrible one's recently. But again it does not live up to it's name, having some pretty bad characters who were obviously going to die from the start. It also lacks the satire and acting from the original, but I expected that from the start. There is very good camera work in some scenes especially at the start. There are also some very tense scenes, not really enough though and the plot isn't one of the strongest I've ever seen.But in conclusion dawn of the dead is an above average zombie movie which is very enjoyable but doesn't do much for the brain.

Review title: One of the best Zombie movies I've seen...
Review_body: ...and I've seen quite a few. This movie is a must for all those enjoy seeing horror-zombie movies with a twist, but not containing excessive amounts of blood and gore, like BrainDead had. Unlike others, I don't think this movie should compare to Resident Evil because zombies here don't act like those ones, oh no, not at all. You surely will need to see the movie to understand, but I was simply delighted. Most important, this movie contains no pseudo-scientific bullsh!t regarding how do the zombies appear, skips through unnecessary preparation, the soundtrack is absolutely beautiful and the end, oh, the end is... what can I say? Great-great-great! Overall, I very much enjoyed seeing this and I guess it's a movie you can see more than once. I, personally, have seen it 4 times in 2 days and I always found something new to look at.

Review title: More Flaws Than You Can Shake a Dead Limb At
Review_body: I'll make it simple. Both Snyder and Gunn managed to put together an action film with gore and flash. However, they didn't make a ZOMBIE film. They made a horror film that settles for the lowest common denominator. Sadly, this is the modern trend for nearly any horror film created by a Hollywood company (remake or original).To avoid looking like a simple basher, I would like to start out by saying that the tandem did do a few interesting things. The special effects and the montage sequence at the beginning added much to the original story. I wouldn't be surprised if Romero would have loved to have added a similar montage to his original piece if he had the budget at the time to do so.Sadly, that's about all they did right. Snyder quickly took away the core emotion of the original, gutted it, and filled it with stuffing. This remake is something that had much potential with such a large budget and advancement in filming techniques. However, Gunn managed to write some of the worst pieces for a ZOMBIE film. This film was written in the manner of a body-count film. The characters are introduced on screen, we don't care much for any of them, and they are quickly exterminated in the flashiest manner possible. Gunn couldn't have given a damn about his characters, and Snyder did little to help by making the Zombies doped up on meth.Thus, instead of making a very character oriented film like Romero did back in the 70s, Snyder and Gunn created a plot-driven film. With such a take on a genre with more depth than any other in the horror branch of film, there's little interest left for the audience. Romero had 4 characters in his mall, and only these 4 characters had any real screen time. They bonded. They grew. The audience grows attached to the characters. These characters pushed forward the events of the film. However, Snyder managed to avoid this and go straight for the jugular. There was no character development. There was no attachment. All you had was a group of over TEN CHARACTERS on screen getting butchered one after the other. There was so much potential with the ORIGINAL group that Gunn had written into the mall at the beginning of the film, however, he opted to add more and more so he could kill them off. Character development and meaning were sacrificed, leaving a very hallow film with nothing but running corpses and explosions, and none of the creative flair Romero had written and directed.Take away the "Dawn of the Dead" name and all you have similar to the original is the mall and Tom Savini making a cameo. You won't care for the characters or the hell they are put through, as they aren't on the screen long enough for you to attach to them. Gunn shows his amateurish writing ability (which, oddly enough, gets you far in Hollywood) with this screenplay--then again, he wrote the second Scoobydoo film, so there is little shock there. Snyder did a decent job with the weak material he was given on paper. He could have done a much better job by directing focus to a small portion of the core group so we'd grow to care for these people. However, he too fell into the pathetic Hollywood style of bang over substance and gave us a flashy action (and body-count) film with corpses on meth.If you haven't watched this film, don't rush to see it. Watch the original, and await Romero's Land of the Dead this June. This is a forgettable film with an unforgettable heritage.

Review title: Nothing new. Just average ("B" class) film with some special effects and a lot of blood. Mix of the "28 Days Later" and the "Resident Evil"
Review_body: This film did not bring anything new or original. The storyline is almost the same compared to the film "28 Days Later" ( http://imdb.com/title/tt0289043/ ). Some new disease started to spread. Nobody knows what it exactly is, how does it spread, how to stop it. Few people comes together to some shopping mall and try to survive. And the ending is a bit pessimistic. (You must watch whole ending-titles to see whole end of their story!)So this film has more special effects compared to the 28 Days Later - explosions. It is more bloody, too. And main "heroes" kill undead by shooting them into theirs heads. Isn't the same killing method used in the "Resident Evil"? ( http://imdb.com/title/tt0120804/ )It pumped adrenalin into my blood, like other films, but I was disappointed by the storyline. Worse then the average.

Review title: I would've recommended this back in 04' and it should definitely go down as a "Cult" Classic
Review_body: I remember seeing this in the theater, back in 2004. I will never forget how unexpectedly horrific, excited and awesome the opening 15 minute scene of Dawn of the Dead actually was... and I was 24 at the time. Also take into account 2004, was well before the entire "Zombie Apocalyptic" genre pandemic swept across everymovie complex and network station. So dear TWD fans, something you should definitely do is pay homage, watch this movie and thank it's creators for helping pave the way to entire genre!

I said before something about Andy's extra-fast transformation... focused mostly on the roof scene, something else occurred to me: just look on the fresh zombie's expression and gestures... I mean, at the beginning, after throwing down the bloody sign, Andy looks around for a few seconds, and it seems that he doesn't quite know what's he looking for, or what he's doing... in other words, he's disoriented... just like a new born animal, a deer cub who tries to get up on his feet, but without success, or anything similar... So, my theory is that Andy got bitten inside the shop, he also hyped inside (dvd extra), but he wasn't quite completely morphed... in the first minutes of zombie-being, the zombie/human has to overcome the new-born like sensation, this human to zombie violent transcendence.... What would be your reaction if a ultra-deadly virus will kill you, and you'll wake up with a fresh swiss-cheesed brain? I guess "highly confused" is the word(s) you're looking for, even if you wouldn't be able to think that much about the state you've just got into. That explains a lot of things: in the first minutes of the film, we witness how Anna's husband dies and wakes up as a zombie, and when he does, he wanders a bit around with a "I don't know, who am I" expression on his face... not to mention the little girl who's simply staring at the loving couple, without even trying to jump on them an kill them instantly... Another example... that new big fat lady zombie in the mall.. when she wakes up, she first stands still and tilts her head, without instantly harming the surrounding folk... In the end, even Steve the Zombie looks a bit at Anna like he's just waiting for her to say hello to him... That's a thought to think about... Not like the transformations in Resident Evil, or any other almost-cheesy zombie flicks, where the living wake up as perfect zombies (sometimes, the transformations happen when the dude's not even really dead... a some kind of lucid feet stand transformation of the living dead, loll :)) So, after all, Dr. Logan's desperate tries to educate Bub, in Day of the Dead, weren't so futile after all... I guess Dr. Logan would have succeeded in educating Bub, returning him to a more human-side, fact witch he partially did, if it weren't for that army clichéd, zombie sociopath freak... all in all, it's a form of racism, you know :) (reminds me of 'The Dead Next Door')... even the zombies have rights after all, huh? Why shouldn't they... it's not like they wanted to become zombies... If the remaining living want to blame someone for all the unnatural mayhem, they should blame the one who deserves it... none others than the creators (or creator) of the virus. But hey, if you put it that way, I guess the ones at NASA have to be blamed, since the true origin of this apocalyptic plague is that irradiated crashed satellite (NOTLD 68)... hell, you think they'll admit it? Noah... they don't even really admit that, even now, they're messin' up the ozone layer, with their rocket flights, fact which is 100% real, let me assure you. Another fact that bothers me is that everybody thinks that zombies are made of pure stupidity and cannibal instincts... That's not true... First of all, ask yourself these questions: why don't the zombies simply attack their kin? What drives them straight to the mall? What about their learning capacity? Is there really one? Of course it is... just watch how the zombies open Andy's door, just after the dog gets in... Or the zombie without legs, the one who mastered his climbing and hanging skills on the cellar pipes, beneath the mall, silently jumping on Bart... I say that's a trail of intelligence, after all... But I guess these guys will show their true scholar side (:)) in Land of the Dead... can't wait to see the movie! Funny I haven't sent it yet, isn't it? Well, what can I say... I'M FROM ROMANIA GODDAMIT! D'ya think that fresh made films just pop-out on our 2-star cinemas or on over-aged, almost communist TV sets? But what the heck... After all, I can consider myself lucky, you know... I'm among the few ones who manage to crop a few new good movies, once in a while... Hope that I'm not gonna wait too long to see Land of the Dead, though I heard the flick is in the can... or worse :)

There are good elements to this film and some bad ones. First of all, the bad ones. I think that some of the scenes were completely predictable and unrealistic, and the only reason the were put into the film was for the suspense effect. I believe that even the smallest flaw in a film, can ruin a film overall, and this film certainly had many of them. Despite these small flaws, the film had impressive elements like a creepy almost surreal atmosphere, that gave you the sense of what it's like to live in a nightmare. I enjoyed the consistency of the action, which kept me thrilled throughout the film. Overall the film was a good suspense thriller which could had been better if there had been a little more ambition.

Review title: Classic zombie movie to compare and relate all future movies to
Review_body: Warning about minor spoilers:Dawn of the Dead is the most widely-recognized zombie film in my opinion, and everyone can agree that it has very important elements that we look for in an apocalyptic film. It has emotional loss, in-group tension, a temporary mall haven/playground, a stupid decision to try to leave, modified/armored vehicles, a gun store, and a crazy escape plan. Some things that could have been altered include saving a main character that got bit and chose to be left behind, the rather awful ending mixed with credits, the majority of the people dying, a better definition for what caused the outbreak, the use of amputation to save a life, slower walking or at least worse postured and unbalanced (uncoordinated) zombies, the desire for the zombies to eat any creature not just human, less of an unrealistic explosion with propane, and more. Overall this remake picks up and leaves alone some important aspects that the original covers, and the two movies make great buddies. The new one has many more thoughts in mind, while the old one is centralized in less locations.

Review title: The best zombie movie I know!
Review_body: I have seen the remake a year before the original movie. And I am a fan of remakes, if they are good. This remake is way better than the original, to be honest: It's my favorite zombie-movie. The makeup is great, the effects are good, the actors are good, the camera-work is good and even the actors of the original movie have cameos (not as their old roles of course). I think, "Dawn of the Dead" from 2004 is simply the best zombie movie I have seen yet, better than the George A. Romero's, better than "28 days (and weeks) later" and better than "zombieland" (but not funnier). The only thing that is not that awesome is the violence: It is very bloody sometimes. But that doesn't make the movie much worse, the blood is used in a realistic way, not like "If they shoot a zombie just let the head explode" or something like that. All in one: This movie is just great.

Review title: By far the worst zombie movie I've seen in a while
Review_body: Wow."This is the worst movie I've seen." That was my reaction and repeated thoughts throughout the entire movie. I was just devastated and chocked by the ill screenplay. I cannot understand how someone can write a screenplay like this. With really unfitting and inappropriate comments, feelings and actions throughout the entire movie. I feel deeply sorry for Ving Rhames for being part of this movie.I think that this movie was completely ruined by its screenplay and does not deserve the high rating of 7.4. If it wasn't for the good effects and screen, I would have rated 1 point, although I think it deserves a 3 point thanks to the effects.The music is also of worst possible choice. It does simply not fit.It was a complete disappointment.If you enjoy zombie-movies, like I am Legend or World War Z, don't watch this movie. However, if you get turned on by gore, you might find one and another exciting scenes.All in all a terrible movie. Don't watch it.

Review title: Just buy it and like it
Review_body: Need I say more?I don't really see a lot of people barging into the boards and saying how much this movie sucks, and I agree with them. This movie is at the top of my list so far, right above Day of the Dead. Who cares about those slow, un-terrifying zombies that seem to take over the world oh so easily, when you can have faster, meaner, more fiercer running zombies that are able to smash through windows with one punch? I saw this movie the first day it came out, and I have to say I became obsessed with zombies once I saw this. It was so good, I went and saw it again about a week later.Sure it has its dull moments, its stupid moments, and those famous "Let me have my own speech" moments. But it's worth the watch. But I don't know why people don't like the plot as well as everything else. I mean, I guess they overlook the movie too much, and start concentrating on the plot. Please, don't do that. You will just ruin the movie for yourself.But I must say, the writer did pretty well for a remake, though it shouldn't really BE a remake, since it only has a few things that actually relate to the old Dawn of the Dead. The death scenes were great: a woman getting sliced by a chainsaw, little girls ripping skin and muscle out of guys neck...awesome. The actors are great too. Ving Rhames did a great job. I like his character because you barely see him laugh, he's always serious, and he doesn't seem to talk much, which you need in every zombie movie, must I say. Then there's the stupid one, Nicole, where they get everyone killed. Please, for God's sake, it's a dog! Well I guess it had to keep the movie going. And then you have to smart allick, Steve, where all he does is push everyone out of his way, and barely helps, no matter what happens. Whatever you do, don't trust him when he has to watch a door...Now go buy the movie, watch it, and like it. Promise me, it's worth the $24.99, and it's worth the hour and a half. What more do you need with running zombies, suspense, horror, great actors, nice death scenes, and an awesome plot on one DVD?Exactly.

Review title: It's a keeper vs a twitcher.
Review_body: It's a solid zombie movie but with a twist: a cast you can actually care when they end up munched. All of the characters are much deeper than more or less any horror film I've seen. You actually feel sorry for Anna being an overworked nurse, Kenneth is just trying to get to his brother, Michael is just trying to stay alive, and Mekhi Phifer's character is just trying to become the husband and father he never had. Jack the playboy, is the group a$%^*&e and plays it perfectly.Don't get me wrong, there are things that wouldn't make a lot of sense in real life. Like why would a police officer have the shotgun from his cruiser but not his sidearm for which he'd doubtlessly have 50 or more rounds of ammo? Why not find every possible weapon and use them to kill as many zombies as possible? A gas pump that works without electricity? Minor things with minimal impact on the movie but just don't make sense either.All in all, I enjoy watching this flick frequently and just ordered the DVD of the original as well as the original "Night of the Living Dead" A little known fact about "Night of the Living Dead" is that the TV reporter (Bill Cardille) in the film actually did work for WIIC in Pittsburgh as the host for the Saturday late night horror double feature.

Review title: The best "Dead" movie made so far.
Review_body: Finally, somebody got it right!!! First let me start by saying that I have always been a huge "Dead/Romero" fan. With that said, this is the best "Dead" movie made ever; and yes, I am aware that this is not a Romero flick. That's not to say this one was perfect, but, close. The zombies are fast and scary; finally, the way they should be. I don't know what the budget was like for this movie but the film looks great. The script/dialogue is at times questionable and casting is less than bang-on but these are minor flaws. This movie is fricken terrifying! Get the DVD, it's well worth the extras. BTW. I went to "Land of the Dead" with the greatest of expectations...save your money, rent the DVD.

Review title: worst movie ever seen, total waste of money
Review_body: worst movie ever seen, total waste of money , movie is for kids and for the people who are not mature enough, i don't understand how this movie got above 7 . although movie deserve 5 rating but i am giving it 1 so that it should come close to 5 , i request all the viewers who don't like this movie to rate it 1. If you read something like this: Dawn Of The Dead is a great film. It's funny, it's clever and it's got zombies in it! Just when the British film industry appears to be dead this gem pops up and shows us what someone with a sense of and a real passion for the media can achieve. Go watch it, you'll laugh till it hurts! TRUST ME THEY ARE LYING

First....and this is in no way disrespectful of anyone who enjoyed the original Dawn of The Dead, but the original Dawn of The Dead is horrible. It was boring, it was stoopid, it was too slow, the dead didn't make any sense (I'll comment on that in a second) - and the main characters didn't seem to know what they wanted to focus on.One moment they are scared, the next happy and comical, then sad, then ...it was just all over the place and I am sooo glad they didn't try and stick to the original.Now....this re-make of DOTD rocks. It's just that plain and simple. Sure it is a zombie movie - but the real story plays out in what goes on between the survivors. There are a lot of hills and dips and stuff that goes on in the movie. Sure some things don't make sense of what the people are doing - but that is exactly the point. How are you suppose to make sense when your world has turned upside down.Now the zombies on the other hand - in this version, they only did one thing. They tried to get "food". That's it. That's all they could do. They followed instinct.In the original, one of the dumbest things that could have possibly happened was to see the zombies staggering around the mall..and then all of a sudden one of the Hairy Krishner one's get's the bright idea to turn around and see what's going on down the other hall.They don't think like that. Duh. Okay, maybe if the dead person was a store detective or something...but certainly not a Hairy Krishner. So, I have absolutely no problems with the zombies running. None what so ever. If they can have a Hairy Krishner get zombie smart in a boring dead movie....then zombies can run.But think about it logically for a second. The zombies are "Freshly Dead". Not in the ground rotting for century dead. But freshly reanimated dead people. They should and would be able to move as fast as they would have when they were alive.That is to say - if they were a big fat tub of lard when they were alive, they aren't gonna move like ... oh wait - nevermind that thought. But let's just say...it's a dang good movie.Go rent it if you haven't seen it yet. You will enjoy.

Review title: Terrible remake of an incredible original
Review_body: I read the above review, and wanted to completely disagree with it. As an aficionado of the Zombie genre, I too was extremely excited to see this film released. But I don't think I have ever been quite so disappointed.The original doesn't need me to describe how incredible it was. I regard it as one of my favourite films in any genre, and certainly the finest horror film ever made. In this big-budget remake they seem to have forgotten the entire premise of zombie films, and just gone all out for action.The acting and dialogue is terrible. The 'civilians' react to events rather more competently than the troops and police do in the first film, the zombies are badly made up, too fast, and overly intelligent, and there is little sense of atmosphere throughout the whole film. The post-credits handy-cam clip is perhaps the only redeeming moment of originality, but too little, too late.They even tried to use a pregnant zombie/zombie baby for shock value (See Peter Jackson's BrainDead), and they only succeeded in ruined the film further, adding an unnecessary (and probably unintentional) comedy scene.Don't waste your time on this: spend the saved money on some alcohol and watch the original again.

Review title: Dawn of a new Horrror movie
Review_body: As a film buff, I love movies. As a horror movie buff, I love horror movies. However, I have been saddened by the lack of decent horror flicks. Most of them have been mediocre at best. But now, here comes the dawn of a horror movie that is, dare i say it, AMAZING!!!!! The casting of mostly unknown stars was ideal for this movie and served the plot better than if Uma Thurman or Nicole Kidman played the leading lady. Instead, this is an ensemble driven movie, which it should feel like if survivors are uniting together against the undead. I actually felt compassion towards each and every character. The script was impeccable and the direction even better. The acting of all the unknown stars was fabulous and I LOVED the roles of Ana and that cynical guy with the boat ( I forgot his name). All of the situations felt so fresh and it never felt like I was watching a remake. The cinematography blew me away and some of the most intimate shots used with zombies actually added another dynamic to the static and boring character of a zombie. My only real gripe was that the whole Grandma showdown thing felt a little too "wild west" for me and that after the opening sequence and titles, the whole movie started off very slowly, which was strange considering there was a whole outbreak of zombies. other than that, i thought that this movie was awesome. My favorite horror movie and one of my favorite movies of all time. A DEFINITE MUST SEE AND A MUST BUY FOR HORROR FANS

Review title: Horror? No. Scary? Kinda. Good? HELLS YEAH!
Review_body: As nurse Anna and her husband enjoy a, umm, FUN time in the shower together they miss a fate deciding news broadcast declaring a plague is bringing the recently deceased back to life. In the morning, they awake to the presence of their young neighbor, only for Anna's husband to die and become a zombie. Into the ravaged streets Anna escapes, only to be rescued by a shotgun toting police officer and taken to the local Cross Roads Mall, along with some other survivors, where they will find only temporary refuge. With some help from a stray dog, they attempt to rescue a nearby gun shop owner and escape to an island that is supposedly loosely inhabited and meeting their fate...

Review title: Please Do NOT SPENT TIME on this garbage
Review_body: Omg.... that's all guys don't even try it better go play uno!
This movie is just fun to watch and it doesn't take itself too seriously. Typical zombie shooting is all I can say and it has fun characters to watch.

Writing's really stupid. Their major decisions were incredibly dumb and made no sense at all. 
Why on earth would they go to a mall to escape? There would be so many ways the zombies could get in. And shatterproof glass? Seriously? What were the odds? The mall's too big a place with different levels - what made them think that they could cover every single exit? 
And going to a boat was their best way out? Seriously? It could've been a concrete plan if it was explained to us clearly. But no all we know was that Steve had this boat and they were going to reinforce two buses as if they were all suddenly handymen and drive out to it to go to some random island they didn't even know exist.Then there's the zombies. My god were they almost hilarious. I had no idea if the movie was going for a comedic direction because it sure as hell seemed like it. I guess it was still quite entertaining, although for the wrong reasons. I could've stopped watching but I didn't. Probably wouldn't watch it again.

Review title: One thing I loved about Dawn of the Dead (2004)
Review_body: How awesome is the idea that zombies are fast? I think that is very unique and it scared the hell out of me! It keeps you on the edge of your seat through the whole movie. Also, I thought the special effects and makeup was excellent. I definitely enjoyed the directors cut. Cool stuff. It was fun learning the movie from Andy's point of view. I hope there is going to be a part two because I know that at least one person had to survive. Or at least I hope! But one question...If they had waited in the mall, would the zombies have rotted so badly that they would have died off??? Well, I hope to find that out also. Thanks for letting me comment, Monica ~Kittycat~
